Text

﻿SHE

By [H. Rider Haggard IN EARTH AND SKIE AND]251-h. rider haggard in earth and skie and [SEA]1-sea

STRANGE THYNGS THER BE

Doggerel couplet from the

Sherd of Amenartas

[I]0-i inscribe this history to

[ANDREW LANG]104-andrew lang

in token of personal regard

and of

[my]0-i sincere admiration for [his]104-andrew lang learning and [his]104-andrew lang works

INTRODUCTION

In giving to [the world]252-the world the record of what , looked at as an adventure only , is [I]0-i suppose one of the most wonderful and mysterious experiences ever undergone by [mortal men]253-mortal men , [I]0-i feel it incumbent on [me]0-i to explain what [my]0-i exact connection with it is . And so [I]0-i may as well say at once that [I]0-i am not [the narrator]254-the narrator but only [the editor of this extraordinary history]255-the editor of this extraordinary history , and then go on to tell how it found its way into [my]0-i hands .

Some years ago [I]0-i , [the editor]256-the editor , was stopping with [a friend]257-a friend , " vir doctissimus et amicus neus , "[257-a friend] at [a certain University , which for the purposes of this history [we]259-we will call [Cambridge]2-cambridge]258-a certain university , which for the purposes of this history we will call cambridge , and was one day much struck with the appearance of [two persons whom [I]0-i saw going arm - in - arm down [the street]261-the street]260-two persons whom i saw going arm - in - arm down the street . [One of [these gentlemen]263-these gentlemen]262-one of these gentlemen was [I]0-i think , without exception , [the handsomest young fellow [I]0-i have ever seen]264-the handsomest young fellow i have ever seen . [He]264-the handsomest young fellow i have ever seen was very tall , very broad , and had a look of power and a grace of bearing that seemed as native to [him]264-the handsomest young fellow i have ever seen as it is to a wild stag . In addition [his]264-the handsomest young fellow i have ever seen face was almost without flaw - a good face as well as a beautiful one , and when [he]264-the handsomest young fellow i have ever seen lifted [his]264-the handsomest young fellow i have ever seen hat , which [he]264-the handsomest young fellow i have ever seen did just then to [a passing lady]265-a passing lady , [I]0-i saw that [his]264-the handsomest young fellow i have ever seen head was covered with little golden curls growing close to the scalp .

" Good gracious ! "[0-i] [I]0-i said to [[my]0-i friend]266-my friend , with whom [I]0-i was walking , " why , [that fellow]3001-that fellow looks like a statue of [Apollo]105-apollo come to life . What [a splendid man]3002-a splendid man [he]3001-that fellow is ! "[0-i]

" Yes , "[266-my friend] [he]266-my friend answered , " [he]3001-that fellow is [the handsomest man in [the University]3004-the university]3003-the handsomest man in the university , and one of the nicest too . [They]3005-they call [him]3001-that fellow ' [the Greek god ']3006-the greek god ' ; but look at [the other one]3007-the other one , [he]3007-the other one 's [Vincey]106-vincey 's that 's [the god]3008-the god 's name guardian , and supposed to be full of every kind of information . [They]3005-they call [him]3001-that fellow ' [Charon]107-charon . ' "[266-my friend] [I]0-i looked , and found [the older man]267-the older man quite as interesting in [his]267-the older man way as [the glorified specimen of humanity at [his]267-the older man side]268-the glorified specimen of humanity at his side . [He]267-the older man appeared to be about forty years of age , and was [I]0-i think as ugly as [[his]267-the older man companion]269-his companion was handsome . To begin with , [he]267-the older man was shortish , rather bow - legged , very deep chested , and with unusually long arms . [He]267-the older man had dark hair and small eyes , and the hair grew right down on [his]267-the older man forehead , and [his]267-the older man whiskers grew right up to [his]267-the older man hair , so that there was uncommonly little of [his]267-the older man countenance to be seen . Altogether [he]267-the older man reminded [me]0-i forcibly of [a gorilla]270-a gorilla , and yet there was something very pleasing and genial about [the man]271-the man 's eye . [I]0-i remember saying that [I]0-i should like to know [him]267-the older man .

" All right , "[267-the older man] answered [[my]0-i friend]266-my friend , " nothing easier . [I]267-the older man know [Vincey]106-vincey ; [I]267-the older man 'll introduce [you]106-vincey , "[267-the older man] and [he]267-the older man did , and for some minutes [we]273-we stood chatting - about [the Zulu people]274-the zulu people , [I]0-i think , for [I]0-i had just returned from [the Cape]3-the cape at the time . Presently , however , [a stoutish lady , whose name [I]0-i do not remember]275-a stoutish lady , whose name i do not remember , came along [the pavement]276-the pavement , accompanied by [a pretty fair - haired girl]277-a pretty fair - haired girl , and [these two [Mr. Vincey]108-leo , who clearly knew [them]279-them well , at once joined , walking off in [their]279-them company]278-these two mr. vincey , who clearly knew them well , at once joined , walking off in their company . [I]0-i remember being rather amused because of the change in the expression of [the elder man]280-the elder man , whose name [I]0-i discovered was [Holly]109-holly , when [he]280-the elder man saw [the ladies]281-the ladies advancing . [He]280-the elder man suddenly stopped short in [his]280-the elder man talk , cast a reproachful look at [[his]280-the elder man companion]269-his companion , and , with an abrupt nod to [myself]0-i , turned and marched off alone across [the street]261-the street . [I]0-i heard afterwards that [he]280-the elder man was popularly supposed to be as much afraid of [a woman]284-a woman as [most people]285-most people are of a mad dog , which accounted for [his]280-the elder man precipitate retreat . [I]0-i can not say , however , that [young Vincey]108-leo showed much aversion to feminine society on this occasion . Indeed [I]0-i remember laughing , and remarking to [[my]0-i friend]266-my friend at the time that [he]280-the elder man was not [the sort of man whom it would be desirable to introduce to [the lady one was going to marry]288-the lady one was going to marry , since it was exceedingly probable that [the acquaintance]289-the acquaintance would end in a transfer of [her]288-the lady one was going to marry affections]287-the sort of man whom it would be desirable to introduce to the lady one was going to marry , since it was exceedingly probable that the acquaintance would end in a transfer of her affections . [He]280-the elder man was altogether too good - looking , and , what is more , [he]280-the elder man had none of that consciousness and conceit about [him]280-the elder man which usually afflicts [handsome men]290-handsome men , and makes [them]290-handsome men deservedly disliked by [[their]290-handsome men fellows]291-their fellows .

That same evening [my]0-i visit came to an end , and this was the last [I]0-i saw or heard of " [Charon]107-charon "[0-i] and " [the Greek god]3009-the greek god "[0-i] for many a long day . Indeed , [I]0-i have never seen either of [them]292-them from that hour to this , and do not think it probable that [I]0-i shall . But a month ago [I]0-i received a letter and two packets , one of manuscript , and on opening the first found that it was signed by " [Horace Holly]110-horace holly , "[293-i] a name that at the moment was not familiar to [me]0-i . It ran as follows : -

" - - College , [Cambridge]2-cambridge , May 1 , 18 -[293-i]

" [[My]293-i dear Sir]3010-my dear sir , - [You]3010-my dear sir will be surprised , considering the very slight nature of [our]3011-our acquaintance , to get a letter from [me]293-i . Indeed , [I]293-i think [I]293-i had better begin by reminding [you]3010-my dear sir that [we]3011-our once met , now some five years ago , when [I]293-i and [[my]293-i ward]3012-my ward [Leo Vincey]108-leo were introduced to [you]3010-my dear sir in [the street at [Cambridge]2-cambridge]3013-the street at cambridge . To be brief and come to [my]293-i business . [I]293-i have recently read with much interest a book of yours describing a Central African adventure . [I]293-i take it that this book is partly true , and partly an effort of the imagination . However this may be , it has given [me]293-i an idea . It happens , how [you]3010-my dear sir will see in the accompanying manuscript which together with the Scarab , the ' [Royal Son of [the Sun]3015-the sun]3014-royal son of the sun , ' and the original sherd , [I]293-i am sending to [you]3010-my dear sir by hand , that [[my]293-i ward]3012-my ward , or rather [[my]293-i adopted son]3017-my adopted son [Leo Vincey]108-leo and [myself]293-i have recently passed through a real African adventure , of a nature so much more marvellous than the one which [you]3010-my dear sir describe , that to tell the truth [I]293-i am almost ashamed to submit it to [you]3010-my dear sir lest [you]3010-my dear sir should disbelieve [my]293-i tale . [You]3010-my dear sir will see it stated in this manuscript that [I]293-i , or rather [we]3018-we , had made up [our]3018-we minds not to make this history public during [our]3018-we joint lives . Nor should [we]3018-we alter [our]3018-we determination were it not for a circumstance which has recently arisen . [We]3018-we are for reasons that , after perusing this manuscript , [you]3010-my dear sir may be able to guess , going away again this time to [Central Asia]4-central asia where , if anywhere upon [this earth]3019-this earth , wisdom is to be found , and [we]3018-we anticipate that [our]3018-we sojourn there will be a long one . Possibly [we]3018-we shall not return . Under these altered conditions it has become a question whether [we]3018-we are justified in withholding from [the world]252-the world an account of a phenomenon which [we]3018-we believe to be of unparalleled interest , merely because [our]3018-we private life is involved , or because [we]3018-we are afraid of ridicule and doubt being cast upon [our]3018-we statements . [I]293-i hold one view about this matter , and [Leo]108-leo holds another , and finally , after much discussion , [we]3018-we have come to a compromise , namely , to send the history to [you]3010-my dear sir , giving [you]3010-my dear sir full leave to publish it if [you]3010-my dear sir think fit , the only stipulation being that [you]3010-my dear sir shall disguise [our]3018-we real names , and as much concerning [our]3018-we personal identity as is consistent with the maintenance of the bona fides of the narrative .[293-i]

" And now what am [I]293-i to say further ? [I]293-i really do not know beyond once more repeating that everything is described in the accompanying manuscript exactly as it happened . As regards [She]3021-she [herself]3021-she [I]293-i have nothing to add . Day by day [we]3018-we gave greater occasion to regret that [we]3018-we did not better avail [ourselves]3018-we of [our]3018-we opportunities to obtain more information from [that marvellous woman]3022-that marvellous woman . Who was [she]293-i ? How did [she]293-i first come to [the Caves of [K"r]111-k"r]5-the caves of k"r[293-i] , and what was [her]293-i real religion ? [We]294-we never ascertained , and now , alas ! [we]294-we never shall , at least not yet . These and many other questions arise in [my]0-i mind , but what is the good of asking [them]295-them now ?

" Will [you]3023-you undertake the task ? [We]294-we give [you]3023-you complete freedom , and as a reward [you]3023-you will , [we]294-we believe , have the credit of presenting to [the world]252-the world the most wonderful history , as distinguished from romance , that its records can show . Read the manuscript which [I]297-editor have copied out fairly for [your]3023-you benefit , and let [me]297-editor know .[297-editor]

" Believe [me]110-horace holly , very truly [yours]3023-you , "[110-horace holly] [L. Horace Holly]110-horace holly .

" P.S. - Of course , if any profit results from the sale of the writing should [you]3023-you care to undertake its publication , [you]3023-you can do what [you]3023-you like with it , but if there is a loss [I]297-editor will leave instructions with [[my]297-editor lawyers]3025-my lawyers , [Messrs. Geoffrey]112-messrs. geoffrey and [Jordan]113-jordan , to meet it . [We]3026-we entrust the sherd , the scarab , and the parchments to [your]3023-you keeping , till such time as [we]3026-we demand them back again . - L. H. H. "[297-editor]

This name is varied throughout in accordance with [the writer]296-the writer 's request . - [Editor]297-editor .

This letter , as may be imagined , astonished [me]0-i considerably , but when [I]0-i came to look at the MS . , which the pressure of other work prevented [me]0-i from doing for a fortnight , [I]0-i was still more astonished , as [I]0-i think [the reader]298-the reader will be also , and at once made up [my]0-i mind to press on with the matter . [I]0-i wrote to this effect to [Mr. Holly]109-holly , but a week afterwards received a letter from [[that gentleman]299-that gentleman 's lawyers]300-that gentleman 's lawyers , returning [my]0-i own , with the information that [[their]300-that gentleman 's lawyers client]301-their client and [Mr. Leo Vincey]108-leo had already left [this country]302-this country for [Thibet]6-thibet , and [they]300-that gentleman 's lawyers did not at present know [their]300-that gentleman 's lawyers address .

Well , that is all [I]0-i have to say . Of the history itself [the reader]298-the reader must judge . [I]0-i give it [him]298-the reader , with the exception of a very few alterations , made with the object of concealing the identity of [the actors]304-the actors from [the general public]305-the general public , exactly as it came to [me]0-i . Personally [I]0-i have made up [my]0-i mind to refrain from comments . At first [I]0-i was inclined to believe that this history of [a woman on whom]306-a woman on whom , clothed in the majesty of [her]306-a woman on whom almost endless years , the shadow of Eternity itself lay like the dark wing of Night , was some gigantic allegory of which [I]0-i could not catch the meaning . Then [I]0-i thought that it might be a bold attempt to portray the possible results of practical immortality , informing the substance of [a mortal who yet drew [her]306-a woman on whom strength from [Earth]308-earth , and in whose human bosom passions yet rose and fell and beat as in the undying world around [her]306-a woman on whom]307-a mortal who yet drew her strength from earth , and in whose human bosom passions yet rose and fell and beat as in the undying world around her the winds and the tides rise and fall and beat unceasingly . But as [I]0-i went on [I]0-i abandoned that idea also . To [me]0-i the story seems to bear the stamp of truth upon its face . Its explanation [I]0-i must leave to [others]309-others , and with this slight preface , which circumstances make necessary , [I]0-i introduce [the world]252-the world to [Ayesha]114-ayesha and [the Caves of [K"r]111-k"r]5-the caves of k"r . - [The Editor]256-the editor .[298-the reader]

P.S. - There is on consideration one circumstance that , after a reperusal of this history , struck [me]0-i with so much force that [I]0-i can not resist calling the attention of [the reader]298-the reader to it . [He]298-the reader will observe that so far as [we]312-we are made acquainted with [him]298-the reader there appears to be nothing in the character of [Leo Vincey]108-leo which in the opinion of [most people]285-most people would have been likely to attract an intellect so powerful as that of [Ayesha]114-ayesha . [He]298-the reader is not even , at any rate to [my]0-i view , particularly interesting . Indeed , one might imagine that [Mr. Holly]109-holly would under ordinary circumstances have easily outstripped [him]298-the reader in the favour of [She]114-ayesha . Can it be that [extremes]314-extremes meet , and that the very excess and splendour of [her]114-ayesha mind led [her]114-ayesha by means of some strange physical reaction to worship at the shrine of matter ? Was [that ancient Kallikrates]315-that ancient kallikrates nothing but a splendid animal loved for [his]315-that ancient kallikrates hereditary Greek beauty ? Or is the true explanation what [I]0-i believe it to be - namely , that [Ayesha]114-ayesha , seeing further than [we]312-we can see , perceived the germ and smouldering spark of greatness which lay hid within [[her]114-ayesha lover]316-her lover 's soul , and well knew that under the influence of [her]114-ayesha gift of life , watered by [her]114-ayesha wisdom , and shone upon with the sunshine of [her]114-ayesha presence , it would bloom like a flower and flash out like a star , filling [the world]252-the world with light and fragrance ?

Here also [I]0-i am not able to answer , but must leave [the reader]298-the reader to form [his]298-the reader own judgment on the facts before [him]298-the reader , as detailed by [Mr. Holly]109-holly in the following pages .

[I]0-i

[MY]0-i VISITOR

There are some events of which each circumstance and surrounding detail seems to be graven on the memory in such fashion that [we]312-we can not forget it , and so it is with the scene that [I]0-i am about to describe . It rises as clearly before [my]0-i mind at this moment as though it had happened but yesterday .

It was in this very month something over twenty years ago that [I]0-i , [Ludwig Horace Holly]109-holly , was sitting one night in [[my]0-i rooms at [Cambridge]2-cambridge]319-my rooms at cambridge , grinding away at some mathematical work , [I]0-i forget what . [I]0-i was to go up for [my]0-i fellowship within a week , and was expected by [[my]0-i tutor]320-my tutor and [[my]0-i college]321-my college generally to distinguish [myself]0-i . At last , wearied out , [I]0-i flung [my]0-i book down , and , going to the mantelpiece , took down a pipe and filled it . There was a candle burning on the mantelpiece , and a long , narrow glass at the back of it ; and as [I]0-i was in the act of lighting the pipe [I]0-i caught sight of [my]0-i own countenance in the glass , and paused to reflect . The lighted match burnt away till it scorched [my]0-i fingers , forcing [me]0-i to drop it ; but still [I]0-i stood and stared at [myself]0-i in the glass , and reflected .

" Well , "[0-i] [I]0-i said aloud , at last , " it is to be hoped that [I]0-i shall be able to do something with the inside of [my]0-i head , for [I]0-i shall certainly never do anything by the help of the outside . "[0-i]

This remark will doubtless strike anybody who reads it as being slightly obscure , but [I]0-i was in reality alluding to [my]0-i physical deficiencies . [Most men of twenty - two]322-most men of twenty - two are endowed at any rate with some share of the comeliness of youth , but to [me]0-i even this was denied . Short , thick - set , and deep - chested almost to deformity , with long sinewy arms , heavy features , deep - set grey eyes , a low brow half overgrown with a mop of thick black hair , like a deserted clearing on which [the forest]323-the forest had once more begun to encroach ; such was [my]0-i appearance nearly a quarter of a century ago , and such , with some modification , it is to this day . Like [Cain]116-cain , [I]0-i was branded - branded by Nature with the stamp of abnormal ugliness , as [I]0-i was gifted by Nature with iron and abnormal strength and considerable intellectual powers . So ugly was [I]0-i that [the spruce young men of [my]0-i College]324-the spruce young men of my college , though [they]324-the spruce young men of my college were proud enough of [my]0-i feats of endurance and physical prowess , did not even care to be seen walking with [me]0-i . Was it wonderful that [I]0-i was misanthropic and sullen ? Was it wonderful that [I]0-i brooded and worked alone , and had [no friends]325-no friends - at least , only one ? [I]0-i was set apart by Nature to live alone , and draw comfort from [her]326-her breast , and [hers]326-her only . [Women]327-women hated the sight of [me]0-i . Only a week before [I]0-i had heard [one]328-one call [me]0-i a " monster "[328-one] when [she]328-one thought [I]0-i was out of hearing , and say that [I]0-i had converted [her]328-one to the monkey theory . Once , indeed , [a woman]284-a woman pretended to care for [me]0-i , and [I]0-i lavished all the pent - up affection of [my]0-i nature upon [her]284-a woman . Then money that was to have come to [me]0-i went elsewhere , and [she]284-a woman discarded [me]0-i . [I]0-i pleaded with [her]284-a woman as [I]0-i have never pleaded with [any living creature]330-any living creature before or since , for [I]0-i was caught by [her]284-a woman sweet face , and loved [her]284-a woman ; and in the end by way of answer [she]284-a woman took [me]0-i to the glass , and stood side by side with [me]0-i , and looked into it .

" Now , "[284-a woman] [she]284-a woman said , " if [I]284-a woman am [Beauty]117-beauty , who are [you]0-i ? "[284-a woman] That was when [I]0-i was only twenty .

And so [I]0-i stood and stared , and felt a sort of grim satisfaction in the sense of [my]0-i own loneliness ; for [I]0-i had neither [father]331-father , nor [mother]332-mother , nor [brother]333-brother ; and as [I]0-i did so there came a knock at [my]0-i door .

[I]0-i listened before [I]0-i went to open it , for it was nearly twelve o'clock at night , and [I]0-i was in no mood to admit [any stranger]334-any stranger . [I]0-i had but [one friend in [the College]336-the college]335-one friend in the college , or , indeed , in [the world]252-the world - perhaps it was [he]335-one friend in the college .

Just then [the person outside the door]338-the person outside the door coughed , and [I]0-i hastened to open it , for [I]0-i knew the cough .

[A tall man of about thirty , with the remains of great personal beauty]339-a tall man of about thirty , with the remains of great personal beauty , came hurrying in , staggering beneath the weight of a massive iron box which [he]339-a tall man of about thirty , with the remains of great personal beauty carried by a handle with [his]339-a tall man of about thirty , with the remains of great personal beauty right hand . [He]339-a tall man of about thirty , with the remains of great personal beauty placed the box upon the table , and then fell into an awful fit of coughing . [[His]3061-the priest wife]3066-his wife , however , escaped , how , [I]341-i know not , to [Athens]11-athens , bearing [a child with [her]3066-his wife , whom [she]3066-his wife named [Tisisthenes]122-tisisthenes , or [the Mighty Avenger]3077-the mighty avenger]3076-a child with her , whom she named tisisthenes , or the mighty avenger . Five hundred years or more afterwards , [the family]3078-the family migrated to [Rome]12-rome under circumstances of which no trace remains , and here , probably with the idea of preserving the idea of vengeance which [we]3079-we find set out in the name of [Tisisthenes]122-tisisthenes , [they]3078-the family appear to have pretty regularly assumed the cognomen of [Vindex]123-vindex , or [Avenger]3080-avenger . Here , too , [they]3078-the family remained for another five centuries or more , till about 770 A.D. , when [Charlemagne]124-charlemagne invaded [Lombardy]13-lombardy , where [they]3078-the family were then settled , whereon [the head of [the family]3078-the family]3081-the head of the family seems to have attached [himself]3081-the head of the family to [the great Emperor]3083-the great emperor , and to have returned with [him]3083-the great emperor across [the Alps]3084-the alps , and finally to have settled in [Brittany]14-brittany . Eight generations later [[his]3083-the great emperor lineal representative]3085-his lineal representative crossed to [England]15-england in the reign of [Edward the Confessor]125-edward the confessor , and in the time of [William the Conqueror]126-billy was advanced to great honour and power . From that time to the present day [I]341-i can trace [my]341-i descent without a break . Not that [the Vinceys]127-the vinceys - for that was the final corruption of the name after its bearers took root in [English soil]3086-english soil - have been particularly distinguished - [they]3078-the family never came much to the fore . Sometimes [they]3078-the family were [soldiers]3087-soldiers , sometimes [merchants]3088-merchants , but on the whole [they]3078-the family have preserved a dead level of respectability , and a still deader level of mediocrity . From the time of [Charles II]128-charles ii . till the beginning of the present century [they]3078-the family were [merchants]3088-merchants . About 1790 by [grandfather]3090-grandfather made a considerable fortune out of brewing , and retired . In 1821 [he]341-i died , and [[my]341-i father]3091-my father succeeded [him]341-i , and dissipated most of the money . Ten years ago [he]341-i died also , leaving [me]341-i a net income of about two thousand a year . Then it was that [I]341-i undertook an expedition in connection with that , "[341-i] and [he]341-i pointed to the iron chest , " which ended disastrously enough . [The Strong and Beautiful]129-the strong and beautiful , or , more accurately , the Beautiful in strength .

The Kallikrates here referred to by [[my]0-i friend]266-my friend was [a Spartan]343-a spartan , spoken of by [Herodotus Herod]120-herod . ix . 72 as being remarkable for [his]343-a spartan beauty . "[349-i]

[I]0-i said nothing , being , indeed , too bewildered to speak .

[He]349-i held up the candle , and looked at [his]349-i own face in the glass . It had been a beautiful face , but disease had wrecked it . " Food for the worms , "[349-i] [he]349-i said . " Curious to think that in a few hours [I]349-i shall be stiff and cold - the journey done , the little game played out . Ah [me]349-i , [Holly]109-holly ! life is not worth the trouble of life , except when [one]328-one is in love - at least , [mine]349-i has not been ; but the boy [Leo]108-leo 's may be if [he]108-leo has the courage and the faith . "[349-i] and with a sudden access of tenderness [he]349-i flung [his]349-i arm about [me]0-i and kissed [me]0-i on the forehead , and then turned to go .

" Look here , [Vincey]108-leo , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " if [you]108-leo are as ill as [you]108-leo think , [you]108-leo had better let [me]0-i fetch [a doctor]3029-a doctor . "[0-i]

" No , no , "[349-i] [he]349-i said earnestly . " Promise [me]349-i that [you]0-i wo n't . [I]349-i am going to die , and , like a poisoned rat , [I]349-i wish to die alone . "[349-i]

" [I]0-i do n't believe that [you]349-i are going to do anything of the sort , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered . [He]349-i smiled , and , with the word " Remember "[349-i] on [his]349-i lips , was gone . As for [myself]0-i , [I]0-i sat down and rubbed [my]0-i eyes , wondering if [I]0-i had been asleep . As this supposition would not bear investigation [I]0-i gave it up and began to think that [Vincey]108-leo must have been drinking . [I]0-i knew that [he]108-leo was , and had been , very ill , but still it seemed impossible that [he]108-leo could be in such a condition as to be able to know for certain that [he]108-leo would not outlive the night . Had [he]108-leo been so near dissolution surely [he]108-leo would scarcely have been able to walk , and carry a heavy iron box with [him]108-leo . The whole story , on reflection , seemed to [me]0-i utterly incredible , for [I]0-i was not then old enough to be aware how many things happen in [this world]350-this world that the common sense of [the average man]351-the average man would set down as so improbable as to be absolutely impossible . This is a fact that [I]0-i have only recently mastered . Was it likely that [a man]352-a man would have [a son five years of age whom [he]352-a man had never seen since [he]353-a son five years of age whom he had never seen since he was a tiny infant was [a tiny infant]354-a tiny infant]353-a son five years of age whom he had never seen since he was a tiny infant ? No . Was it likely that [he]352-a man could foretell [his]352-a man own death so accurately ? No . Was it likely that [he]352-a man could trace [his]352-a man pedigree for more than three centuries before [Christ]121-christ , or that [he]352-a man would suddenly confide the absolute guardianship of [[his]352-a man child]355-his child , and leave half [his]352-a man fortune , to [a college friend]356-a college friend ? Most certainly not . Clearly [Vincey]108-leo was either drunk or mad . That being so , what did it mean ? and what was in the sealed iron chest ?

The whole thing baffled and puzzled [me]0-i to such an extent that at last [I]0-i could stand it no longer , and determined to sleep over it . So [I]0-i jumped up , and having put the keys and the letter that [Vincey]108-leo had left away into [my]0-i despatch - box , and stowed the iron chest in a large portmanteau , [I]0-i turned in , and was soon fast asleep .

As it seemed to [me]0-i , [I]0-i had only been asleep for a few minutes when [I]0-i was awakened by [somebody]357-somebody calling [me]0-i . [I]0-i sat up and rubbed [my]0-i eyes ; it was broad daylight - eight o'clock , in fact .

" Why , what is the matter with [you]358-the gyp who waited on vincey and myself , [John]106-vincey ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked of [the gyp who waited on [Vincey]106-vincey and [myself]0-i]358-the gyp who waited on vincey and myself . " [You]358-the gyp who waited on vincey and myself look as though [you]358-the gyp who waited on vincey and myself had seen a ghost ! "[0-i]

" Yes , [sir]3126-sir , and so [I]358-the gyp who waited on vincey and myself have , "[358-the gyp who waited on vincey and myself] [he]358-the gyp who waited on vincey and myself answered , " leastways [I]358-the gyp who waited on vincey and myself 've seen a corpse , which is worse . [I]358-the gyp who waited on vincey and myself 've been in to call [Mr. Vincey]108-leo , as usual , and there [he]108-leo lies stark and dead ! "[358-the gyp who waited on vincey and myself]

II

THE YEARS ROLL BY

As might be expected , poor [Vincey]108-leo 's sudden death created a great stir in [the College]336-the college ; but , as [he]108-leo was known to be very ill , and [a satisfactory doctor]360-a satisfactory doctor 's certificate was forthcoming , there was no inquest . [They]361-they were not so particular about inquests in those days as they are now ; indeed , [they]361-they were generally disliked , because of the scandal . Under all these circumstances , being asked no questions , [I]0-i did not feel called upon to volunteer any information about [our]362-our interview on the night of [Vincey]108-leo 's decease , beyond saying that [he]108-leo had come into [[my]0-i rooms]363-my rooms to see [me]0-i , as [he]108-leo often did . On the day of the funeral [a lawyer]364-a lawyer came down from [London]19-london and followed [[my]0-i poor friend]365-my poor friend 's remains to [the grave]366-the grave , and then went back with [his]108-leo papers and effects , except , of course , the iron chest which had been left in [my]0-i keeping . For a week after this [I]0-i heard no more of the matter , and , indeed , [my]0-i attention was amply occupied in other ways , for [I]0-i was up for [my]0-i Fellowship , a fact that had prevented [me]0-i from attending the funeral or seeing [the lawyer]367-the lawyer . At last , however , the examination was over , and [I]0-i came back to [[my]0-i rooms]363-my rooms and sank into an easy chair with a happy consciousness that [I]0-i had got through it very fairly .

Soon , however , [my]0-i thoughts , relieved of the pressure that had crushed them into a single groove during the last few days , turned to the events of the night of poor [Vincey]108-leo 's death , and again [I]0-i asked [myself]0-i what it all meant , and wondered if [I]0-i should hear anything more of the matter , and if [I]0-i did not , what it would be [my]0-i duty to do with the curious iron chest . [I]0-i sat there and thought and thought till [I]0-i began to grow quite disturbed over the whole occurrence : the mysterious midnight visit , the prophecy of death so shortly to be fulfilled , the solemn oath that [I]0-i had taken , and which [Vincey]108-leo had called on [me]0-i to answer to in [another world than this]369-another world than this . Had [the man]271-the man committed suicide ? It looked like it . And what was the quest of which [he]108-leo spoke ? The circumstances were uncanny , so much so that , though [I]0-i am by no means nervous , or apt to be alarmed at anything that may seem to cross the bounds of the natural , [I]0-i grew afraid , and began to wish [I]0-i had nothing to do with them . How much more do [I]0-i wish it now , over twenty years afterwards !

As [I]0-i sat and thought , there came a knock at the door , and a letter , in a big blue envelope , was brought in to [me]0-i . [I]0-i saw at a glance that it was [a lawyer]364-a lawyer 's letter , and an instinct told [me]0-i that it was connected with [my]0-i trust . The letter , which [I]0-i still have , runs thus : -

" [Sir]3126-sir , - [[Our]3128-we client]3129-our client , [the late M. L. Vincey]135-the late m. l. vincey , [Esq .]3130-esq . , who died on the 9th instant in - - College , [Cambridge]2-cambridge , has left behind [him]271-the man a Will , of which [you]3126-sir will please find copy enclosed and of which [we]3128-we are [the executors]3131-the executors . Under this Will [you]3126-sir will perceive that [you]3126-sir take a life - interest in about half of [[the late Mr. Vincey]108-leo 's property]3132-the late mr. vincey 's property , now invested in Consols , subject to [your]3126-sir acceptance of the guardianship of [[his]108-leo only son]3133-his only son , [Leo Vincey]108-leo , at present [an infant , aged five]3134-an infant , aged five . Had [we]3128-we not [ourselves]3128-we drawn up the document in question in obedience to [Mr. Vincey]108-leo 's clear and precise instructions , both personal and written , and had [he]108-leo not then assured [us]3128-we that [he]108-leo had very good reasons for what [he]108-leo was doing , [we]3128-we are bound to tell [you]3126-sir that its provisions seem to [us]3128-we of so unusual a nature , that [we]3128-we should have bound to call the attention of [the Court of Chancery]3135-the court of chancery to [them]3136-them , in order that such steps might be taken as seemed desirable to it , either by contesting the capacity of [the testator]3137-the testator or otherwise , to safeguard the interests of [the infant]3138-the infant . As it is , knowing that [the testator]3137-the testator was [a gentleman of the highest intelligence and acumen]3140-a gentleman of the highest intelligence and acumen , and that [he]3137-the testator has absolutely no relations living to whom [he]3137-the testator could have confided the guardianship of [the child]3122-the child , [we]3128-we do not feel justified in taking this course .[364-a lawyer]

" Awaiting such instructions as [you]3126-sir please to send [us]3128-we as regards the delivery of [the infant]3138-the infant and the payment of the proportion of the dividends due to [you]3126-sir ,[108-leo]

" [We]3128-we remain , [Sir]3126-sir , faithfully [yours]3126-sir ,[364-a lawyer]

" [Geoffrey]112-messrs. geoffrey and [Jordan]113-jordan .[108-leo]

" [Horace L. Holly]136-horatio , [Esq]3144-esq . "[364-a lawyer]

[I]0-i put down the letter , and ran [my]0-i eye through the Will , which appeared , from its utter unintelligibility , to have been drawn on the strictest legal principles . So far as [I]0-i could discover , however , it exactly bore out what [[my]0-i friend]266-my friend [Vincey]108-leo had told [me]0-i on the night of [his]108-leo death . So it was true after all . [I]0-i must take [the boy]3044-the boy . Suddenly [I]0-i remembered the letter which [Vincey]108-leo had left with the chest . [I]0-i fetched and opened it . It only contained such directions as [he]108-leo had already given to [me]0-i as to opening the chest on [Leo]108-leo 's twenty - fifth birthday , and laid down the outlines of [the boy]3044-the boy 's education , which was to include Greek , the higher Mathematics , and Arabic . At the end there was a postscript to the effect that if [the boy]3044-the boy died under the age of twenty - five , which , however , [he]108-leo did not believe would be the case , [I]0-i was to open the chest , and act on the information [I]0-i obtained if [I]0-i saw fit . If [I]0-i did not see fit , [I]0-i was to destroy all the contents . On no account was [I]0-i to pass them on to [a stranger]3108-a stranger .

As this letter added nothing material to [my]0-i knowledge , and certainly raised no further objection in [my]0-i mind to entering on the task [I]0-i had promised [[my]0-i dead friend]377-my dead friend to undertake , there was only one course open to [me]0-i - namely , to write to [Messrs. Geoffrey]112-messrs. geoffrey and [Jordan]113-jordan , and express [my]0-i acceptance of the trust , stating that [I]0-i should be willing to commence [my]0-i guardianship of [Leo]108-leo in ten days ' time . This done [I]0-i went to [the authorities of [[my]0-i college]321-my college]378-the authorities of my college , and , having told [them]378-the authorities of my college as much of the story as [I]0-i considered desirable , which was not very much , after considerable difficulty succeeded in persuading [them]378-the authorities of my college to stretch a point , and , in the event of [my]0-i having obtained a fellowship , which [I]0-i was pretty certain [I]0-i had done , allow [me]0-i to have [the child]3122-the child to live with [me]0-i . [Their]378-the authorities of my college consent , however , was only granted on the condition that [I]0-i vacated [[my]0-i rooms in [college]3035-college]381-my rooms in college and took lodgings . This [I]0-i did , and with some difficulty succeeded in obtaining [very good apartments quite close to [the college]336-the college gates]383-very good apartments quite close to the college gates . The next thing was to find [a nurse]385-a nurse . And on this point [I]0-i came to a determination . [I]0-i would have [no woman]386-no woman to lord it over [me]0-i about [the child]3122-the child , and steal [his]3122-the child affections from [me]0-i . [The boy]3044-the boy was old enough to do without female assistance , so [I]0-i set to work to hunt up [a suitable male attendant]389-a suitable male attendant . With some difficulty [I]0-i succeeded in hiring [a most respectable round - faced young man , who had been [a helper in a hunting - stable]391-a helper in a hunting - stable , but who said that [he]390-a most respectable round - faced young man , who had been a helper in a hunting - stable , but who said that he was one of a family of seventeen and well - accustomed to the ways of children was one of [a family of seventeen and well - accustomed to the ways of children]392-a family of seventeen and well - accustomed to the ways of children]390-a most respectable round - faced young man , who had been a helper in a hunting - stable , but who said that he was one of a family of seventeen and well - accustomed to the ways of children , and professed [himself]390-a most respectable round - faced young man , who had been a helper in a hunting - stable , but who said that he was one of a family of seventeen and well - accustomed to the ways of children quite willing to undertake the charge of [Master Leo]108-leo when [he]390-a most respectable round - faced young man , who had been a helper in a hunting - stable , but who said that he was one of a family of seventeen and well - accustomed to the ways of children arrived . Then , having taken the iron box to [town]393-town , and with [my]0-i own hands deposited it at [[my]0-i banker]394-my banker 's , [I]0-i bought some books upon the health and management of [children]395-children and read them , first to [myself]0-i , and then aloud to [Job]137-job - that was [the young man]396-the young man 's name - and waited .

At length [the child]3122-the child arrived in the charge of [an elderly person]398-an elderly person , who wept bitterly at parting with [him]396-the young man , and [a beautiful boy [he]3122-the child was]399-a beautiful boy he was . Indeed , [I]0-i do not think that [I]0-i ever saw [such a perfect child]400-such a perfect child before or since . [His]396-the young man eyes were grey , [his]396-the young man forehead was broad , and [his]396-the young man face , even at that early age , clean cut as a cameo , without being pinched or thin . But perhaps [his]396-the young man most attractive point was [his]396-the young man hair , which was pure gold in colour and tightly curled over [his]396-the young man shapely head . [He]396-the young man cried a little when [[his]396-the young man nurse]401-his nurse finally tore [herself]401-his nurse away and left [him]396-the young man with [us]402-us . Never shall [I]0-i forget the scene . There [he]396-the young man stood , with the sunlight from the window playing upon [his]396-the young man golden curls , [his]396-the young man fist screwed over one eye , whilst [he]396-the young man took [us]402-us in with the other . [I]0-i was seated in a chair , and stretched out [my]0-i hand to [him]396-the young man to induce [him]396-the young man to come to [me]0-i , while [Job]137-job , in the corner , was making a sort of clucking noise , which , arguing from [his]396-the young man previous experience , or from the analogy of the hen , [he]396-the young man judged would have a soothing effect , and inspire confidence in the youthful mind , and running a wooden horse of peculiar hideousness backwards and forwards in a way that was little short of inane . This went on for some minutes , and then all of a sudden [the lad]403-the lad stretched out both [his]403-the lad little arms and ran to [me]0-i .

" [I]396-the young man like [you]0-i , "[396-the young man] [he]396-the young man said : " [you]0-i is ugly , but [you]0-i is good . "[396-the young man]

Ten minutes afterwards [he]396-the young man was eating large slices of bread and butter , with every sign of satisfaction ; [Job]137-job wanted to put jam on to them , but [I]0-i sternly reminded [him]396-the young man of the excellent works that [we]404-we had read , and forbade it .

In a very little while for , as [I]0-i expected , [I]0-i got [my]0-i fellowship [the boy]3044-the boy became the favourite of [the whole]406-the whole [College]20-college - where , all orders and regulations to the contrary notwithstanding , [he]3044-the boy was continually in and out - a sort of chartered libertine , in whose favour all rules were relaxed . The offerings made at [[his]396-the young man shrine]407-his shrine were simply without number , and [I]0-i had serious difference of opinion with [one old resident Fellow]408-one old resident fellow , now long dead , who was usually supposed to be [the crustiest man in [the University]3004-the university , and to abhor the sight of [a child]411-a child]409-the crustiest man in the university , and to abhor the sight of a child . And yet [I]0-i discovered , when a frequently recurring fit of sickness had forced [Job]137-job to keep a strict look - out , that [this unprincipled old man]412-this unprincipled old man was in the habit of enticing [the boy]3044-the boy to [[his]396-the young man rooms]414-his rooms and there feeding [him]3044-the boy upon unlimited quantities of brandy - balls , and making [him]3044-the boy promise to say nothing about it . [Job]137-job told [him]3044-the boy that [he]3044-the boy ought to be ashamed of [himself]3044-the boy , " at [his]3044-the boy age , too , when [he]3044-the boy might have been [a grandfather]3145-a grandfather if [he]3044-the boy had done what was right , "[3044-the boy] by which [Job]137-job understood had got married , and thence arose the row .

But [I]0-i have no space to dwell upon those delightful years , around which memory still fondly hovers . One by one [they]415-they went by , and as [they]415-they passed [we]416-we two grew dearer and yet more dear to [each other]417-each other . [Few sons]418-few sons have been loved as [I]0-i love [Leo]108-leo , and [few fathers]419-few fathers know the deep and continuous affection that [Leo]108-leo bears to [me]0-i .

[The child]3122-the child grew into [the boy]3044-the boy , and [the boy]3044-the boy into [the young man]396-the young man , while one by one the remorseless years flew by , and as [he]396-the young man grew and increased so did [his]396-the young man beauty and the beauty of [his]396-the young man mind grow with [him]396-the young man . When [he]396-the young man was about fifteen [they]415-they used to call [him]396-the young man [Beauty]117-beauty about [the College]336-the college , and [me]0-i [they]415-they nicknamed [the Beast]425-the beast . [Beauty]117-beauty and the Beast was what [they]415-they called [us]426-us when [we]426-us went out walking together , as [we]426-us used to do every day . Once [Leo]108-leo attacked [[a great strapping butcher]427-a great strapping butcher 's man]428-a great strapping butcher 's man , twice [his]428-a great strapping butcher 's man size , because [he]108-leo sang it out after [us]426-us , and thrashed [him]428-a great strapping butcher 's man , too - thrashed [him]428-a great strapping butcher 's man fairly . [I]0-i walked on and pretended not to see , till the combat got too exciting , when [I]0-i turned round and cheered [him]108-leo on to victory . It was the chaff of [the College]336-the college at the time , but [I]0-i could not help it . Then when [he]108-leo was a little older [the undergraduates]430-the undergraduates found fresh names for [us]426-us . [They]430-the undergraduates called [me]0-i [Charon]107-charon , and [Leo]108-leo [the Greek god]3009-the greek god ! [I]0-i will pass over [my]0-i own appellation with the humble remark that [I]0-i was never handsome , and did not grow more so as [I]0-i grew older . As for [his]108-leo , there was no doubt about its fitness . [Leo]108-leo at twenty - one might have stood for a statue of the youthful [Apollo]105-apollo . [I]0-i never saw [anybody]3032-anybody to touch [him]108-leo in looks , or anybody so absolutely unconscious of [them]433-them . As for [his]108-leo mind , [he]108-leo was brilliant and keen - witted , but not [a scholar]434-a scholar . [He]108-leo had not the dulness necessary for that result . [We]435-we followed out [[his]108-leo father]3053-his father 's instructions as regards [his]108-leo education strictly enough , and on the whole the results , especially in the matters of Greek and Arabic , were satisfactory . [I]0-i learnt the latter language in order to help to teach it to [him]108-leo , but after five years of it [he]108-leo knew it as well as [I]0-i did - almost as well as [the professor who instructed [us]435-we both]437-the professor who instructed us both . [I]0-i always was [a great sportsman]438-a great sportsman - it is [my]0-i one passion - and every autumn [we]435-we went away somewhere shooting or fishing , sometimes to [Scotland]21-scotland , sometimes to [Norway]22-norway , once even to [Russia]23-russia . [I]0-i am a good shot , but even in this [he]108-leo learnt to excel [me]0-i .

When [Leo]108-leo was eighteen [I]0-i moved back into [[my]0-i rooms]363-my rooms , and entered [him]108-leo at [[my]0-i own College]440-my own college , and at twenty - one [he]108-leo took [his]108-leo degree - a respectable degree , but not a very high one . Then it was that [I]0-i , for the first time , told [him]108-leo something of [his]108-leo own story , and of the mystery that loomed ahead . Of course [he]108-leo was very curious about it , and of course [I]0-i explained to [him]108-leo that [his]108-leo curiosity could not be gratified at present . After that , to pass the time away , [I]0-i suggested that [he]108-leo should get [himself]108-leo called to [the Bar]441-the bar ; and this [he]108-leo did , reading at [Cambridge]2-cambridge , and only going up to [London]19-london to eat [his]108-leo dinners .

[I]0-i had only one trouble about [him]108-leo , and that was that [every young woman who came across [him]108-leo]442-every young woman who came across him , or , if not [every one , nearly so]443-every one , nearly so , would insist on falling in love with [him]108-leo . Hence arose difficulties which [I]0-i need not enter into [here]3102-here , though they were troublesome enough at the time . On the whole , [he]108-leo behaved fairly well ; [I]0-i can not say more than that .

And so the time went by till at last [he]108-leo reached [his]108-leo twenty - fifth birthday , at which date this strange and , in some ways , awful history really begins .

III

THE SHERD OF [AMENARTAS]118-kallikrates

On the day preceding [Leo]108-leo 's twenty - fifth birthday [we]445-we both journeyed to [London]19-london , and extracted the mysterious chest from [the bank where [I]0-i had deposited it twenty years before]446-the bank where i had deposited it twenty years before . It was , [I]0-i remember , brought up by [the same clerk who had taken it down]447-the same clerk who had taken it down . [He]108-leo perfectly remembered having hidden it away . Had [he]108-leo not done so , [he]108-leo said , [he]108-leo should have had difficulty in finding it , it was so covered up with cobwebs .

In the evening [we]445-we returned with [our]445-we precious burden to [Cambridge]2-cambridge , and [I]0-i think that [we]445-we might both of [us]445-we have given away all the sleep [we]445-we got that night and not have been much the poorer . At daybreak [Leo]108-leo arrived in [[my]0-i room]448-my room in a dressing - gown , and suggested that [we]445-we should at once proceed to business . [I]0-i scouted the idea as showing an unworthy curiosity . The chest had waited twenty years , [I]0-i said , so it could very well continue to wait until after breakfast . Accordingly at nine - an unusually sharp nine - [we]445-we breakfasted ; and so occupied was [I]0-i with [my]0-i own thoughts that [I]0-i regret to state that [I]0-i put a piece of bacon into [Leo]108-leo 's tea in mistake for a lump of sugar . [Job]137-job , too , to whom the contagion of excitement had , of course , spread , managed to break the handle off [my]0-i Sèvres china tea - cup , the identical one [I]0-i believe that [Marat]138-marat had been drinking from just before [he]138-marat was stabbed in [his]138-marat bath .

At last , however , breakfast was cleared away , and [Job]137-job , at [my]0-i request , fetched the chest , and placed it upon the table in a somewhat gingerly fashion , as though [he]137-job mistrusted it . Then [he]137-job prepared to leave [the room]449-the room .

" Stop a moment , [Job]137-job , "[0-i] [I]0-i said . " If [Mr. Leo]108-leo has no objection , [I]0-i should prefer to have [an independent witness]3146-an independent witness to this business , who can be relied upon to hold [his]108-leo tongue unless [he]108-leo is asked to speak . "[0-i]

" Certainly , [Uncle Horace]139-uncle horace , "[108-leo] answered [Leo]108-leo ; for [I]0-i had brought [him]108-leo up to call [me]0-i [uncle]450-uncle - though [he]108-leo varied the appellation somewhat disrespectfully by calling [me]0-i " [old fellow]3147-old fellow , "[108-leo] or even " [[my]108-leo avuncular relative]3148-my avuncular relative . "[108-leo]

[Job]137-job touched [his]137-job head , not having a hat on .

" Lock the door , [Job]137-job , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " and bring [me]0-i [my]0-i despatch - box . "[0-i]

[He]137-job obeyed , and from the box [I]0-i took the keys that [poor Vincey , [[Leo]108-leo 's father]452-leo 's father]451-poor vincey , leo 's father , had given [me]0-i on the night of [his]451-poor vincey , leo 's father death . There were three of them ; the largest a comparatively modern key , the second an exceedingly ancient one , and the third entirely unlike anything of the sort that [we]453-we had ever seen before , being fashioned apparently from a strip of solid silver , with a bar placed across to serve as a handle , and leaving some nicks cut in the edge of the bar . It was more like a model of an antediluvian railway key than anything else .

" Now are [you]3149-you both ready ? "[0-i] [I]0-i said , as [people]454-people do when [they]454-people are going to fire [a mine]455-a mine . There was no answer , so [I]0-i took the big key , rubbed some salad oil into the wards , and after one or two bad shots , for [my]0-i hands were shaking , managed to fit it , and shoot the lock . [Leo]108-leo bent over and caught the massive lid in both [his]108-leo hands , and with an effort , for the hinges had rusted , forced it back . Its removal revealed another case covered with dust . This [we]453-we extracted from the iron chest without any difficulty , and removed the accumulated filth of years from it with a clothes - brush .

It was , or appeared to be , of ebony , or some such close - grained black wood , and was bound in every direction with flat bands of iron . [Its]456-its antiquity must have been extreme , for the dense heavy wood was in parts actually commencing to crumble from age .

" Now for it , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , inserting the second key .

[Job]137-job and [Leo]108-leo bent forward in breathless silence . The key turned , and [I]0-i flung back the lid , and uttered an exclamation , and no wonder , for inside the ebony case was a magnificent silver casket , about twelve inches square by eight high . It appeared to be of Egyptian workmanship , and the four legs were formed of Sphinxes , and the dome - shaped cover was also surmounted by a Sphinx . The casket was of course much tarnished and dinted with age , but otherwise in fairly sound condition .

[I]0-i drew it out and set it on the table , and then , in the midst of the most perfect silence , [I]0-i inserted the strange - looking silver key , and pressed this way and that until at last the lock yielded , and the casket stood before [us]453-we . It was filled to the brim with some brown shredded material , more like vegetable fibre than paper , the nature of which [I]0-i have never been able to discover . This [I]0-i carefully removed to the depth of some three inches , when [I]0-i came to a letter enclosed in an ordinary modern - looking envelope , and addressed in the handwriting of [[my]0-i dead friend]377-my dead friend [Vincey]108-leo .

" To [[my]0-i son]3150-my son [Leo]108-leo , should [he]108-leo live to open this casket . "[0-i]

[I]0-i handed the letter to [Leo]108-leo , who glanced at the envelope , and then put it down upon the table , making a motion to [me]0-i to go on emptying the casket .

The next thing that [I]0-i found was a parchment carefully rolled up . [I]0-i unrolled it , and seeing that it was also in [Vincey]108-leo 's handwriting , and headed , " Translation of the Uncial Greek Writing on the Potsherd , "[0-i] put it down by the letter . Then followed another ancient roll of parchment , that had become yellow and crinkled with the passage of years . This [I]0-i also unrolled . It was likewise a translation of the same Greek original , but into black - letter Latin , which at the first glance from the style and character appeared to [me]0-i to date from somewhere about the beginning of the sixteenth century . Immediately beneath this roll was something hard and heavy , wrapped up in yellow linen , and reposing upon another layer of the fibrous material . Slowly and carefully [we]453-we unrolled the linen , exposing to view a very large but undoubtedly ancient potsherd of a dirty yellow colour ! This potsherd had in [my]0-i judgment , once been a part of an ordinary amphora of medium size . For the rest , it measured ten and a half inches in length by seven in width , was about a quarter of an inch thick , and densely covered on the convex side that lay towards the bottom of the box with writing in the later uncial Greek character , faded here and there , but for the most part perfectly legible , the inscription having evidently been executed with the greatest care , and by means of a reed pen , such as [the ancients]458-the ancients often used . [I]0-i must not forget to mention that in some remote age this wonderful fragment had been broken in two , and rejoined by means of cement and eight long rivets . Also there were numerous inscriptions on the inner side , but these were of the most erratic character , and had clearly been made by different hands and in many different ages , and of them , together with the writings on the parchments , [I]0-i shall have to speak presently .

plate 1

FACSIMILE OF THE SHERD OF AMENARTAS

One 1 2 size

Greatest length of the original 10 inches Greatest breadth 7 inches Weight 1 lb 5 oz

plate 2

FACSIMILE OF THE SHERD OF [AMENARTAS]118-kallikrates

One 1 2 size

" Is there anything more ? "[108-leo] asked [Leo]108-leo , in a kind of excited whisper .

[I]0-i groped about , and produced something hard , done up in a little linen bag . Out of the bag [we]453-we took first a very beautiful miniature done upon ivory , and secondly , a small chocolate - coloured composition scarabæus , marked thus : -

sketch omitted

symbols which , [we]453-we have since ascertained , mean " Suten se Ra , "[108-leo] which is being translated the " Royal Son of [Ra]140-ra or the Sun . "[108-leo] The miniature was a picture of [[Leo]108-leo 's Greek mother]459-leo 's greek mother - a lovely , dark - eyed creature . On the back of it was written , in poor [Vincey]108-leo 's handwriting , " [[My]108-leo beloved wife]3093-my beloved wife . "[108-leo]

" That is all , "[0-i] [I]0-i said .

" Very well , "[108-leo] answered [Leo]108-leo , putting down the miniature , at which [he]108-leo had been gazing affectionately ; " and now let [us]453-we read the letter , "[108-leo] and without further ado [he]108-leo broke the seal , and read aloud as follows : -

" [[My]108-leo Son]3150-my son [Leo]108-leo , - When [you]108-leo open this , if [you]108-leo ever live to do so , [you]108-leo will have attained to manhood , and [I]108-leo shall have been long enough dead to be absolutely forgotten by [nearly all who knew [me]108-leo]3153-nearly all who knew me . Yet in reading it remember that [I]108-leo have been , and for anything [you]108-leo know may still be , and that in it , through this link of pen and paper , [I]108-leo stretch out [my]108-leo hand to [you]108-leo across [the gulf of death]3154-the gulf of death , and [my]108-leo voice speaks to [you]108-leo from the silence of the grave . Though [I]108-leo am dead , and no memory of [me]108-leo remains in [your]108-leo mind , yet am [I]108-leo with [you]108-leo in this hour that [you]108-leo read . Since [your]108-leo birth to this day [I]108-leo have scarcely seen [your]108-leo face . Forgive [me]108-leo this . [Your]108-leo life supplanted the life of one whom [I]108-leo loved better than [women]327-women are often loved , and the bitterness of it endureth yet . Had [I]108-leo lived [I]108-leo should in time have conquered this foolish feeling , but [I]108-leo am not destined to live . [My]108-leo sufferings , physical and mental , are more than [I]108-leo can bear , and when such small arrangements as [I]108-leo have to make for [your]108-leo future well - being are completed it is [my]108-leo intention to put a period to them . May [God]134-god forgive [me]108-leo if [I]108-leo do wrong . At the best [I]108-leo could not live more than another year . "[108-leo]

" So [he]108-leo killed [himself]108-leo , "[0-i] [I]0-i exclaimed . " [I]0-i thought so . "[0-i]

" And now , "[108-leo] [Leo]108-leo went on , without replying , " enough of [myself]108-leo . What has to be said belongs to [you]108-leo who live , not to [me]108-leo , who am dead , and almost as much forgotten as though [I]108-leo had never been . [Holly]136-horatio , [[my]108-leo friend]266-my friend to whom , if [he]108-leo will accept the trust , it is [my]108-leo intention to confide [you]108-leo , will have told [you]108-leo something of the extraordinary antiquity of [[your]108-leo race]3157-your race . In the contents of this casket [you]108-leo will find sufficient to prove it . The strange legend that [you]108-leo will find inscribed by [[your]108-leo remote ancestress]3158-your remote ancestress upon the potsherd was communicated to [me]108-leo by [[my]108-leo father]3091-my father on [his]3091-my father deathbed , and took a strong hold in [my]108-leo imagination . When [I]108-leo was only nineteen years of age [I]108-leo determined , as , to [his]108-leo misfortune , did one of [[our]3160-our ancestors]3161-our ancestors about the time of [Elizabeth]141-elizabeth , to investigate its truth . Into all that befell [me]108-leo [I]108-leo can not enter now . But this [I]108-leo saw with [my]108-leo own eyes . On [the coast of [Africa]9-africa]3063-the coast of africa , in [a hitherto unexplored region]3163-a hitherto unexplored region , some distance to [the north of where [the Zambesi falls into the sea]3165-the zambesi falls into the sea]3164-the north of where the zambesi falls into the sea , there is [a headland , at the extremity of which a peak towers up]3166-a headland , at the extremity of which a peak towers up , shaped like the head of [a negro , similar to that of which the writing speaks]3167-a negro , similar to that of which the writing speaks . [I]108-leo landed [there]3168-there , and learnt from [a wandering native , who had been cast out by [[his]3169-a wandering native , who had been cast out by his people because of some crime which he had committed people]3170-his people because of some crime which [he]3169-a wandering native , who had been cast out by his people because of some crime which he had committed had committed]3169-a wandering native , who had been cast out by his people because of some crime which he had committed , that far inland are great mountains , shaped like cups , and [caves surrounded by measureless swamps]3171-caves surrounded by measureless swamps . [I]108-leo learnt also that [the people there]3172-the people there speak a dialect of Arabic , and are ruled over by [a beautiful white woman who is seldom seen by [them]3172-the people there , but who is reported to have power over [all things living and dead]3174-all things living and dead]3173-a beautiful white woman who is seldom seen by them , but who is reported to have power over all things living and dead . Two days after [I]108-leo had ascertained this [the man]271-the man died of fever contracted in crossing [the swamps]3176-the swamps , and [I]108-leo was forced by want of provisions and by symptoms of an illness which afterwards prostrated [me]108-leo to take to [my]108-leo dhow again .[108-leo]

" Of the adventures that befell [me]108-leo after this [I]108-leo need not now speak . [I]108-leo was wrecked upon [the coast of [Madagascar]25-madagascar]3177-the coast of madagascar , and rescued some months afterwards by [an English ship]3178-an english ship that brought [me]108-leo to [Aden]26-aden , whence [I]108-leo started for [England]15-england , intending to prosecute [my]108-leo search as soon as [I]108-leo had made sufficient preparations . On [my]108-leo way [I]108-leo stopped in [Greece]18-greece , and there , for ' Omnia vincit amor , ' [I]108-leo met [[your]3179-you beloved mother]3180-your beloved mother , and married [her]3180-your beloved mother , and there [you]3179-you were born and [she]3180-your beloved mother died . Then it was that [my]108-leo last illness seized [me]108-leo , and [I]108-leo returned hither to die . But still [I]108-leo hoped against hope , and set [myself]108-leo to work to learn [Arabic]142-arabic , with the intention , should [I]108-leo ever get better , of returning to [the coast of [Africa]9-africa]3063-the coast of africa , and solving the mystery of which the tradition has lived so many centuries in [[our]3182-our family]3183-our family . But [I]108-leo have not got better , and , so far as [I]108-leo am concerned , the story is at an end .[108-leo]

" For [you]3179-you , however , [[my]108-leo son]3150-my son , it is not at an end , and to [you]3179-you [I]108-leo hand on these the results of [my]108-leo labour , together with the hereditary proofs of its origin . It is [my]108-leo intention to provide that they shall not be put into [your]3179-you hands until [you]3179-you have reached an age when [you]3179-you will be able to judge for [yourself]3179-you whether or no [you]3179-you will choose to investigate what , if it is true , must be the greatest mystery in [the world]252-the world , or to put it by as an idle fable , originating in the first place in [a woman]284-a woman 's disordered brain .[108-leo]

" [I]108-leo do not believe that it is a fable ; [I]108-leo believe that if it can only be re - discovered there is a spot where the vital forces of [the world]252-the world visibly exist . Life exists ; why therefore should not the means of preserving it indefinitely exist also ? But [I]108-leo have no wish to prejudice [your]3179-you mind about the matter . Read and judge for [yourself]3179-you . If [you]3179-you are inclined to undertake the search , [I]108-leo have so provided that [you]3179-you will not lack for means . If , on the other hand , [you]3179-you are satisfied that the whole thing is a chimera , then , [I]108-leo adjure [you]3179-you , destroy the potsherd and the writings , and let a cause of troubling be removed from [our]3188-our race for ever . Perhaps that will be wisest . The unknown is generally taken to be terrible , not as the proverb would infer , from the inherent superstition of [man]3189-man , but because it so often is terrible . [[He]3189-man who would tamper with the vast and secret forces that animate [the world]252-the world]3190-he who would tamper with the vast and secret forces that animate the world may well fall a victim to [them]3190-he who would tamper with the vast and secret forces that animate the world . And if the end were attained , if at last [you]3179-you emerged from the trial ever beautiful and ever young , defying time and evil , and lifted above the natural decay of flesh and intellect , who shall say that the awesome change would prove a happy one ? Choose , [[my]108-leo son]3150-my son , and may [the Power who rules all things]3193-the power who rules all things , and who says ' thus far shalt [thou]3194-thou go , and thus much shalt [thou]3194-thou learn , ' direct the choice to [your]3179-you own happiness and the happiness of [the world]252-the world , which , in the event of [your]3179-you success , [you]3179-you would one day certainly rule by the pure force of accumulated experience . - Farewell ! "[108-leo]

Thus the letter , which was unsigned and undated , abruptly ended .

" What do [you]108-leo make of that , [Uncle Holly]143-uncle holly , "[108-leo] said [Leo]108-leo , with a sort of gasp , as [he]108-leo replaced it on the table . " [We]3196-we have been looking for a mystery , and [we]3196-we certainly seem to have found one . "[108-leo]

" What do [I]0-i make of it ? Why , that [[your]0-i poor dear father]3197-your poor dear father was off [his]3197-your poor dear father head , of course , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered , testily . " [I]0-i guessed as much that night , twenty years ago , when [he]3197-your poor dear father came into [[my]0-i room]448-my room . [You]0-i see [he]3197-your poor dear father evidently hurried [his]3197-your poor dear father own end , [poor man]3199-poor man . It is absolute balderdash . "[0-i]

" That 's it , [sir]3126-sir ! "[137-job] said [Job]137-job , solemnly . [Job]137-job was a most matter - of - fact specimen of a matter - of - fact class .

" Well , let 's see what [the potsherd]3201-the potsherd has to say , at any rate , "[108-leo] said [Leo]108-leo , taking up the translation in [[his]108-leo father]3053-his father 's writing , and commencing to read : -

" [I]108-leo , [Amenartas]118-kallikrates , of [the Royal House of [the Pharaohs of [Egypt]8-egypt]3203-the pharaohs of egypt]3202-the royal house of the pharaohs of egypt , wife of [Kallikrates]118-kallikrates [the Beautiful in Strength]3204-the beautiful in strength , [a Priest of Isis whom [the gods cherish and the demons]3206-the gods cherish and the demons obey , being about to die , to [[my]108-leo little son]3207-my little son Tisisthenes [the Mighty Avenger]3077-the mighty avenger]3205-a priest of isis whom the gods cherish and the demons obey , being about to die , to my little son tisisthenes the mighty avenger . [I]108-leo fled with [[thy]3207-my little son father]3209-thy father from [Egypt]8-egypt in the days of [Nectanebes]144-nectanebes , causing [him]3209-thy father through love to break the vows that [he]3209-thy father had vowed . [We]3210-us fled southward , across [the waters]3211-the waters , and [we]3210-us wandered for twice twelve moons on [the coast of [Libya Africa]27-libya africa]3212-the coast of libya africa that looks towards the rising sun , where by [a river]3213-a river is [a great rock carven like the head of [an Ethiopian]3215-an ethiopian]3214-a great rock carven like the head of an ethiopian . Four days on the water from [the mouth of [a mighty river]3217-a mighty river]3216-the mouth of a mighty river were [we]3210-us cast away , and [some]3218-some were drowned and [some]3218-some died of sickness . But [[us]3210-us [wild men]3221-wild men]3220-us wild men took through wastes and [marshes]3222-marshes , where [the sea fowl]3223-the sea fowl hid the sky , bearing [us]3210-us ten days ' journey till [we]3210-us came to [a hollow mountain , where [a great city]3225-a great city had been and fallen , and where there are caves of which [no man hath seen the end]3226-no man hath seen the end]3224-a hollow mountain , where a great city had been and fallen , and where there are caves of which no man hath seen the end ; and [they]3221-wild men brought [us]3210-us to [the Queen of [the people who place pots upon the heads of [strangers]3229-strangers]3228-the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is [a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die]3230-a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . And [she]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father cast eyes of love upon [[thy]3231-thy father]3209-thy father]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father , [Kallikrates]118-kallikrates , and would have slain [me]108-leo , and taken [him]118-kallikrates to [husband]3233-husband , but [he]118-kallikrates loved [me]108-leo and feared [her]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father , and would not . Then did [she]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father take [us]3210-us , and lead [us]3210-us by terrible ways , by means of dark magic , to where [the great pit]3234-the great pit is , in the mouth of which [the old philosopher]3235-the old philosopher lay dead , and showed to [us]3210-us the rolling Pillar of Life that dies not , whereof the voice is as the voice of thunder ; and [she]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father did stand in the flames , and come forth unharmed , and yet more beautiful . Then did [she]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father swear to make [[thy]3231-thy father]3209-thy father undying even as [she]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father is , if [he]118-kallikrates would but slay [me]108-leo , and give [himself]118-kallikrates to [her]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father , for [me]108-leo [she]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father could not slay because of the magic of [[my]108-leo own people]3237-my own people that [I]108-leo have , and that prevailed thus far against [her]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father . And [he]118-kallikrates held [his]118-kallikrates hand before [his]118-kallikrates eyes to hide [her]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father beauty , and would not . Then in [her]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father rage did [she]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father smite [him]118-kallikrates by [her]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father magic , and [he]118-kallikrates died ; but [she]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father wept over [him]118-kallikrates , and bore [him]118-kallikrates thence with lamentations : and being afraid , [me]108-leo [she]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father sent to [the mouth of [the great river]3239-the great river where [the ships]3240-the ships come]3238-the mouth of the great river where the ships come , and [I]108-leo was carried far away on [the ships where [I]108-leo gave [thee]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father birth , and hither to [Athens]11-athens [I]108-leo came at last after many wanderings]3241-the ships where i gave thee birth , and hither to athens i came at last after many wanderings . Now [I]108-leo say to [thee]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father , [[my]108-leo son]3150-my son , [Tisisthenes]122-tisisthenes , seek out [the woman]3243-the woman , and learn the secret of Life , and if [thou]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father mayest find a way slay [her]3243-the woman , because of [[thy]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father father]3209-thy father [Kallikrates]118-kallikrates ; and if [thou]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father dost fear or fail , this [I]108-leo say to [all [thy]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father seed who come after [thee]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father , till at last [a brave man]3246-a brave man be found among [them]3227-the queen of the people who place pots upon the heads of strangers , who is a magician having a knowledge of all things , and life and loveliness that does not die . and she cast eyes of love upon thy father who shall bathe in the fire and sit in [the place of [the Pharaohs]3059-the pharaohs]3247-the place of the pharaohs]3245-all thy seed who come after thee , till at last a brave man be found among them who shall bathe in the fire and sit in the place of the pharaohs . [I]108-leo speak of those things , that though they be past belief , yet [I]108-leo have known , and [I]108-leo lie not . "[108-leo]

Nekht - nebf , or [Nectanebo II]145-nectanebo ii . , [the last native Pharaoh of [Egypt]8-egypt]461-the last native pharaoh of egypt , fled from [Ochus]28-ochus to [Ethiopia]29-ethiopia , B.C. 339 . - Editor .

" May [the Lord]3249-the lord forgive [her]365-my poor friend for that , "[137-job] groaned [Job]137-job , who had been listening to this marvellous composition with [his]137-job mouth open .

As for [myself]0-i , [I]0-i said nothing : [my]0-i first idea being that [[my]0-i poor friend]365-my poor friend , being demented , had composed the whole thing , though it scarcely seemed likely that such a story could have been invented by [anybody]3032-anybody . It was too original . To solve [my]0-i doubts [I]0-i took up the potsherd and began to read the close uncial Greek writing on it ; and very good Greek of the period it is , considering that it came from the pen of [an Egyptian born]464-an egyptian born . Here is an exact transcript of it : -
