ΑΜΕΝΑΡΤΑΣΤΟΥΒΑΣΙΛΙΚΟΥΓΕΝΟΥΣΤΟΥΑΙΓΥΠΤΙΟΥΗΤΟΥΚΑΛΛΙΚΡΑΤΟΥΣΙΣΙΔΟΣΙΕΡΕΩΣΗΝΟ ΙΜΕΝéΕΟΙΤΡΕΦΟΥΣΙΤΑΔΕΔΑΙΜΟΝΙΑΥΠΟΤΑΣΣΕΤΑΙΗΔΗΤΕΛΕΥΤΩΣΑΤΙΣΙΣéΕΝΕΙΤΩΠΑΙΔΙΕΠ ΙΣΤΕΛΛΕΙΤΑΔΕΣΥΝΕΦΥΓΟΝΓΑΡΠΟΤΕΕΚΤΗΣΑΙΓΥΠΤΙΑΣΕΠΙΝΕΚΤΑΝΕΒΟΥΜΕΤΑΤΟΥΣΟΥΠΑΤΡΟ ΣΔΙΑΤΟΝΕΡΩΤΑΤΟΝΕΜΟΝΕΠΙΟΡΚΗΣΑΝΤΟΣΦΥΓΟΝΤΕΣΔΕΠΡΟΣΝΟΤΟΝΔΙΑΠΟΝΤΙΟΙΚΑΙΚΔΜΗΝΑ ΣΚΑΤΑΤΑΠΑΡΑéΑΛΑΣΣΙΑΤΗΣΛΙΒΥΗΣΤΑΠΡΟΣΗΛΙΟΥΑΝΑΤΟΛΑΣΠΛΑΝΗéΕΝΤΕΣΕΝéΑΠΕΡΠΕΤΡΑ ΤΙΣΜΕΓΑΛΗΓΛΥΠΤΟΝΟΜΟΙΩΜΑΑΙéΙΟΠΟΣΚΕΦΑΛΗΣΕΙΤΑΗΜΕΡΑΣΔΑΠΟΣΤΟΜΑΤΟΣΠΟΤΑΜΟΥΜΕΓ ΑΛΟΥΕΚΠΕΣΟΝΤΕΣΟΙΜΕΝΚΑΤΕΠΟΝΤΙΣéΗΜΕΝΟΙΔΕΝΟΣΩΙΑΠΕéΑΝΟΜΕΝΤΕΛΟΣΔΕΥΠΑΓΡΙΩΝΑΝ éΡΩΠΩΝΕΦΕΡΟΜΕéΑΔΙΑΕΛΕΩΝΤΕΚΑΙΤΕΝΑΓΕΩΝΕΝéΑΠΕΡΠΤΗΝΩΝΠΛΗéΟΣΑΠΟΚΡΥΠΤΕΙΤΟΝΟΥ ΡΑΝΟΝΗΜΕΡΑΣΙΕΩΣΗΛéΟΜΕΝΕΙΣΚΟΙΛΟΝΤΙΟΡΟΣΕΝéΑΠΟΤΕΜΕΓΑΛΗΜΕΝΠΟΛΙΣΗΝΑΝΤΡΑΔΕΑΠ ΕΙΡΟΝΑΗΓΑΓΟΝΔΕΩΣΒΑΣΙΛΕΙΑΝΤΗΝΤΩΝΞΕΝΟΥΣΧΥΤΡΑΙΣΣΤΕΦΑΝΟΥΝΤΩΝΗΤΙΣΜΑΓΕΙΑΜΕΝΕ ΧΡΗΤΟΕΠΙΣΤΗΜΗΔΕΠΑΝΤΩΝΚΑΙΔΗΚΑΙΚΑΛΛΟΣΚΑΙΡΩΜΗΝΑΓΗΡΩΣΗΝΗΔΕΚΑΛΛΙΚΡΑΤΟΥΣΤΟΥΣ ΟΥΠΑΤΡΟΣΕΡΑΣéΕΙΣΑΤΟΜΕΝΠΡΩΤΟΝΣΥΝΟΙΚΕΙΝΕΒΟΥΛΕΤΟΕΜΕΔΕΑΝΕΛΕΙΝΕΠΕΙΤΑΩΣΟΥΚΑΝ ΕΠΕΙéΕΝΕΜΕΓΑΡΥΠΕΡΕΦΙΛΕΙΚΑΙΤΗΝΞΕΝΗΝΕΦΟΒΕΙΤΟΑΠΗΓΑΓΕΝΗΜΑΣΥΠΟΜΑΓΕΙΑΣΚΑéΟΔΟ ΥΣΣΦΑΛΕΡΑΣΕΝéΑΤΟΒΑΡΑéΡΟΝΤΟΜΕΓΑΟΥΚΑΤΑΣΤΟΜΑΕΚΕΙΤΟΟΓΕΡΩΝΟΦΙΛΟΣΟΦΟΣΤΕéΝΕΩΣ ΑΦΙΚΟΜΕΝΟΙΣΔΕΔΕΙΞΕΦΩΣΤΟΥΒΙΟΥΕΥéΥΟΙΟΝΚΙΟΝΑΕΛΙΣΣΟΜΕΝΟΝΦΩΝΗΝΙΕΝΤΑΚΑéΑΠΕΡΒ ΡΟΝΤΗΣΕΙΤΑΔΙΑΠΥΡΟΣΒΕΒΗΚΥΙΑΑΒΛΑΒΗΣΚΑΙΕΤΙΚΑΛΛΙΩΝΑΥΤΗΕΑΥΤΗΣΕΞΕΦΑΝΗΕΚΔΕΤΟΥ ΤΩΝΩΜΟΣΕΚΑΙΤΟΝΣΟΝΠΑΤΕΡΑΑéΑΝΑΤΟΝΑΠΟΔΕΙΞΕΙΝΕΙΣΥΝΟΙΚΕΙΝΟΙΒΟΥΛΟΙΤΟΕΜΕΔΕΑΝΕ ΛΕΙΝΟΥΓΑΡΟΥΝΑΥΤΗΑΝΕΛΕΙΝΙΣΧΥΕΝΥΠΟΤΩΝΗΜΕΔΑΠΩΝΗΝΚΑΙΑΥΤΗΕΧΩΜΑΓΕΙΑΣΟΔΟΥΔΕΝΤ ΙΜΑΛΛΟΝΗéΕΛΕΤΩΧΕΙΡΕΤΩΝΟΜΜΑΤΩΝΠΡΟΙΣΧΩΝΙΝΑΔΗΤΟΤΗΣΓΥΝΑΙΚΟΣΚΑΛΛΟΣΜΗΟΡΩΗΕΠΕ ΙΤΑΟΡΓΙΣéΕΙΣΑΚΑΤΕΓΟΗΤΕΥΣΕΜΕΝΑΥΤΟΝΑΠΟΛΟΜΕΝΟΝΜΕΝΤΟΙΚΛΑΟΥΣΑΚΑΙΟΔΥΡΟΜΕΝΗΕΚ ΕΙéΕΝΑΠΗΝΕΓΚΕΝΕΜΕΔΕΦΟΒΩΙΑΦΗΚΕΝΕΙΣΣΤΟΜΑΤΟΥΜΕΓΑΛΟΥΠΟΤΑΜΟΥΤΟΥΝΑΥΣΙΠΟΡΟΥΠΟ ΡΡΩΔΕΝΑΥΣΙΝΕΦΩΝΠΕΡΠΛΕΟΥΣΑΕΤΕΚΟΝΣΕΑΠΟΠΛΕΥΣΑΣΑΜΟΛΙΣΠΟΤΕΔΕΥΡΟΑéΗΝΑΖΕΚΑΤΗΓ ΑΓΟΜΗΝΣΥΔΕΩΤΙΣΙΣéΕΝΕΣΩΝΕΠΙΣΤΕΛΛΩΜΗΟΛΙΓΩΡΕΙΔΕΙΓΑΡΤΗΝΓΥΝΑΙΚΑΑΝΑΖΗΤΕΙΝΗΝΠ ΩΣΤΟΤΟΥΒΙΟΥΜΥΣΤΗΡΙΟΝΑΝΕΥΡΗΣΚΑΙΑΝΑΙΡΕΙΝΗΝΠΟΥΠΑΡΑΣΧΗΔΙΑΤΟΝΣΟΝΠΑΤΕΡΑΚΑΛΛΙ ΚΡΑΤΗΝΕΙΔΕΦΟΒΟΥΜΕΝΟΣΗΔΙΑΑΛΛΟΤΙΑΥΤΟΣΛΕΙΠΕΙΤΟΥΕΡΓΟΥΠΑΣΙΤΟΙΣΥΣΤΕΡΟΝΑΥΤΟΤΟ ΥΤΟΕΠΙΣΤΕΛΛΩΕΩΣΠΟΤΕΑΓΑéΟΣΤΙΣΓΕΝΟΜΕΝΟΣΤΩΠΥΡΙΛΟΥΣΑΣéΑΙΤΟΛΜΗΣΕΙΚΑΙΤΑΑΡΙΣΤ ΕΙΑΕΧΩΝΒΑΣΙΛΕΥΣΑΙΤΩΝΑΝéΡΩΠΩΝΑΠΙΣΤΑΜΕΝΔΗΤΑΤΟΙΑΥΤΑΛΕΓΩΟΜΩΣΔΕΑΑΥΤΗΕΓΝΩΚΑΟ ΥΚΕΨΕΥΣΑΜΗΝ

The general convenience in reading , [I]0-i have here accurately transcribed this inscription into the cursive character .

Ἀμενάρτας , τοῦ βασικοῦ γένους τοῦ Αἰγυπτίου , ἡ τοῦ Καλλικράτους Ἴσιδος ἱερέως , ἣν οἱ μὲν éεοὶ τρέφουσι τὰ δὲ δαιμονια ὑποτάσσεται , ἤδη τελευτῶσα Τισισéένει τῷ παιδὶ ἐπιστέλλει τάδε συνέφυγον γάρ ποτε ἐκ τῆς Αἰγυπτίας ἐπὶ Νεκτανέβου μετὰ τοῦ σοῦ πατρός , διὰ τὸν ἔρωτα τὸν ἐμὸν ἐπιορκήσαντος . φυγόντες δὲ πρὸς νότον διαπόντιοι καὶ κ δ μῆνας κατὰ τὰ παραéαλάσσια τῆς Αιβύης τὰ πρός ἡλίου ἀνατολὰς πλανηéέντες , ἔνéαπερ πέτρα τις μελάλη , γλυπτὸν ὁμοίωμα Αἰéίοπος κεφαλῆς , εἶτα ἡμέρας δ ἀπὸ στόματος ποταμοῦ μεγάλου ἐκπεσόντες , οἱ μέν κατεποντίσéημεν , οἱ δὲ νόσῳ ἀπεéάνομεν τέλος δὲ ὑπ ἀλρίων ἀνéρώπων ἐφερόμεéα διὰ ἐλέων τε καὶ τεναλέων ἔνéαπερ πτηνῶν πλῆéος ἀποκρύπτει τὸν οὐρανὸν , ἡμέρας ί , ἕως ἤλéομεν εἰς κοῖλόν τι ὄρος , ἔνéα ποτὲ μεγάλη μὲν πόλις ἦν , ἄντρα δὲ ἀπείρονα ἤγαγον δὲ ὡς βασίλειαν τὴν τῶν ξένους χύτραις στεφανούντων , ἥτις μαλεία μὲν ἐχρῆτο ἐπιστήμη δὲ πάντων καὶ δὴ καὶ κάλλός καὶ ῥώμην ἀλήρως ἦν ἡ δὲ Καλλικράτους τοῦ πατρὸς ἐρασéεῖδα τὸ μὲν πρῶτον συνοικεῖν ἐβούλετο ἐμὲ δὲ ἀνελεῖν ἔπειτα , ὡς οὐκ ἀνέπειéεν , ἐμὲ γὰρ ὑπερεφίλει καὶ τὴν ξένην ἐφοβεῖτο , ἀπήγαγεν ἡμᾶς ὑπὸ μαγείας καé ὁδοὺς σφαλερὰς ἔνéα τὸ βάραéρον τὸ μέγα , οὗ κατὰ στόμα ἔκειτο ὁ γέρων ὁ φιλόσοφος τεéνεώς , ἀφικομένοις δ ἔδειξε φῶς τοῦ βίου εὐéύ , οἷον κίονα ἑλισσόμενον φώνην ἱέντα καéάπερ βροντῆς , εἶτα διὰ πυρὸς βεβηκυῖα ἀβλαβὴς καὶ ἔτι καλλίων αὐτὴ ἑαυτῆς ἐξεφάνη . ἐκ δὲ τούτων ὤμοσε καὶ τὸν σὸν πατέρα ἀéάνατον ἀποδείξειν , εἰ συνοικεῖν οἱ βούλοιτο ἐμὲ δε ὰνελεῖν , οὐ γὰρ οὖν αὐτὴ ἀνελεῖν ἴσχυεν ὑπὸ τῶν ἡμεδαπῶν ἣν καὶ αὐτὴ ἔχω μαγείας . ὁ δ οὐδέν τι μᾶλλον ἤéελε , τὼ χεῖρε τῶν ὀμμάτων προίσχων ἵνα δὴ τὸ τῆς γυναικὸς κάλλος μὴ ὁρῴη ἔπειτα ὀργισéεῖσα κατεγοήτευσε μὲν αὐτόν , ἀπολόμενον μέντοι κλάουσα καὶ ὀδυρμένη ἐκεῖéεν ἀπήνεγκεν , ἐμὲ δὲ φόβῳ ἀφῆκεν εἰς στόμα τοῦ μεγάλου ποταμοῦ τοῦ ναυσιπόρου , πόδδω δὲ ναυσίν , ἐφ ὧνπερ πλέουσα ἔτεκόν σε , ἀποπλεύσασα μόλις ποτὲ δεῦρο Ἀéηνάζε κατηγαγόν . σὺ δέ , ὦ Τισίσéενες , ὧν ἐπιστέλλω μὴ ὀλιγώρει δεῖ γὰρ τῆν γυναῖκα ἀναζητεῖν ἤν πως τῦ βίου μυστήριον ἀνεύρῃς , καὶ ἀναιρεῖν , ἤν που παρασχῇ , διὰ τὸν πατέρα Καλλικράτους . εἐ δὲ φοβούμενος ἢ διὰ ἄλλο τι αὐτὸς λείπει τοῦ ἔργου , πᾶσι τοῖς ὕστερον αὐτὸ τοῦτο ἐπιστέλλω , ἕως ποτὲ ἀγαéός τις γενόμενος τῷ πυρὶ λούσασéαι τολμήσει καὶ τὰ ἀριστεῖα ἔχων βασιλεῦσαι τῶν ἀνéρώπων ἄπιστα μὲν δὴ τὰ τοιαῦτα λέγω , ὅμως δὲ ἃ αὐτὴ ἔγνωκα οὐκ ἐψευσάμην .

The English translation was , as [I]0-i discovered on further investigation , and as [the reader]298-the reader may easily see by comparison , both accurate and elegant .

Besides the uncial writing on the convex side of the sherd at the top , painted in dull red , on what had once been the lip of the amphora , was the cartouche already mentioned as being on the scarabæus , which [we]466-we had also found in the casket . The hieroglyphics or symbols , however , were reversed , just as though they had been pressed on wax . Whether this was the cartouche of [the original Kallikrates]467-the original kallikrates , or of [some Prince]468-some prince or Pharaoh from whom [[his]468-some prince wife]3066-his wife [Amenartas]118-kallikrates was descended , [I]0-i am not sure , nor can [I]0-i tell if it was drawn upon the sherd at the same time that the uncial Greek was inscribed , or copied on more recently from the Scarab by [some other member of the family]470-some other member of the family . Nor was this all . At the foot of the writing , painted in the same dull red , was the faint outline of a somewhat rude drawing of the head and shoulders of [a Sphinx wearing two feathers , symbols of majesty , which , though common enough upon the effigies of sacred bulls and gods]471-a sphinx wearing two feathers , symbols of majesty , which , though common enough upon the effigies of sacred bulls and gods , [I]0-i have never before met with on a Sphinx .

The cartouche , if it be a true cartouche , can not have been that of [Kallikrates]118-kallikrates , as [Mr. Holly]109-holly suggests . [Kallikrates]118-kallikrates was [a priest]472-a priest and not entitled to a cartouche , which was the prerogative of [Egyptian royalty]473-egyptian royalty , though [he]118-kallikrates might have inscribed [his]118-kallikrates name or title upon an oval . - Editor .

Also on the right - hand side of this surface of the sherd , painted obliquely in red on the space not covered by the uncial characters , and signed in blue paint , was the following quaint inscription : -

IN EARTH AND SKIE AND [SEA]1-sea

STRANGE THYNGES THER BE .

HOC FECIT

DOROTHEA VINCEY .

Perfectly bewildered , [I]0-i turned the relic over . It was covered from top to bottom with notes and signatures in Greek , Latin , and English . The first in uncial Greek was by [Tisisthenes]122-tisisthenes , [the son to whom the writing]474-the son to whom the writing was addressed . It was , " [I]122-tisisthenes could not go . [Tisisthenes]122-tisisthenes to [[his]474-the son to whom the writing son]3250-his son , [Kallikrates]118-kallikrates . "[122-tisisthenes] Here it is in fac - simile with its cursive equivalent : -

ΟΥΚΑΝΔΥΝΑΙΜΗΝΠΟΡΕΥΕϹéΑΙΤΙϹΙϹéΕΝΗϹΚΑΛΛΙΚΡΑΤΕΙΤΩΙΠΑΙΔΙ

οὐκ ἂν δυναίμην πορεύεσéαι . Τισισéένης Καλλικράτει τῷ παιδί.

This [Kallikrates]118-kallikrates probably , in the Greek fashion , so named after [[his]474-the son to whom the writing grandfather]3057-his grandfather evidently made some attempt to start on the quest , for [his]3057-his grandfather entry written in very faint and almost illegible uncial is , " [I]3057-his grandfather ceased from [my]3057-his grandfather going , [the gods]3251-the gods being against [me]3057-his grandfather . [Kallikrates]118-kallikrates to [[his]3057-his grandfather son]3250-his son . "[3057-his grandfather] Here it is also : -

ΤΩΝéΕΩΝΑΝΤΙΣΤΑΝΤΩΝΕΠΑΥΣΑΜΗΝΤΗΣΠΟΡΕΙΑΣΑΛΛΙΚΡΑΤΗΣΤΩΙΠΑΙΔΙ

τῶν éεῶν ἀντιστάντων ἐπαυσάμην τῆς πορείας . Καλλικράτης τῷ παιδί.

Between these two ancient writings , the second of which was inscribed upside down and was so faint and worn that , had it not been for the transcript of it executed by [Vincey]108-leo , [I]0-i should scarcely have been able to read it , since , owing to its having been written on that portion of the tile which had , in the course of ages , undergone the most handling , it was nearly rubbed out - was the bold , modern - looking signature of one [Lionel Vincey]108-leo , " Ætate sua 17 , "[108-leo] which was written thereon , [I]0-i think , by [[Leo]108-leo 's grandfather]476-leo 's grandfather . To the right of this were the initials " J. B. V. , "[0-i] and below came a variety of Greek signatures , in uncial and cursive character , and what appeared to be some carelessly executed repetitions of the sentence τῷ παιδί to [[my]0-i son]3150-my son , showing that the relic was religiously passed on from generation to generation .

The next legible thing after the Greek signatures was the word " Romae , A.U.C. , "[3078-the family] showing that [the family]3078-the family had now migrated to [Rome]12-rome . Unfortunately , however , with the exception of [its]479-its termination evi the date of [their]3078-the family settlement there is for ever lost , for just where it had been placed a piece of the potsherd is broken away .

Then followed twelve Latin signatures , jotted about here and there , wherever there was a space upon the tile suitable to [their]3078-the family inscription . These signatures , with three exceptions only , ended with the name " Vindex "[481-an avenger] or " [the Avenger]3253-the avenger , "[481-an avenger] which seems to have been adopted by [the family]3078-the family after [its]3078-the family migration to [Rome]12-rome as a kind of equivalent to the Greek " Tisisthenes , "[481-an avenger] which also means [an avenger]481-an avenger . Ultimately , as might be expected , [this Latin cognomen of Vindex]482-this latin cognomen of vindex was transformed first into De Vincey , and then into [the plain , modern Vincey]483-the plain , modern vincey . It is very curious to observe how the idea of revenge , inspired by [an Egyptian who lived before the time of Christ]484-an egyptian who lived before the time of christ , is thus , as it were , embalmed in an English family name .

A few of the Roman names inscribed upon the sherd [I]0-i have actually since found mentioned in history and other records . They were , if [I]0-i remember right ,

[MVSSIVS]146-mvssivs . [VINDEX

SEX]30-vindex sex . [VARIVS MARVLLVS]31-varivs marvllvs

C. FVFIDIVS . C. F. VINDEX

and

[LABERIA POMPEIANA]32-laberia pompeiana . CONIVX . [MACRINI]33-macrini . VINDICIS

this last being , of course , the name of [a Roman lady]485-a roman lady .

The following list , however , comprises all the Latin names upon [the sherd]486-the sherd : -

C. CAECILIVS VINDEX M. AIMILIVS VINDEX SEX . VARIVS . MARVLLVS Q. [SOSIVS PRISCVS SENECIO VINDEX L. VALERIVS COMINIVS VINDEX SEX]487-sosivs priscvs senecio vindex l. valerivs cominivs vindex sex . [OTACILIVS]147-otacilivs . M. F. L. ATTIVS . [VINDEX MVSSIVS VINDEX]34-vindex mvssivs vindex C. FVFIDIVS . C. F. VINDEX LICINIVS FAVSTVS [LABERIA POMPEIANA CONIVX MACRINI VINDICIS MANILIA LVCILLA CONIVX MARVLLI VINDICIS]35-laberia pompeiana conivx macrini vindicis manilia lvcilla conivx marvlli vindicis

After the Roman names there is evidently a gap of very many centuries . [Nobody]488-nobody will ever know now what was the history of the relic during those dark ages , or how it came to have been preserved in [the family]3078-the family . [[My]0-i poor friend]365-my poor friend [Vincey]108-leo had , it will be remembered , told [me]0-i that [[his]108-leo Roman ancestors]491-his roman ancestors finally settled in [Lombardy]13-lombardy , and when [Charlemagne]124-charlemagne invaded [it]13-lombardy , returned with [him]124-charlemagne across [the Alps]36-the alps , and made [their]491-his roman ancestors home in [Brittany]14-brittany , whence [they]491-his roman ancestors crossed to [England]15-england in the reign of [Edward the Confessor]125-edward the confessor . How [he]108-leo knew this [I]0-i am not aware , for there is no reference to [Lombardy]13-lombardy or [Charlemagne]124-charlemagne upon the tile , though , as will presently be seen , there is a reference to [Brittany]14-brittany . To continue : the next entries on the sherd , if [I]0-i may except a long splash either of blood or red colouring matter of some sort , consist of two crosses drawn in red pigment , and probably representing [Crusaders]148-crusaders ' swords , and a rather neat monogram " D. V. "[149-dorothea vincey] in scarlet and blue , perhaps executed by that same [Dorothea Vincey]149-dorothea vincey who wrote , or rather painted , the doggrel couplet . To the left of this , inscribed in faint blue , were the initials A. V. , and after them a date , 1800 .

Then came what was perhaps as curious an entry as anything upon this extraordinary relic of the past . It is executed in black letter , written over the crosses or Crusaders ' swords , and dated fourteen hundred and forty - five . As the best plan will be to allow it to speak for itself , [I]0-i here give the black - letter fac - simile , together with the original Latin without the contractions , from which it will be seen that [the writer]296-the writer was [a fair mediæval Latinist]493-a fair mediæval latinist . Also [we]494-we discovered what is still more curious , an English version of the black - letter Latin . This , also written in black letter , [we]494-we found inscribed on a second parchment that was in the coffer , apparently somewhat older in date than that on which was inscribed the mediæval Latin translation of the uncial Greek of which [I]0-i shall speak presently . This [I]0-i also give in full .

Fac - simile of Black - Letter Inscription on [the Sherd of [Amenartas]118-kallikrates]495-the sherd of amenartas .

" Iſta reliq ia eſt valde miſticu et myrificu op s q d maiores mei ex Armorica ſſ [Brittania]37-brittania mi ore ſecu co veheba t et q dm ſc [s cleric]3254-s cleric s ſe per p ri meo in manu ferebat q d pe itus illvd deſtrueret , affirma s q d eſſet ab ipſo ſathana co flatu preſtigioſa et dyabolica arte q re p ter [mevs]3255-mevs co fregit illvd [i]0-i dvas p tes q s q dm ego Johs de Vi ceto ſalvas ſervavi et adaptavi ſicut ap paret die lu e p r poſt feſt beate Mrie vir g anni gr e mccccxlv . "[0-i]

Expanded Version of the above Black - Letter Inscription .

" Ista reliquia est valde misticum et myrificum opus , quod majores mei ex Armorica , scilicet Britannia Minore , secum convehebant ; et et quidam sanctus clericus semper patri meo in manu ferebat quod penitus illud destrueret , affirmans quod esset ab ipso Sathana conflatum prestigiosa et dyabolica arte , quare pater meus confregit illud in duas partes , quas quidem ego Johannes de Vinceto salvas servavi et adaptavi sicut apparet die lune proximo post festum beate Marie Virginis anni gratie MCCCCXLV . "[0-i]

Fac - simile of the Old English Black - Letter Translation of the above Latin Inscription from the Sherd of [Amenartas]118-kallikrates found inscribed upon a parchment .

" Thys rellike ys a ryghte mistycall worke a marvaylous yᵉ whyche myne aunceteres afore tyme dyd conveigh hider wᵗ yᵐ ffrom Armoryke whᵉ ys to ſeien Britaine yᵉ leſſe a certayne holye clerke ſhoulde allweyes beare [my]0-i ffadir on honde yᵗ [he]296-the writer owghte uttirly ffor to ffruſſhe yᵉ ſame affyrmynge yᵗ yt was ffourmyd confflatyd off ſathanas hym ſelffe by arte magike dyvellyſſhe wherefore [my]0-i ffadir dyd take [yᵉ]3256-yᵉ ſame to braſt yt yn tweyne but [I]0-i [John de Vincey]106-vincey dyd ſave whool yᵉ tweye p tes therof topeecyd yᵐ togydder agayne ſoe as [yee]3257-ye ſe on y s daye mondaye next ffolowynge after yᵉ ffeeste of ſeynte Marye yᵉ bleſſed vyrgyne yn yᵉ [yeere of ſalvacioun ffowertene hundreth ffyve ffowrti]3258-yeere of ſalvacioun ffowertene hundreth ffyve ffowrti . "[0-i]

Modernised Version of the above Black - Letter Translation .

" Thys rellike ys a ryghte mistycall worke and a marvaylous , [ye]3257-ye whyche myne aunceteres aforetyme dyd conveigh hider with [them]3259-them from Armoryke which ys to seien Britaine [ye]3257-ye Lesse and a certayne holye clerke should allweyes beare [my]0-i fadir on honde that [he]296-the writer owghte uttirly for to frusshe [ye]3257-ye same , affyrmynge that yt was fourmed and conflatyed of Sathanas hym selfe by arte magike and dyvellysshe wherefore [my]0-i fadir dyd take [ye]3257-ye same and tobrast yt yn tweyne , but [I]0-i , [John de Vincey]106-vincey , dyd save whool [ye]3257-ye tweye partes therof and topeecyd [them]3259-them togydder agayne soe as [yee]3257-ye se , on this daye mondaye next followynge after [ye]3257-ye feeste of Seynte Marye [ye]3257-ye Blessed Vyrgyne yn [ye]3257-ye yeere of [Salvacioun fowertene hundreth]150-salvacioun fowertene hundreth and fyve and fowerti . "[0-i]

The next and , save one , last entry was Elizabethan , and dated 1564 . " A most strange historie , and one that did cost [[my]0-i father]3091-my father [his]3091-my father life ; for in seekynge for [the place upon [the east coast of [Africa]9-africa]3262-the east coast of africa]3261-the place upon the east coast of africa , [his]3091-my father pinnance was sunk by [a Portuguese galleon]3263-a portuguese galleon off [Lorenzo Marquez]39-lorenzo marquez , and [he]3091-my father [himself]3091-my father perished . - [John Vincey]106-vincey . "[0-i]

Then came the last entry , apparently , to judge by the style of writing , made by [some representative of [the family]3078-the family]496-some representative of the family in the middle of the eighteenth century . It was a misquotation of the well - known lines in [Hamlet]151-hamlet , and ran thus : " There are more things in [Heaven and earth]3264-heaven and earth than are dreamt of in [your]136-horatio philosophy , [Horatio]136-horatio . "[151-hamlet]

Another thing that makes [me]0-i fix the date of this entry at the middle of the eighteenth century is that , curiously enough , [I]0-i have an acting copy of " Hamlet , "[151-hamlet] written about 1740 , in which these two lines are misquoted almost exactly in the same way , and [I]0-i have little doubt but that [the Vincey who wrote them on the potsherd]498-the vincey who wrote them on the potsherd heard them so misquoted at that date . Of course , the lines really run : -

There are more things in [heaven and earth]3264-heaven and earth , [Horatio]136-horatio , Than are dreamt of in [your]136-horatio philosophy . - L. H. H.

And now there remained but one more document to be examined - namely , the ancient black - letter transcription into mediæval Latin of the uncial inscription on the sherd . As will be seen , this translation was executed and subscribed in the year 1495 , by [a certain " learned man]3265-a certain " learned man , "[3265-a certain " learned man] [Edmundus de Prato Edmund Pratt]152-edmundus de prato edmund pratt by name , licentiate in Canon Law , of Exeter College , [Oxford]40-oxford , who had actually been [a pupil of [Grocyn]153-grocyn]500-a pupil of grocyn , [the first scholar who taught Greek in [England]15-england]501-the first scholar who taught greek in england . No doubt , on the fame of this new learning reaching [his]153-grocyn ears , [the Vincey of the day]502-the vincey of the day , perhaps that same [John de Vincey]106-vincey [who years before had saved the relic from destruction and made the black - letter entry on the sherd]503-who years before had saved the relic from destruction and made the black - letter entry on the sherd in 1445 , hurried off to [Oxford]40-oxford to see if perchance it might avail to dissolve the secret of the mysterious inscription . Nor was [he]153-grocyn disappointed , for [the learned Edmundus]152-edmundus de prato edmund pratt was equal to the task . Indeed [his]153-grocyn rendering is so excellent an example of mediæval learning and latinity that , even at the risk of sating [the learned reader]504-the learned reader with too many antiquities , [I]0-i have made up [my]0-i mind to give it in fac - simile , together with an expanded version for the benefit of [those who find the contractions troublesome]505-those who find the contractions troublesome . The translation has several peculiarities on which this is not the place to dwell , but [I]0-i would in passing call the attention of [scholars]506-scholars to the passage " duxerunt autem nos ad reginam advenaslasaniscoronantium , "[153-grocyn] which strikes [me]0-i as a delightful rendering of the original , " ἤγαγον δὲ ὡς βασίλειαν τὴν τῶν ξένους χύτραις στεφανούντων . "[153-grocyn]

[Grocyn]153-grocyn , [the instructor of [Erasmus]154-erasmus]507-the instructor of erasmus , studied Greek under Chalcondylas the Byzantine at [Florence]41-florence , and first lectured in [the Hall of Exeter College]508-the hall of exeter college , [Oxford]40-oxford , in 1491 . - Editor .

Mediæval Black - Letter Latin Translation of the Uncial Inscription on [the Sherd of Amenartas

Amenartas]42-the sherd of amenartas amenartas e gen . reg . Egyptii uxor Callicratis ſacerdot Iſidis qua dei fove t demonia atte du t filiol ſuo Tiſiſtheni ia moribu da ita ma dat : Effugi quo da ex Egypto regna te Nectanebo cu patre tuo , p pter mei amore pejerato . Fugie tes aute v ſus Notu trans mare et xxiiij [me]0-i ſes p r litora Libye v ſus Orie te errant ubi eſt petra queda m gna ſculpta inſtar Ethiop capit , deinde dies iiij ab oſt flum m gni eiecti p tim ſubmerſi ſumus p [tim morbo mortui]155-tim morbo mortui ſum : in fine aute a fer ho i bs portabamur p r palud et vada . ubi aviu m titudo celu obu brat dies x. donec advenim ad cavu que da monte , ubi olim m gna urbs erat , caverne quoq [i]0-i m e ſe : duxeru t aute nos ad regina Advenaſlaſaniſcorona tiu que magic utebat et peritia omniu rer et ſalte pulcrit et vigore i ſe eſcibil erat . [Hec]509-hec m gno patr tui amore p culſa p mu q de ei con ubiu michi morte parabat . poſtea v ro recuſa te Callicrate amore mei et timore regine affecto nos p r magica abduxit p r vias horribil ubi eſt puteus ille p fu dus , cuius iuxta aditu iacebat ſenior philoſophi cadaver , et adve ie tib mo ſtravit flam a Vite erecta , i star columne voluta tis , voces emitte te q ſi tonitrus : tu c p r igne i petu nociuo expers tra ſiit et ia ipsa ſeſe formoſior viſa eſt .

Quib fact iuravit ſe patre tuu quoq [i]0-i m ortale oſte ſura eſſe , ſi [me]0-i prius occiſa regine co tuberniu mallet ; neq eni ipſa [me]0-i occidere valuit , p pter noſtratu m gica cuius egomet p tem habeo . Ille vero nichil huius geñ maluit , manib ante ocul paſſis ne mulier formoſitate adſpiceret : poſtea eu m gica p cuſſit arte , at mortuu efferebat i de cu fletib et vagitib , [me]0-i p r timore expulit ad oſtiu m gni flumiñ veliuoli porro in [nave]510-nave in qua te peperi , uix poſt dies hvc Athenas invecta ſu . At tu , O Tiſiſtheñ , ne q d quoru ma do nauci fac : neceſſe eni eſt muliere exquirere ſi qva Vite myſteriu [i]0-i petres et vi dicare , qua tu in te eſt , patre tuu Callierat in regine morte . Sin timore ſue aliq cavſa re reli quis i fecta , hoc ipſu oi b poſter ma do du bonvs q s inveniatur qvi ignis lauacru no p rhorreſcet et p tentia digñ do [i]0-i abit ho i u .

Talia dico incredibilia q de at min e ñcta de reb michi cognitis .

Hec Grece scripta Latine reddidit vir doctus Edm ds de Prato , in Decretis Licenciatus e Coll . Exon : Oxon : doctiſſimi Grocyni quondam e pupillis , Id. Apr. Aᵒ. Dn i. MCCCCLXXXXV .

Expanded Version of the above Mediæval Latin Translation

Amenartas , e genere regio Egyptii , uxor Callicratis , sacerdotis Isidis , quam dei fovent demonia attendunt , filiolo suo Tisistheni jam moribunda ita mandat : Effugi quodam ex Egypto , regnante Nectanebo , cum patre tuo , propter mei amorem pejerato . Fugientes autem versus Notum trans mare , et viginti quatuor menses per litora Libye versus Orientem errantes , ubi est petra quedam magna sculpta instar Ethiopis capitis , deinde dies quatuor ab ostio fluminis magni ejecti partim submersi sumus partim morbo mortui sumus : in fine autem a feris hominibus portabamur per paludes et vada , ubi avium multitudo celum obumbrat , dies decem , donec advenimus ad cavum quendam montem , ubi olim magna urbs erat , caverne quoque immense ; duxerunt autem nos ad reginam Advenaslasaniscoronantium , que magicâ utebatur et peritiá omnium rerum , et saltem pulcritudine et vigore insenescibilis erat . Hec magno patris tui amore perculsa , primum quidem ei connubium michi mortem parabat ; postea vero , recusante Callicrate , amore mei et timore regine affecto , nos per magicam abduxit per vias horribiles ubi est puteus ille profundus , cujus juxta aditum jacebat senioris philosophi cadaver , et advenientibus monstravit flammam Vite erectam , instar columne voluntantis , voces emittentem quasi tonitrus : tunc per ignem impetu nocivo expers transiit et jam ipsa sese formosior visa est .

Quibus factis juravit se patrem tuum quoque immortalem ostensuram esse , si [me]0-i prius occisa regine contubernium mallet ; neque enim ipsa [me]0-i occidere valuit , propter nostratum magicam cujus egomet partem habeo . Ille vero nichil hujus generis malebat , manibus ante oculos passis , ne mulieris formositatem adspiceret : postea illum magica percussit arte , at mortuum efferebat inde cum fletibus et vagitibus , et [me]0-i per timorem expulit ad ostium [magni fluminis , velivoli]511-magni fluminis , velivoli , porro in nave , in qua te peperi , vix post dies huc Athenas vecta sum . At tu , O Tisisthenes , ne quid quorum mando nauci fac : necesse enim est mulierem exquirere si qua Vite mysterium impetres et vindicare , quautum in te est , patrem tuum Callieratem in regine morte . Sin timore sue aliqua causa rem reliquis infectam , hoc ipsum omnibus posteris mando , dum bonus quis inveniatur qui ignis lavacrum non perhorrescet , et potentia dignus dominabitur hominum .

Talia dico incredibilia quidem at minime ficta de rebus michi cognitis .

Hec Grece scripta Latine reddidit vir doctus Edmundus de Prato , in Descretis Licenciatus , e Collegio Exoniensi Oxoniensi doctissimi Grocyni quondam e pupillis , Idibus Aprilis Anno Domini MCCCCLXXXXV .

" Well , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , when at length [I]0-i had read out and carefully examined these writings and paragraphs , at least those of them that were still easily legible , " that is the conclusion of the whole matter , [Leo]108-leo , and now [you]108-leo can form [your]108-leo own opinion on it . [I]0-i have already formed [mine]0-i . "[0-i]

" And what is it ? "[512-i] [he]512-i asked , in [his]512-i quick way .

" It is this . [I]512-i believe that potsherd to be perfectly genuine , and that , wonderful as it may seem , it has come down in [[your]108-leo family]3266-your family from since the fourth century before [Christ]121-christ . The entries absolutely prove it , and therefore , however improbable it may seem , it must be accepted . But there [I]512-i stop . That [[your]108-leo remote ancestress]3158-your remote ancestress , [the Egyptian princess]3268-the egyptian princess , or [some scribe under [her]3268-the egyptian princess direction]3269-some scribe under her direction , wrote that which [we]3270-we see on the sherd [I]512-i have no doubt , nor have [I]512-i the slightest doubt but that [her]3268-the egyptian princess sufferings and the loss of [[her]3268-the egyptian princess husband]3271-her husband had turned [her]3268-the egyptian princess head , and that [she]3268-the egyptian princess was not right in [her]3268-the egyptian princess mind when [she]3268-the egyptian princess did write it . "[512-i]

" How do [you]108-leo account for what [[my]108-leo father]3091-my father saw and heard there ? "[108-leo] asked [Leo]108-leo .

" Coincidence . No doubt there are bluffs on [the coast of [Africa]9-africa]3063-the coast of africa that look something like [a man]352-a man 's head , and plenty of people who speak bastard Arabic . Also , [I]396-the young man believe that there are [lots of swamps]3275-lots of swamps . Another thing is , [Leo]108-leo , and [I]396-the young man am sorry to say it , but [I]396-the young man do not believe that [[your]108-leo poor father]3276-your poor father was quite right when [he]3276-your poor father wrote that letter . [He]3276-your poor father had met with a great trouble , and also [he]3276-your poor father had allowed this story to prey on [his]3276-your poor father imagination , and [he]3276-your poor father was [a very imaginative man]3277-a very imaginative man . Anyway , [I]396-the young man believe that the whole thing is the most unmitigated rubbish . [I]396-the young man know that there are curious things and forces in nature which [we]3278-we rarely meet with , and , when [we]3278-we do meet them , can not understand . But until [I]396-the young man see it with [my]396-the young man own eyes , which [I]396-the young man am not likely to , [I]396-the young man never will believe that there is any means of avoiding death , even for a time , or that there is or was [a white sorceress]3279-a white sorceress living in [the heart of [an African swamp]3281-an african swamp]3280-the heart of an african swamp . It is bosh , [[my]396-the young man boy]3095-my boy , all bosh ! - What do [you]108-leo say , [Job]137-job ? "[396-the young man]

" [I]396-the young man say , [sir]3126-sir , that it is a lie , and , if it is true , [I]396-the young man hope [Mr. Leo]108-leo wo n't meddle with no such things , for no good ca n't come of it . "[396-the young man]

" Perhaps [you]3126-sir are both right , "[108-leo] said [Leo]108-leo , very quietly . " [I]108-leo express no opinion . But [I]108-leo say this . [I]108-leo am going to set the matter at rest once and for all , and if [you]3126-sir wo n't come with [me]108-leo [I]108-leo will go by [myself]108-leo . "[108-leo]

[I]0-i looked at [the young man]396-the young man , and saw that [he]396-the young man meant what [he]396-the young man said . When [Leo]108-leo means what [he]108-leo says [he]108-leo always puts on a curious look about the mouth . It has been a trick of [his]108-leo from [a child]411-a child . Now , as a matter of fact , [I]0-i had no intention of allowing [Leo]108-leo to go anywhere by [himself]108-leo , for [my]0-i own sake , if not for [his]108-leo . [I]0-i was far too attached to [him]108-leo for that . [I]0-i am not [a man of many ties or affections]515-a man of many ties or affections . Circumstances have been against [me]0-i in this respect , and [men]516-men and [women]327-women shrink from [me]0-i , or at least , [I]0-i fancy that [they]518-they do , which comes to the same thing , thinking , perhaps , that [my]0-i somewhat forbidding exterior is a key to [my]0-i character . Rather than endure this , [I]0-i have , to a great extent , secluded [myself]0-i from [the world]252-the world , and cut [myself]0-i off from those opportunities which with [most men]3036-most men result in the formation of relations more or less intimate . Therefore [Leo]108-leo was all [the world]252-the world to [me]0-i - [brother]333-brother , [child]523-child , and [friend]524-friend - and until [he]108-leo wearied of [me]0-i , where [he]108-leo went there [I]0-i should go too . But , of course , it would not do to let [him]108-leo see how great a hold [he]108-leo had over [me]0-i ; so [I]0-i cast about for some means whereby [I]0-i might let [myself]0-i down easy .

" Yes , [I]0-i shall go , [Uncle]450-uncle ; and if [I]0-i do n't find the ' rolling Pillar of Life , ' at any rate [I]0-i shall get some first - class shooting . "[0-i]

Here was [my]0-i opportunity , and [I]0-i took it .

" Shooting ? "[0-i] [I]0-i said . " Ah ! yes ; [I]0-i never thought of that . [It]3285-it must be [a very wild stretch of country]3286-a very wild stretch of country , and full of big game . [I]0-i have always wanted to kill a buffalo before [I]0-i die . Do [you]450-uncle know , [[my]0-i boy]3095-my boy , [I]0-i do n't believe in the quest , but [I]0-i do believe in big game , and really on the whole , if , after thinking it over , [you]450-uncle make up [your]450-uncle mind to go , [I]0-i will take a holiday , and come with [you]450-uncle . "[0-i]

" Ah , "[108-leo] said [Leo]108-leo , " [I]108-leo thought that [you]450-uncle would not lose such a chance . But how about money ? [We]3288-we shall want a good lot . "[108-leo]

" [You]450-uncle need not trouble about that , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered . " There is all [your]450-uncle income that has been accumulating for years , and besides that [I]0-i have saved two - thirds of what [[your]450-uncle father]3289-your father left to [me]0-i , as [I]0-i consider , in trust for [you]450-uncle . There is plenty of cash . "[0-i]

" Very well , then , [we]3288-we may as well stow these things away and go up to [town]393-town to see about [our]3288-we guns . By the way , [Job]137-job , are [you]137-job coming too ? It 's time [you]137-job began to see [the world]252-the world . "[0-i]

" Well , [sir]3126-sir , "[137-job] answered [Job]137-job , stolidly , " [I]137-job do n't hold much with foreign parts , but if [both [you]3293-both you gentlemen [gentlemen]3294-gentlemen]3293-both you gentlemen are going [you]3293-both you gentlemen will want [somebody]357-somebody to look after [you]3293-both you gentlemen , and [I]137-job am not [the man to stop behind after serving [you]3293-both you gentlemen for twenty years]3296-the man to stop behind after serving you for twenty years . "[137-job]

" That 's right , [Job]137-job , "[137-job] said [I.]137-job " [You]3293-both you gentlemen wo n't find out anything wonderful , but [you]3293-both you gentlemen will get some good shooting . And now look here , both of [you]3293-both you gentlemen . [I]0-i wo n't have a word said to [a living soul]3297-a living soul about this nonsense , "[0-i] and [I]0-i pointed to the potsherd . " If it got out , and anything happened to [me]0-i , [[my]0-i next of kin]3298-my next of kin would dispute [my]0-i will on the ground of insanity , and [I]0-i should become [the laughing stock of [Cambridge]2-cambridge]3299-the laughing stock of cambridge . "[0-i]

That day three months [we]525-we were on [the ocean]526-the ocean , bound for [Zanzibar]43-zanzibar .

IV

THE SQUALL

How different is the scene that [I]0-i have now to tell from that which has just been told ! Gone are [the quiet college rooms]527-the quiet college rooms , gone the wind - swayed English elms , the cawing rooks , and the familiar volumes on the shelves , and in [their]528-their place there rises a vision of [the great calm ocean]529-the great calm ocean gleaming in shaded silver lights beneath the beams of the full African moon . A gentle breeze fills the huge sail of [our]525-we dhow , and draws [us]525-we through the water that ripples musically against [her]530-her sides . [Most of [the men]532-the men]531-most of the men are sleeping forward , for it is near midnight , but [a stout swarthy Arab , Mahomed by name]533-a stout swarthy arab , mahomed by name , stands at the tiller , lazily steering by the stars . Three miles or more to [our]525-we starboard is a low dim line . It is [the Eastern shore of [Central Africa]44-central africa]534-the eastern shore of central africa . [We]525-we are running to the southward , before [the North East Monsoon]45-the north east monsoon , between [the mainland]535-the mainland and [the reef that for hundreds of miles fringes [this perilous coast]537-this perilous coast]536-the reef that for hundreds of miles fringes this perilous coast . The night is quiet , so quiet that a whisper can be heard fore and aft the dhow ; so quiet that a faint booming sound rolls across [the water]538-the water to [us]525-we from [the distant land]539-the distant land .

[The Arab at the tiller]540-the arab at the tiller holds up [his]540-the arab at the tiller hand , and says one word : - " [Simba]157-simba lion ! "[540-the arab at the tiller]

[We]525-we all sit up and listen . Then it comes again , a slow , majestic sound , that thrills [us]525-we to the marrow .

" To - morrow by ten o'clock , "[0-i] [I]0-i say , " [we]525-we ought , if [the Captain]3300-the captain is not out in [his]3300-the captain reckoning , which [I]0-i think very probable , to make [this mysterious rock]3301-this mysterious rock with [a man]352-a man 's head , and begin [our]525-we shooting . "[0-i]

" And begin [our]525-we search for [the ruined city]3303-the ruined city and [the Fire of Life]3304-the fire of life , "[108-leo] corrected [Leo]108-leo , taking [his]108-leo pipe from [his]108-leo mouth , and laughing a little .

" Nonsense ! "[0-i] [I]0-i answered . " [You]108-leo were airing [your]108-leo Arabic with [that man at the tiller]3305-that man at the tiller this afternoon . What did [he]3305-that man at the tiller tell [you]108-leo ? [He]3305-that man at the tiller has been trading slave - trading , probably up and down these latitudes for half of [his]3305-that man at the tiller iniquitous life , and once landed on this very ' man ' rock . Did [he]3305-that man at the tiller ever hear anything of [the ruined city]3303-the ruined city or [the caves]3307-the caves ? "[0-i]

" No , "[108-leo] answered [Leo]108-leo . " [He]3305-that man at the tiller says that [the country]3308-the country is all swamp behind , and full of snakes , especially pythons , and game , and that [no man]3309-no man lives there . But then there is [a belt of swamp all along [the East African coast]3311-the east african coast]3310-a belt of swamp all along the east african coast , so that does not go for much . "[108-leo]

" Yes , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " it does - it goes for malaria . [You]108-leo see what sort of an opinion [these gentry]3312-these gentry have of [the country]3308-the country . Not one of [them]3312-these gentry will go with [us]3314-we . [They]3312-these gentry think that [we]3314-we are mad , and upon [my]0-i word [I]0-i believe that [they]3312-these gentry are right . If ever [we]3314-we see old [England]15-england again [I]0-i shall be astonished . However , it does not greatly matter to [me]0-i at [my]0-i age , but [I]0-i am anxious for [you]108-leo , [Leo]108-leo , and for [Job]137-job . It 's [a Tom Fool]3315-a tom fool 's business , [[my]0-i boy]3095-my boy . "[0-i]

" All right , [Uncle Horace]139-uncle horace . So far as [I]541-he am concerned , [I]541-he am willing to take [my]541-he chance . Look ! What is that cloud ? "[541-he] and [he]541-he pointed to a dark blotch upon the starry sky , some miles astern of [us]542-us .

" Go and ask [the man at the tiller]3317-the man at the tiller , "[0-i] [I]0-i said .

[He]541-he rose , stretched [his]541-he arms , and went . Presently [he]541-he returned .

" [He]3317-the man at the tiller says it is a squall , but it will pass far on one side of [us]542-us . "[137-job]

Just then [Job]137-job came up , looking very stout and English in [his]137-job shooting - suit of brown flannel , and with a sort of perplexed appearance upon [his]137-job honest round face that had been very common with [him]137-job since [he]137-job got into [these strange waters]543-these strange waters .

" Please , [sir]3126-sir , "[137-job] [he]137-job said , touching [his]137-job sun hat , which was stuck on to the back of [his]137-job head in a somewhat ludicrous fashion , " as [we]542-us have got all those guns and things in [the whale - boat]3319-the whale - boat astern , to say nothing of the provisions in the lockers , [I]137-job think it would be best if [I]137-job got down and slept in [her]3319-the whale - boat . [I]137-job do n't like the looks "[137-job] here [he]541-he dropped [his]541-he voice to a portentous whisper " of [these black gentry]3320-these black gentry ; [they]3320-these black gentry have such a wonderful thievish way about [them]3320-these black gentry . Supposing now that [some of [them]3320-these black gentry]3321-some of them were to slip into [the boat]3322-the boat at night and cut the cable , and make off with [her]3319-the whale - boat ? That would be a pretty go , that would . "[541-he]

[The whale - boat]3319-the whale - boat , [I]0-i may explain , was one specially built for [us]545-we at [Dundee]46-dundee , in [Scotland]21-scotland . [We]545-we had brought [it]3319-the whale - boat with [us]545-we , as [we]545-we knew that [this coast]546-this coast was [a network of creeks]547-a network of creeks , and that [we]545-we might require something to navigate [them]546-this coast with . [She]3319-the whale - boat was [a beautiful boat , thirty - feet in length , with a centre - board for sailing , copper - bottomed to keep the worm out of [her]3319-the whale - boat]548-a beautiful boat , thirty - feet in length , with a centre - board for sailing , copper - bottomed to keep the worm out of her , and full of water - tight compartments . [The Captain of the dhow]549-the captain of the dhow had told [us]545-we that when [we]545-we reached [the rock]550-the rock , which [he]549-the captain of the dhow knew , and which appeared to be identical with the one described upon the sherd and by [[Leo]108-leo 's father]452-leo 's father , [he]549-the captain of the dhow would probably not be able to run up to [it]550-the rock on account of [the shallows]552-the shallows and breakers . Therefore [we]545-we had employed three hours that very morning , whilst [we]545-we were totally becalmed , the wind having dropped at sunrise , in transferring most of [our]545-we goods and chattels to [the whale - boat]3319-the whale - boat , and placing the guns , ammunition , and preserved provisions in the water - tight lockers specially prepared for [them]546-this coast , so that when [we]545-we did sight [the fabled rock]554-the fabled rock [we]545-we should have nothing to do but step into [the boat]3322-the boat , and run [her]3319-the whale - boat ashore . Another reason that induced [us]545-we to take this precautionary step was that [Arab captains]556-arab captains are apt to run past the point that [they]556-arab captains are making , either from carelessness or owing to a mistake in its identity . Now , as [sailors]557-sailors know , it is quite impossible for a dhow which is only rigged to run before the monsoon to beat back against it . Therefore [we]545-we got [[our]545-we boat]558-our boat ready to row for [the rock]550-the rock at any moment .

" Well , [Job]137-job , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " perhaps it would be as well . There are lots of blankets there , only be careful to keep out of the moon , or it may turn [your]137-job head or blind [you]137-job . "[0-i]

" Lord , [sir]3126-sir ! [I]137-job do n't think it would much matter if it did ; it is that turned already with the sight of [these blackamoors]3324-these blackamoors and [their]3324-these blackamoors filthy , thieving ways . [They]3324-these blackamoors are only fit for muck , [they]3324-these blackamoors are ; and [they]3324-these blackamoors smell bad enough for it already . "[137-job]

[Job]137-job , it will be perceived , was no admirer of the manners and customs of [[our]545-we dark - skinned brothers]560-our dark - skinned brothers .

Accordingly [we]545-we hauled up [the boat]3322-the boat by the tow - rope till it was right under the stern of [the dhow]562-the dhow , and [Job]137-job bundled into [her]3322-the boat with all the grace of a falling sack of potatoes . Then [we]545-we returned and sat down on [the deck]563-the deck again , and smoked and talked in little gusts and jerks . The night was so lovely , and [our]545-we brains were so full of suppressed excitement of one sort and another , that [we]545-we did not feel inclined to turn in . For nearly an hour [we]545-we sat thus , and then , [I]0-i think , [we]545-we both dozed off . At least [I]0-i have a faint recollection of [Leo]108-leo sleepily explaining that the head was not a bad place to hit a buffalo , if [you]564-you could catch [him]108-leo exactly between the horns , or send [your]564-you bullet down [his]108-leo throat , or some nonsense of the sort .

Then [I]0-i remember no more ; till suddenly - a frightful roar of wind , a shriek of terror from [the awakening crew]565-the awakening crew , and a whip - like sting of water in [our]545-we faces . [Some of [the men]532-the men]566-some of the men ran to let go the haulyards and lower the sail , but [the parrel]568-the parrel jammed and [the yard]569-the yard would not come down . [I]0-i sprang to [my]0-i feet and hung on to a rope . The sky aft was dark as pitch , but the moon still shone brightly ahead of [us]545-we and lit up the blackness . Beneath its sheen a huge white - topped breaker , twenty feet high or more , was rushing on to [us]545-we . It was on the break - the moon shone on its crest and tipped its foam with light . On it rushed beneath the inky sky , driven by the awful squall behind it . Suddenly , in the twinkling of an eye , [I]0-i saw the black shape of [the whale - boat]3319-the whale - boat cast high into the air on the crest of the breaking wave . Then - a shock of water , a wild rush of boiling foam , and [I]0-i was clinging for [my]0-i life to the shroud , ay , swept straight out from it like a flag in a gale .

[We]545-we were pooped .

The wave passed . It seemed to [me]0-i that [I]0-i was under water for minutes - really it was seconds . [I]0-i looked forward . The blast had torn out the great sail , and high in the air it was fluttering away to leeward like a huge wounded bird . Then for a moment there was comparative calm , and in it [I]0-i heard [Job]137-job 's voice yelling wildly , " Come here to [the boat]3322-the boat . "[137-job]

Bewildered and half - drowned as [I]0-i was , [I]0-i had the sense to rush aft . [I]0-i felt the dhow sinking under [me]0-i - [she]571-her was full of water . Under [her]571-her counter [the whale - boat]3319-the whale - boat was tossing furiously , and [I]0-i saw [the Arab Mahomed]158-mahomed , who had been steering , leap into [her]571-her . [I]0-i gave one desperate pull at the tow - rope to bring [the boat]3322-the boat alongside . Wildly [I]0-i sprang also , [Job]137-job caught [me]0-i by the arm and [I]0-i rolled into the bottom of [the boat]3322-the boat . Down went [the dhow]562-the dhow bodily , and as [she]571-her did so [Mahomed]158-mahomed drew [his]158-mahomed curved knife and severed the fibre - rope by which [we]576-we were fast to [her]571-her , and in another second [we]576-we were driving before the storm over the place where the dhow had been .

" [Great God]134-god ! "[0-i] [I]0-i shrieked , " where is [Leo]108-leo ? [Leo]108-leo ! [Leo]108-leo ! "[0-i]

" [He]108-leo 's gone , [sir]3126-sir , [God]134-god help [him]108-leo ! "[137-job] roared [Job]137-job into [my]0-i ear ; and such was the fury of the squall that [his]137-job voice sounded like a whisper .

[I]0-i wrung [my]0-i hands in agony . [Leo]108-leo was drowned , and [I]0-i was left alive to mourn [him]108-leo .

" Look out , "[137-job] yelled [Job]137-job ; " here comes another . "[137-job]

[I]0-i turned ; a second huge wave was overtaking [us]576-we . [I]0-i half hoped that it would drown [me]0-i . With a curious fascination [I]0-i watched its awful advent . The moon was nearly hidden now by the wreaths of the rushing storm , but a little light still caught the crest of [the devouring breaker]577-the devouring breaker . There was something dark on [it]577-the devouring breaker - a piece of wreckage . [It]577-the devouring breaker was on [us]576-we now , and [the boat]3322-the boat was nearly full of water . But [she]3322-the boat was built in air - tight compartments - Heaven bless [the man who invented them]579-the man who invented them ! - and lifted up through it like a swan . Through the foam and turmoil [I]0-i saw the black thing on the wave hurrying right at [me]0-i . [I]0-i put out [my]0-i right arm to ward it from [me]0-i , and [my]0-i hand closed on another arm , the wrist of which [my]0-i fingers gripped like a vice . [I]0-i am [a very strong man]580-a very strong man , and had something to hold to , but [my]0-i arm was nearly torn from its socket by the strain and weight of the floating body . Had the rush lasted another two seconds [I]0-i might either have let go or gone with it . But it passed , leaving [us]576-we up to [our]576-we knees in water .

" Bail out ! bail out ! "[137-job] shouted [Job]137-job , suiting the action to the word .

But [I]0-i could not bail just then , for as the moon went out and left [us]576-we in total darkness , one faint , flying ray of light lit upon the face of [the man [I]0-i had gripped , who was now half lying , half floating in the bottom of [the boat]3322-the boat]581-the man i had gripped , who was now half lying , half floating in the bottom of the boat .

It was [Leo]108-leo . [Leo]108-leo brought back by the wave - back , dead or alive , from the very jaws of Death .

" Bail out ! bail out ! "[137-job] yelled [Job]137-job , " or [we]576-we shall founder . "[137-job]

[I]0-i seized a large tin bowl with a handle to it , which was fixed under one of the seats , and [the three of [us]576-we]583-the three of us bailed away for dear life . The furious tempest drove over and round [us]576-we , flinging [the boat]3322-the boat this way and that , the wind and the storm wreaths and the sheets of stinging spray blinded and bewildered [us]576-we , but through it all [we]576-we worked like demons with the wild exhilaration of despair , for even despair can exhilarate . One minute ! three minutes ! six minutes ! [The boat]3322-the boat began to lighten , and no fresh wave swamped [us]576-we . Five minutes more , and [she]3322-the boat was fairly clear . Then , suddenly , above the awful shriekings of the hurricane came a duller , deeper roar . Great Heavens ! It was the voice of [breakers]586-breakers !

At that moment the moon began to shine forth again - this time behind the path of the squall . Out far across the torn bosom of [the ocean]526-the ocean shot the ragged arrows of [her]3322-the boat light , and there , half a mile ahead of [us]576-we , was a white line of foam , then a little space of open - mouthed blackness , and then another line of white . It was [the breakers]588-the breakers , and [their]588-the breakers roar grew clearer and yet more clear as [we]576-we sped down upon [them]588-the breakers like a swallow . There [they]588-the breakers were , boiling up in snowy spouts of spray , smiting and gnashing together like the gleaming teeth of hell .

" Take the tiller , [Mahomed]158-mahomed ! "[0-i] [I]0-i roared in Arabic . " [We]576-we must try and shoot [them]588-the breakers . "[0-i] At the same moment [I]0-i seized an oar , and got it out , motioning to [Job]137-job to do likewise .

[Mahomed]158-mahomed clambered aft , and got hold of the tiller , and with some difficulty [Job]137-job , who had sometimes pulled [a tub upon the homely Cam]589-a tub upon the homely cam , got out [his]137-job oar . In another minute [the boat]3322-the boat 's head was straight on to the ever - nearing foam , towards which [she]3322-the boat plunged and tore with the speed of a racehorse . Just in front of [us]576-we the first line of breakers seemed a little thinner than to the right or left - there was a cap of rather deeper water . [I]0-i turned and pointed to it .

" Steer for [your]158-mahomed life , [Mahomed]158-mahomed ! "[0-i] [I]0-i yelled . [He]158-mahomed was [a skilful steersman]591-a skilful steersman , and well acquainted with the dangers of [this most perilous coast]592-this most perilous coast , and [I]0-i saw [him]158-mahomed grip the tiller , bend [his]158-mahomed heavy frame forward , and stare at the foaming terror till [his]158-mahomed big round eyes looked as though they would start out of [his]158-mahomed head . The send of [the sea]593-the sea was driving [the boat]3322-the boat 's head round to starboard . If [we]576-we struck the line of breakers fifty yards to starboard of the gap [we]576-we must sink . It was a great field of twisting , spouting waves . [Mahomed]158-mahomed planted [his]158-mahomed foot against the seat before [him]158-mahomed , and , glancing at [him]158-mahomed , [I]0-i saw [his]158-mahomed brown toes spread out like a hand with the weight [he]158-mahomed put upon them as [he]158-mahomed took the strain of the tiller . [She]595-she came round a bit , but not enough . [I]0-i roared to [Job]137-job to back water , whilst [I]0-i dragged and laboured at [my]0-i oar . [She]595-she answered now , and none too soon .

Heavens , [we]576-we were in them ! And then followed a couple of minutes of heart - breaking excitement such as [I]0-i can not hope to describe . All that [I]0-i remember is [a shrieking sea of foam]596-a shrieking sea of foam , out of which the billows rose here , there , and everywhere like avenging ghosts from [[their]597-their ocean grave]598-their ocean grave . Once [we]576-we were turned right round , but either by chance , or through [Mahomed]158-mahomed 's skilful steering , [the boat]3322-the boat 's head came straight again before a breaker filled [us]576-we . One more - [a monster]600-a monster . [We]576-we were through it or over it - more through than over - and then , with a wild yell of exultation from [the Arab]158-mahomed , [we]576-we shot out into the comparative smooth water of [the mouth of sea]601-the mouth of sea between the teeth - like lines of gnashing waves .

But [we]576-we were nearly full of water again , and not more than half a mile ahead was the second line of breakers . Again [we]576-we set to and bailed furiously . Fortunately the storm had now quite gone by , and the moon shone brightly , revealing [a rocky headland]602-a rocky headland running half a mile or more out into [the sea]593-the sea , of which [this second line of breakers]604-this second line of breakers appeared to be a continuation . At any rate , they boiled around its foot . Probably [the ridge that formed [the headland]606-the headland]605-the ridge that formed the headland ran out into [the ocean]526-the ocean , only at a lower level , and made [the reef]608-the reef also . [This headland]609-this headland was terminated by [a curious peak that seemed not to be more than a mile away from [us]576-we]610-a curious peak that seemed not to be more than a mile away from us . Just as [we]576-we got [the boat]3322-the boat pretty clear for the second time , [Leo]108-leo , to [my]0-i immense relief , opened [his]108-leo eyes and remarked that the clothes had tumbled off the bed , and that [he]108-leo supposed it was time to get up for [chapel]612-chapel . [I]0-i told [him]108-leo to shut [his]108-leo eyes and keep quiet , which [he]108-leo did without in the slightest degree realizing the position . As for [myself]0-i , [his]108-leo reference to [chapel]612-chapel made [me]0-i reflect , with a sort of sick longing , on [[my]0-i comfortable rooms at [Cambridge]2-cambridge]614-my comfortable rooms at cambridge . Why had [I]0-i been such a fool as to leave [them]614-my comfortable rooms at cambridge ? This is a reflection that has several times recurred to [me]0-i since , and with an ever - increasing force .

But now again [we]615-we were drifting down on the breakers , though with lessened speed , for the wind had fallen , and only the current or the tide it afterwards turned out to be the tide was driving [us]615-we .

Another minute , and with a sort of howl to [Allah]159-allah from [the Arab]158-mahomed , a pious ejaculation from [myself]0-i , and something that was not pious from [Job]137-job , [we]615-we were in [them]614-my comfortable rooms at cambridge . And then the whole scene , down to [our]615-we final escape , repeated itself , only not quite so violently . [Mahomed]158-mahomed 's skilful steering and the air - tight compartments saved [our]615-we lives . In five minutes [we]615-we were through , and drifting - for [we]615-we were too exhausted to do anything to help [ourselves]615-we except keep [her]616-her head straight - with the most startling rapidity round [the headland]606-the headland which [I]0-i have described .

Round [we]615-we went with the tide , until [we]615-we got well under the lee of the point , and then suddenly the speed slackened , [we]615-we ceased to make way , and finally appeared to be in dead water . The storm had entirely passed , leaving a clean - washed sky behind [it]618-it ; [the headland]606-the headland intercepted [the heavy sea]620-the heavy sea that had been occasioned by the squall , and the tide , which had been running so fiercely up [the river]621-the river for [we]615-we were now in [the mouth of [a river]3213-a river]622-the mouth of a river , was sluggish before it turned , so [we]615-we floated quietly , and before the moon went down managed to bail out [the boat]3322-the boat thoroughly and get [her]616-her a little ship - shape . [Leo]108-leo was sleeping profoundly , and on the whole [I]0-i thought it wise not to wake [him]108-leo . It was true [he]108-leo was sleeping in wet clothes , but the night was now so warm that [I]0-i thought and so did [Job]137-job that [they]625-they were not likely to injure [a man of [his]108-leo unusually vigorous constitution]626-a man of his unusually vigorous constitution . Besides , [we]615-we had no dry ones at hand .

Presently the moon went down , and left [us]615-we floating on [the waters]3211-the waters , now only heaving like [some troubled woman]628-some troubled woman 's breast , with leisure to reflect upon all that [we]615-we had gone through and all that [we]615-we had escaped . [Job]137-job stationed [himself]137-job at the bow , [Mahomed]158-mahomed kept [his]158-mahomed post at the tiller , and [I]0-i sat on a seat in the middle of [the boat]3322-the boat close to where [Leo]108-leo was lying .

The moon went slowly down in chastened loveliness ; [she]630-her departed like [some sweet bride into [her]630-her chamber]631-some sweet bride into her chamber , and long veil - like shadows crept up the sky through which the stars peeped shyly out . Soon , however , they too began to pale before a splendour in the east , and then the quivering footsteps of the dawn came rushing across the new - born blue , and shook the high stars from their places . Quieter and yet more quiet grew [the sea]593-the sea , quiet as the soft mist that brooded on [her]630-her bosom , and covered up [her]630-her troubling , as the illusive wreaths of sleep brood upon a pain - racked mind , causing it to forget its sorrow . From the east to the west sped [the angels of the Dawn]633-the angels of the dawn , from [sea to sea]634-sea to sea , from [mountain - top to mountain - top]635-mountain - top to mountain - top , scattering light with both [their]633-the angels of the dawn hands . On [they]633-the angels of the dawn sped out of the darkness , perfect , glorious , like [spirits of the just breaking from the tomb]636-spirits of the just breaking from the tomb ; on , over [the quiet sea]637-the quiet sea , over [the low coastline]638-the low coastline , and [the swamps beyond]639-the swamps beyond , and [the mountains above [them]633-the angels of the dawn]640-the mountains above them ; over [those who slept in peace]641-those who slept in peace and [those who woke in sorrow]642-those who woke in sorrow ; over the evil and the good ; over the living and the dead ; over [the wide world]643-the wide world and all that breathes or has breathed thereon .

It was a wonderfully beautiful sight , and yet sad , perhaps , from the very excess of [its]644-its beauty . The arising sun ; the setting sun ! There [we]645-we have the symbol and the type of [humanity]646-humanity , and all things with which [humanity]646-humanity has to do . The symbol and the type , yes , and the earthly beginning , and the end also . And on that morning this came [home]648-home to [me]0-i with a peculiar force . The sun that rose to - day for [us]645-we had set last night for [eighteen of [[our]645-we fellow - voyagers]650-our fellow - voyagers]649-eighteen of our fellow - voyagers ! - had set everlastingly for [eighteen whom [we]645-we knew]651-eighteen whom we knew !

The dhow had gone down with [them]651-eighteen whom we knew , [they]651-eighteen whom we knew were tossing about among the rocks and seaweed , so much human drift on [the great ocean of Death]652-the great ocean of death ! And [we]645-we four were saved . But one day a sunrise will come when [we]645-we shall be among [those who are lost]653-those who are lost , and then [others]309-others will watch those glorious rays , and grow sad in the midst of beauty , and dream of Death in the full glow of arising Life !

For this is the lot of [man]3189-man .

V

THE HEAD OF [THE ETHIOPIAN]47-the ethiopian

At length [the heralds and forerunners of the royal sun]656-the heralds and forerunners of the royal sun had done [their]656-the heralds and forerunners of the royal sun work , and , searching out the shadows , had caused [them]656-the heralds and forerunners of the royal sun to flee away . Then up [he]657-he came in glory from [[his]657-he ocean]658-his ocean - bed , and flooded [the earth]659-the earth with warmth and light . [I]0-i sat there in [the boat]3322-the boat listening to the gentle lapping of the water and watched [him]657-he rise , till presently the slight drift of [the boat]3322-the boat brought the odd - shaped rock , or peak , at the end of [the promontory]662-the promontory which [we]645-we had weathered with so much peril , between [me]0-i and the majestic sight , and blotted it from [my]0-i view . [I]0-i still continued , however , to stare at the rock , absently enough , till presently it became edged with the fire of the growing light behind it , and then [I]0-i started , as well [I]0-i might , for [I]0-i perceived that the top of the peak , which was about eighty feet high by one hundred and fifty feet thick at [its]662-the promontory base , was shaped like [a negro]663-a negro 's head and face , whereon was stamped a most fiendish and terrifying expression . There was no doubt about it ; there were the thick lips , the fat cheeks , and the squat nose standing out with startling clearness against the flaming background . There , too , was the round skull , washed into shape perhaps by thousands of years of wind and weather , and , to complete the resemblance , there was a scrubby growth of weeds or lichen upon it , which against the sun looked for all [the world]252-the world like the wool on a colossal negro 's head . It certainly was very odd ; so odd that now [I]0-i believe it is not a mere freak of nature but a gigantic monument fashioned , like the well - known Egyptian Sphinx , by [a forgotten people out of a pile of rock that lent itself to [their]666-their design , perhaps as an emblem of warning and defiance to [any enemies who approached [the harbour]668-the harbour]667-any enemies who approached the harbour]665-a forgotten people out of a pile of rock that lent itself to their design , perhaps as an emblem of warning and defiance to any enemies who approached the harbour . Unfortunately [we]645-we were never able to ascertain whether or not this was the case , inasmuch as [the rock]550-the rock was difficult of access both from [the land]670-the land and [the waterside]671-the waterside , and [we]645-we had other things to attend to . [Myself]0-i , considering the matter by the light of what [we]645-we afterwards saw , [I]0-i believe that it was fashioned by [man]3189-man , but whether or not this is so , there it stands , and sullenly stares from age to age out across [the changing sea]673-the changing sea - there it stood two thousand years and more ago , when [Amenartas]118-kallikrates , [the Egyptian princess]3268-the egyptian princess , and [the wife of [[Leo]108-leo 's remote ancestor [Kallikrates]118-kallikrates]676-leo 's remote ancestor kallikrates]675-the wife of leo 's remote ancestor kallikrates , gazed upon [its]550-the rock devilish face - and there [I]0-i have no doubt it will still stand when as many centuries as are numbered between [her]550-the rock day and [our]645-we own are added to the year that bore [us]645-we to oblivion .

" What do [you]137-job think of that , [Job]137-job ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked of [[our]645-we retainer]677-our retainer , who was sitting on the edge of [the boat]3322-the boat , trying to get as much sunshine as possible , and generally looking uncommonly wretched , and [I]0-i pointed to the fiery and demonical head .

" Oh Lord , [sir]3126-sir , "[137-job] answered [Job]137-job , who now perceived the object for the first time , " [I]137-job think that [the old geneleman]3328-the old geneleman must have been sitting for [his]3328-the old geneleman portrait on them rocks . "[137-job]

[I]0-i laughed , and the laugh woke up [Leo]108-leo .

" [Hullo]160-hullo , "[108-leo] [he]108-leo said , " what 's the matter with [me]108-leo ? [I]108-leo am all stiff - where is the dhow ? Give [me]108-leo some brandy , please . "[108-leo]

" [You]108-leo may be thankful that [you]108-leo are not stiffer , [[my]0-i boy]3095-my boy , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered . " The dhow is sunk , [everybody on board [her]3331-her]3330-everybody on board her is drowned with the exception of [us]679-we four , and [your]108-leo own life was only saved by a miracle "[0-i] ; and whilst [Job]137-job , now that it was light enough , searched about in a locker for the brandy for which [Leo]108-leo asked , [I]0-i told [him]108-leo the history of [our]679-we night 's adventure .

" Great Heavens ! "[108-leo] [he]108-leo said faintly ; " and to think that [we]679-we should have been chosen to live through it ! "[108-leo]

By this time the brandy was forthcoming , and [we]679-we all had a good pull at it , and thankful enough [we]679-we were for it . Also the sun was beginning to get strength , and warm [our]679-we chilled bones , for [we]679-we had been wet through for five hours or more .

" Why , "[108-leo] said [Leo]108-leo , with a gasp as [he]108-leo put down the brandy bottle , " there is the head the writing talks of , the ' rock carven like the head of [an Ethiopian]3215-an ethiopian . ' "[108-leo]

" Yes , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " there it is . "[0-i]

" Well , then , "[108-leo] [he]108-leo answered , " the whole thing is true . "[108-leo]

" [I]0-i do n't see at all that that follows , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered . " [We]679-we knew this head was here : [[your]0-i father]3289-your father saw it . Very likely it is not the same head that the writing talks of ; or if it is , it proves nothing . "[0-i]

[Leo]108-leo smiled at [me]0-i in a superior way . " [You]0-i are [an unbelieving Jew]3334-an unbelieving jew , [Uncle Horace]139-uncle horace , "[108-leo] [he]108-leo said . " [Those who live]3335-those who live will see . "[108-leo]

" Exactly so , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered , " and now perhaps [you]0-i will observe that [we]681-we are drifting across [a sandbank]3336-a sandbank into [the mouth of [the river]621-the river]3337-the mouth of the river . Get hold of [your]0-i oar , [Job]137-job , and [we]681-we will row in and see if [we]681-we can find a place to land . "[0-i]

[The river mouth which [we]681-we were entering]680-the river mouth which we were entering did not appear to be a very wide one , though as yet the long banks of steaming mist that clung about [its]680-the river mouth which we were entering shores had not lifted sufficiently to enable [us]681-we to see its exact measure . There was , as is the case with nearly [every East African river]682-every east african river , a considerable bar at [the mouth]683-the mouth , which , no doubt , when the wind was on [shore]684-shore and the tide running out , was absolutely impassable even for [a boat]685-a boat drawing only a few inches . But as things were it was manageable enough , and [we]681-we did not ship a cupful of water . In twenty minutes [we]681-we were well across [it]686-it , with but slight assistance from [ourselves]681-we , and being carried by a strong though somewhat variable breeze well up [the harbour]668-the harbour . By this time the mist was being sucked up by the sun , which was getting uncomfortably hot , and [we]681-we saw that [the mouth of [the little estuary]689-the little estuary]688-the mouth of the little estuary was here about half a mile across , and that [the banks]690-the banks were very marshy , and crowded with crocodiles lying about on the mud like logs . About a mile ahead of [us]681-we , however , was what appeared to be [a strip of firm land]691-a strip of firm land , and for this [we]681-we steered . In another quarter of an hour [we]681-we were there , and making [the boat]3322-the boat fast to a beautiful tree with broad shining leaves , and flowers of the magnolia species , only they were rose - coloured and not white , which hung over the water , [we]681-we disembarked . This done [we]681-we undressed , washed [ourselves]681-we , and spread [our]681-we clothes , together with the contents of [the boat]3322-the boat , in the sun to dry , which [they]694-they very quickly did . Then , taking shelter from the sun under some trees , [we]681-we made a hearty breakfast off a " Paysandu "[694-they] potted tongue , of which [we]681-we had brought a good quantity with [us]681-we , congratulating [ourselves]681-we loudly on [our]681-we good fortune in having loaded and provisioned [the boat]3322-the boat on the previous day before the hurricane destroyed the dhow . By the time that [we]681-we had finished [our]681-we meal [our]681-we clothes were quite dry , and [we]681-we hastened to get into them , feeling not a little refreshed . Indeed , with the exception of weariness and a few bruises , [none of [us]681-we]696-none of us were the worse for the terrifying adventure which had been fatal to [all [our]681-we companions]697-all our companions . [Leo]108-leo , it is true , had been half - drowned , but that is no great matter to [a vigorous young athlete of five - and - twenty]698-a vigorous young athlete of five - and - twenty .

There is a known species of magnolia with pink flowers . It is indigenous in [Sikkim]48-sikkim , and known as [Magnolia Campbellii]161-magnolia campbellii . - Editor .

After breakfast [we]681-we started to look about [us]681-we . [We]681-we were on [a strip of dry land about two hundred yards broad by five hundred long , bordered on one side by [the river]621-the river]699-a strip of dry land about two hundred yards broad by five hundred long , bordered on one side by the river , and on the other three by [endless desolate swamps]701-endless desolate swamps , that stretched as far as the eye could reach . [This strip of land]702-this strip of land was raised about twenty - five feet above [the plain of [the surrounding swamps]704-the surrounding swamps]703-the plain of the surrounding swamps and [the river]621-the river level : indeed [it]702-this strip of land had every appearance of having been made by the hand of [man]3189-man .

" [This place]3339-this place has been [a wharf]3340-a wharf , "[108-leo] said [Leo]108-leo , dogmatically .

" Nonsense , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered . " Who would be stupid enough to build a wharf in the middle of [these dreadful marshes]3341-these dreadful marshes in [a country inhabited by [savages]3343-savages]3342-a country inhabited by savages - that is , if it is inhabited at all ? "[0-i]

" Perhaps it was not always marsh , and perhaps [the people]3344-the people were not always savage , "[108-leo] [he]108-leo said drily , looking down [the steep bank]707-the steep bank , for [we]681-we were standing by [the river]621-the river . " Look there , "[108-leo] [he]108-leo went on , pointing to a spot where the hurricane of the previous night had torn up one of the magnolia trees by the roots , which had grown on [the extreme edge of [the bank]710-the bank just where it sloped down to the water]709-the extreme edge of the bank just where it sloped down to the water , and lifted a large cake of earth with them . " Is not that stonework ? If not , it is very like it . "[108-leo]

" Nonsense , "[0-i] [I]0-i said again , but [we]681-we clambered down to [the spot]711-the spot , and got between the upturned roots and [the bank]710-the bank .

" Well ? "[108-leo] [he]108-leo said .

But [I]0-i did not answer this time . [I]0-i only whistled . For there , laid bare by the removal of the earth , was an undoubted facing of solid stone laid in large blocks and bound together with brown cement , so hard that [I]0-i could make no impression on it with the file in [my]0-i shooting - knife . Nor was this all ; seeing something projecting through the soil at the bottom of the bared patch of walling , [I]0-i removed the loose earth with [my]0-i hands , and revealed a huge stone ring , a foot or more in diameter , and about three inches thick . This fairly staggered [me]0-i .

" Looks rather like [a wharf where [good - sized vessels]3346-good - sized vessels have been moored]3345-a wharf where good - sized vessels have been moored , does it not , [Uncle Horace]139-uncle horace ? "[108-leo] said [Leo]108-leo , with an excited grin .

[I]0-i tried to say " Nonsense "[0-i] again , but the word stuck in [my]0-i throat - the ring spoke for itself . In some past age vessels had been moored [there]3168-there , and this stone wall was undoubtedly the remnant of [a solidly constructed wharf]714-a solidly constructed wharf . Probably [the city to which [it]3168-there had belonged]715-the city to which it had belonged lay buried beneath [the swamp behind [it]3168-there]716-the swamp behind it .

" Begins to look as though there were something in the story after all , [Uncle Horace]139-uncle horace , "[108-leo] said the exultant [Leo]108-leo ; and reflecting on [the mysterious negro]717-the mysterious negro 's head and the equally mysterious stonework , [I]0-i made no direct reply .

" [A country like [Africa]9-africa]3347-a country like africa , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " is sure to be full of the relics of long dead and forgotten civilisations . [Nobody]488-nobody knows the age of the Egyptian civilisation , and very likely it had offshoots . Then there were [the Babylonians]3349-the babylonians and [the Phœnicians]162-the phœnicians , and [the Persians]3350-the persians , and all manner of people , all more or less civilised , to say nothing of [the Jews whom [everybody]3352-everybody ' wants ' nowadays]3351-the jews whom everybody ' wants ' nowadays . It is possible that [they]3351-the jews whom everybody ' wants ' nowadays , or [any one of [them]3351-the jews whom everybody ' wants ' nowadays]3353-any one of them , may have had colonies or trading stations about here . Remember those buried [Persian cities that [the consul]3355-the consul showed [us]3356-us at [Kilwa]49-kilwa]3354-persian cities that the consul showed us at kilwa . "[0-i]

Near [Kilwa]49-kilwa , on [the East Coast of [Africa]9-africa , about 400 miles south of [Zanzibar]43-zanzibar]718-the east coast of africa , about 400 miles south of zanzibar , is [a cliff which has been recently washed by the waves]719-a cliff which has been recently washed by the waves . On the top of this cliff are Persian tombs known to be at least seven centuries old by the dates still legible upon [them]720-them . Beneath [these tombs]721-these tombs is a layer of débris representing [a city]722-a city . Farther down [the cliff]723-the cliff is a second layer representing [an older city]724-an older city , and farther down still a third layer , the remains of yet another city of vast and unknown antiquity . Beneath [the bottom city]725-the bottom city were recently found some specimens of glazed earthenware , such as are occasionally to be met with on [that coast]726-that coast to this day . [I]0-i believe that they are now in the possession of [Sir John Kirk]163-sir john kirk . - [Editor]164-editor .

" Quite so , "[108-leo] said [Leo]108-leo , " but that is not what [you]0-i said before . "[108-leo]

" Well , what is to be done now ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked , turning the conversation .

As no answer was forthcoming [we]727-we walked to [the edge of [the swamp]729-the swamp]728-the edge of the swamp , and looked over [it]729-the swamp . [It]729-the swamp was apparently boundless , and vast flocks of every sort of waterfowl flew from its recesses , till it was sometimes difficult to see the sky . Now that the sun was getting high it drew thin sickly looking clouds of poisonous vapour from the surface of [the marsh]730-the marsh and from [the scummy pools of stagnant water]731-the scummy pools of stagnant water .

" Two things are clear to [me]0-i , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , addressing [[my]0-i three companions]732-my three companions , who stared at this spectacle in dismay : " first , that [we]727-we ca n't go across there "[0-i] [I]0-i pointed to [the swamp]729-the swamp , " and , secondly , that if [we]727-we stop [here]3102-here [we]727-we shall certainly die of fever . "[0-i]

" That 's as clear as a haystack , [sir]3126-sir , "[137-job] said [Job]137-job .

" Very well , then ; there are two alternatives before [us]727-we . One is to 'bout [ship]3359-ship , and try and run for some port in [the whale - boat]3319-the whale - boat , which would be a sufficiently risky proceeding , and the other to sail or row on up [the river]621-the river , and see where [we]727-we come to . "[0-i]

" [I]108-leo do n't know what [you]108-leo are going to do , "[108-leo] said [Leo]108-leo , setting [his]108-leo mouth , " but [I]108-leo am going up [that river]3362-that river . "[108-leo]

[Job]137-job turned up the whites of [his]137-job eyes and groaned , and [the Arab]734-the arab murmured " Allah , "[734-the arab] and groaned also . As for [me]0-i , [I]0-i remarked sweetly that as [we]735-we seemed to be between [the devil]736-the devil and [the deep sea]737-the deep sea , it did not much matter where [we]735-we went . But in reality [I]0-i was as anxious to proceed as [Leo]108-leo . [The colossal negro]738-the colossal negro 's head and [the stone wharf]739-the stone wharf had excited [my]0-i curiosity to an extent of which [I]0-i was secretly ashamed , and [I]0-i was prepared to gratify it at any cost . Accordingly , having carefully fitted the mast , restowed [the boat]3322-the boat , and got out [our]735-we rifles , [we]735-we embarked . Fortunately the wind was blowing on [shore]684-shore from [the ocean]526-the ocean , so [we]735-we were able to hoist the sail . Indeed , [we]735-we afterwards found out that as a general rule the wind set on [shore]684-shore from daybreak for some hours , and off [shore]684-shore again at sunset , and the explanation that [I]0-i offer of this is , that when [the earth]659-the earth is cooled by the dew and the night the hot air rises , and the draught rushes in from [the sea]593-the sea till the sun has once more heated it through . At least that appeared to be the rule here .

Taking advantage of this favouring wind , [we]735-we sailed merrily up [the river]621-the river for three or four hours . Once [we]735-we came across a school of hippopotami , which rose , and bellowed dreadfully at [us]735-we within ten or a dozen fathoms of [the boat]3322-the boat , much to [Job]137-job 's alarm , and , [I]0-i will confess , to [my]0-i own . These were [the first hippopotami that [we]735-we had ever seen]749-the first hippopotami that we had ever seen , and , to judge by [their]749-the first hippopotami that we had ever seen insatiable curiosity , [I]0-i should judge that [we]735-we were [the first white men that [they]749-the first hippopotami that we had ever seen had ever seen]750-the first white men that they had ever seen .
