" [I]108-leo feel as though [I]108-leo were going to die , "[108-leo] [he]108-leo answered hoarsely . " [My]108-leo head is splitting , [my]108-leo body is trembling , and [I]108-leo am as sick as a cat . "[108-leo]

[I]0-i whistled , or if [I]0-i did not whistle [I]0-i felt inclined to - [Leo]108-leo had got a sharp attack of fever . [I]0-i went to [Job]137-job , and asked [him]137-job for the quinine , of which fortunately [we]1404-we had still a good supply , only to find that [Job]137-job [himself]137-job was not much better . [He]137-job complained of pains across the back , and dizziness , and was almost incapable of helping [himself]137-job . Then [I]0-i did the only thing it was possible to do under the circumstances - gave [them]1405-them both about ten grains of quinine , and took a slightly smaller dose [myself]0-i as a matter of precaution . After that [I]0-i found [Billali]137-job , and explained to [him]137-job how matters stood , asking at the same time what [he]137-job thought had best be done . [He]137-job came with [me]0-i , and looked at [Leo]108-leo and [Job]137-job whom , by the way , [he]137-job had named the Pig on account of [his]137-job fatness , round face , and small eyes .

" Ah , "[137-job] [he]137-job said , when [we]1404-we were out of earshot , " the fever ! [I]137-job thought so . [The Lion]183-leo has it badly , but [he]137-job is young , and [he]137-job may live . As for [the Pig]185-the pig , [his]137-job attack is not so bad ; it is the ' little fever ' which [he]137-job has ; that always begins with pains across the back , it will spend itself upon [his]137-job fat . "[137-job]

" Can [they]3560-they go on , [[my]0-i father]3091-my father ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

" Nay , [[my]137-job son]3150-my son , [they]3560-they must go on . If [they]3560-they stop [here]3102-here [they]3560-they will certainly die ; also , [they]3560-they will be better in the litters than on the ground . By to - night , if all goes well , [we]1406-we shall be across [the marsh]730-the marsh and in good air . Come , let [us]1406-we lift [them]3560-they into the litters and start , for it is very bad to stand still in this morning fog . [We]1406-we can eat [our]1406-we meal as [we]1406-we go . "[137-job]

This [we]1406-we accordingly did , and with a heavy heart [I]0-i once more set out upon [our]1406-we strange journey . For the first three hours all went as well as could be expected , and then an accident happened that nearly lost [us]1406-we the pleasure of the company of [[our]1406-we venerable friend]1407-our venerable friend [Billali]137-job , whose litter was leading [the cavalcade]1355-the cavalcade . [We]1406-we were going through a particularly dangerous stretch of quagmire , in which [the bearers]890-the bearers sometimes sank up to [their]890-the bearers knees . Indeed , it was a mystery to [me]0-i how [they]890-the bearers contrived to carry the heavy litters at all over such ground as that which [we]1406-we were traversing , though [the two spare hands]1410-the two spare hands , as well as [the four regular ones]1411-the four regular ones , had of course to put [their]1411-the four regular ones shoulders to the pole .

Presently , as [we]1406-we blundered and floundered along , there was a sharp cry , then a storm of exclamations , and , last of all , a most tremendous splash , and [the whole caravan]1412-the whole caravan halted .

[I]0-i jumped out of [my]0-i litter and ran forward . About twenty yards ahead was the edge of [one of [those sullen peaty pools of which]1414-those sullen peaty pools of which [I]0-i have spoken]1413-one of those sullen peaty pools of which i have spoken , the path [we]1406-we were following running along [the top of [its]1413-one of those sullen peaty pools of which i have spoken bank]1415-the top of its bank , that , as it happened , was a steep one . Looking towards [this pool]1416-this pool , to [my]0-i horror [I]0-i saw that [Billali]137-job 's litter was floating on it , and as for [Billali]137-job [himself]137-job , [he]137-job was nowhere to be seen . To make matters clear [I]0-i may as well explain at once what had happened . [One of [[Billali]137-job 's bearers]1418-billali 's bearers]1417-one of billali 's bearers had unfortunately trodden on a basking snake , which had bitten [him]1417-one of billali 's bearers in the leg , whereon [he]1417-one of billali 's bearers had , not unnaturally , let go of the pole , and then , finding that [he]1417-one of billali 's bearers was tumbling down [the bank]710-the bank , grasped at the litter to save [himself]1417-one of billali 's bearers . The result of this was what might have been expected . The litter was pulled over the edge of [the bank]710-the bank , [the bearers]890-the bearers let go , and the whole thing , including [Billali]137-job and [the man who had been bitten]1422-the man who had been bitten , rolled into [the slimy pool]1423-the slimy pool . When [I]0-i got to the edge of the water neither of [them]1424-them were to be seen ; indeed , [the unfortunate bearer]1425-the unfortunate bearer never was seen again . Either [he]1425-the unfortunate bearer struck [his]1425-the unfortunate bearer head against something , or get wedged in the mud , or possibly the snake - bite paralyzed [him]1425-the unfortunate bearer . At any rate [he]1425-the unfortunate bearer vanished . But though [Billali]137-job was not to be seen , [his]137-job whereabouts was clear enough from the agitation of the floating litter , in the bearing cloth and curtains of which [he]137-job was entangled .

" [He]137-job is there ! [[Our]532-the men father]3565-our father is there ! "[1426-one of the men] said [one of [the men]532-the men]1426-one of the men , but [he]1426-one of the men did not stir a finger to help [him]137-job , nor did [any of [the others]847-the others]1428-any of the others . [They]532-the men simply stood and stared at the water .

" Out of the way , [you brutes]3566-you brutes ! "[0-i] [I]0-i shouted in English , and throwing off [my]0-i hat [I]0-i took a run and sprang well out into [the horrid slimy - looking pool]1430-the horrid slimy - looking pool . A couple of strokes took [me]0-i to where [Billali]137-job was struggling beneath the cloth .

Somehow , [I]0-i do not quite know how , [I]0-i managed to push it free of [him]137-job , and [his]137-job venerable head all covered with green slime , like that of a yellowish Bacchus with ivy leaves , emerged upon the surface of [the water]538-the water . The rest was easy , for [Billali]137-job was [an eminently practical individual]1432-an eminently practical individual , and had the common sense not to grasp hold of [me]0-i as [drowning people]1433-drowning people often do , so [I]0-i got [him]137-job by the arm , and towed [him]137-job to [the bank]710-the bank , through the mud out of which [we]1435-we were with difficulty dragged . Such a filthy spectacle as [we]1435-we presented [I]0-i have never seen before or since , and it will perhaps give some idea of the almost superhuman dignity of [Billali]137-job 's appearance when [I]0-i say that , coughing , half - drowned , and covered with mud and green slime as [he]137-job was , with [his]137-job beautiful beard coming to a dripping point , like [a Chinaman]1436-a chinaman 's freshly - oiled pig - tail , [he]137-job still looked venerable and imposing .

" [Ye]890-the bearers dogs , "[137-job] [he]137-job said , addressing [the bearers]890-the bearers , as soon as [he]137-job had sufficiently recovered to speak , " [ye]890-the bearers left [me]137-job , [[your]890-the bearers father]3289-your father , to drown . Had it not been for [this stranger]3568-this stranger , [[my]137-job son]3150-my son [the Baboon]3497-the baboon , assuredly [I]137-job should have drowned . Well , [I]137-job will remember it , "[137-job] and [he]137-job fixed [them]890-the bearers with [his]137-job gleaming though slightly watery eye , in a way [I]0-i saw that [they]890-the bearers did not like , though [they]890-the bearers tried to appear sulkily indifferent .

" As for [thee]0-i , [[my]910-the old man son]3150-my son , "[910-the old man] [the old man]910-the old man went on , turning towards [me]0-i and grasping [my]0-i hand , " rest assured that [I]910-the old man am [[thy]0-i friend]3572-thy friend through good and evil . [Thou]0-i hast saved [my]910-the old man life : perchance a day may come when [I]910-the old man shall save [thine]0-i . "[910-the old man]

After that [we]1439-we cleaned [ourselves]1439-we as best [we]1439-we could , fished out the litter , and went on , minus [the man who had been drowned]1440-the man who had been drowned . [I]0-i do not know if it was owing to [his]1440-the man who had been drowned being [an unpopular character]1441-an unpopular character , or from native indifference and selfishness of temperament , but [I]0-i am bound to say that [nobody]488-nobody seemed to grieve much over [his]1440-the man who had been drowned sudden and final disappearance , unless , perhaps , it was [the men who had to do [his]1440-the man who had been drowned share of the work]1443-the men who had to do his share of the work .

[XI

THE PLAIN OF K"R]111-k"r[111-k"r]

About an hour before sundown [we]1439-we at last , to [my]0-i unbounded gratitude , emerged from [the great belt of marsh on to land that swelled upwards in a succession of rolling waves]1444-the great belt of marsh on to land that swelled upwards in a succession of rolling waves . Just on [the hither side of the crest of the first wave]1445-the hither side of the crest of the first wave [we]1439-we halted for the night . [My]0-i first act was to examine [Leo]183-leo 's condition . It was , if anything , worse than in the morning , and a new and very distressing feature , vomiting , set in , and continued till dawn . Not one wink of sleep did [I]0-i get that night , for [I]0-i passed it in assisting [Ustane]172-ustane , who was one of [the most gentle and indefatigable nurses [I]0-i ever saw]1446-the most gentle and indefatigable nurses i ever saw , to wait upon [Leo]183-leo and [Job]137-job . However , the air here was warm and genial without being too hot , and there were no mosquitoes to speak of . Also [we]1439-we were above the level of [the marsh]730-the marsh mist , which lay stretched beneath [us]1439-we like the dim smoke - pall over [a city]722-a city , lit up here and there by the wandering globes of fen fire . Thus it will be seen that [we]1439-we were , speaking comparatively , in clover .

By dawn on the following morning [Leo]183-leo was quite light - headed , and fancied that [he]183-leo was divided into halves . [I]0-i was dreadfully distressed , and began to wonder with a sort of sick fear what the end of the attack would be . Alas ! [I]0-i had heard but too much of how these attacks generally terminate . As [I]0-i was wondering [Billali]137-job came up and said that [we]1439-we must be getting on , more especially as , in [his]137-job opinion , if [Leo]183-leo did not reach some spot where [he]183-leo could be quiet , and have proper nursing , within the next twelve hours , [his]183-leo life would only be a matter of a day or two . [I]0-i could not but agree with [him]137-job , so [we]1439-we got [Leo]183-leo into the litter , and started on , [Ustane]172-ustane walking by [his]183-leo side to keep the flies off [him]183-leo , and see that [he]183-leo did not throw [himself]183-leo out on to the ground .

Within half an hour of sunrise [we]1439-we had reached the top of [the rise of which [I]0-i have spoken]1449-the rise of which i have spoken , and a most beautiful view broke upon [our]1439-we gaze . Beneath [us]1439-we was [a rich stretch of country]1450-a rich stretch of country , verdant with grass and lovely with foliage and flowers . In the background , at a distance , so far as [I]0-i could judge , of some eighteen miles from where [we]1439-we then stood , [a huge and extraordinary mountain]1451-a huge and extraordinary mountain rose abruptly from [the plain]1452-the plain . [The base of [this great mountain]1454-this great mountain]1453-the base of this great mountain appeared to consist of a grassy slope , but rising from this , [I]0-i should say , from subsequent observation , at a height of about five hundred feet above [the level of [the plain]1452-the plain]1455-the level of the plain , was a most tremendous and absolutely precipitous wall of bare rock , quite twelve or fifteen hundred feet in height . The shape of [the mountain]1457-the mountain , which was undoubtedly of volcanic origin , was round , and of course , as only a segment of [its]1457-the mountain circle was visible , it was difficult to estimate [its]1457-the mountain exact size , which was enormous . [I]0-i afterwards discovered that [it]1457-the mountain could cover less than fifty square miles of ground . Anything more grand and imposing than the sight presented by [this great natural castle]1458-this great natural castle , starting in solitary grandeur from the level of [the plain]1452-the plain , [I]0-i never saw , and [I]0-i suppose [I]0-i never shall . [Its]1457-the mountain very solitude added to [its]1457-the mountain majesty , and [its]1457-the mountain towering cliffs seemed to kiss the sky . Indeed , generally speaking , [they]1460-they were clothed in clouds that lay in fleecy masses upon [their]1460-they broad and level battlements .

[I]0-i sat up in [my]0-i hammock and gazed out across [the plain]1452-the plain at this thrilling and majestic sight , and [I]0-i suppose that [Billali]137-job noticed it , for [he]137-job brought [his]137-job litter alongside .

" Behold the house of ' [[She]3573-she - who - must - be - obeyed]3574-she - who - must - be - obeyed ! ' "[137-job] [he]137-job said . " Had ever [a queen]1102-a queen such a throne before ? "[137-job]

" It is wonderful , [[my]0-i father]3091-my father , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered . " But how do [we]3577-we enter . Those cliffs look hard to climb . "[0-i]

" [Thou]3578-thou shalt see , [[my]137-job Baboon]3510-my baboon . Look now at [the path below [us]3577-we]3580-the path below us . What thinkest [thou]3578-thou that it is ? [Thou]3578-thou art [a wise man]3581-a wise man . Come , tell [me]137-job . "[137-job]

[I]0-i looked , and saw what appeared to be the line of [roadway]1462-roadway running straight towards [the base of [the mountain]1457-the mountain]1463-the base of the mountain , though it was covered with turf . There were high banks on each side of [it]1457-the mountain , broken here and there , but fairly continuous on the whole , the meaning of which [I]0-i did not understand . It seemed so very odd that [anybody]3032-anybody should embank [a roadway]1466-a roadway .

" Well , [[my]0-i father]3091-my father , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered , " [I]0-i suppose that it is [a road]3583-a road , otherwise [I]0-i should have been inclined to say that it was the bed of [a river]3213-a river , or rather , "[0-i] [I]0-i added , observing the extraordinary directness of the cutting , " of a canal . "[0-i]

[Billali]137-job - who , by the way , was none the worse for [his]137-job immersion of the day before - nodded [his]137-job head sagely as [he]137-job replied -

" [Thou]3585-thou art right , [[my]137-job son]3150-my son . It is a channel cut out by [those who were before [us]3588-us in [this place to carry away water]3589-this place to carry away water]3587-those who were before us in this place to carry away water . Of this [I]137-job am sure : within [the rocky circle of [the mountain]1457-the mountain]3590-the rocky circle of the mountain whither [we]3588-us journey was once [a great lake]3592-a great lake . But [those who were before [us]3588-us]3593-those who were before us , by wonderful arts of which [I]137-job know naught , hewed a path for the water through [the solid rock of [the mountain]1457-the mountain]3594-the solid rock of the mountain , piercing even to [the bed of [the lake]779-the lake]3596-the bed of the lake . But first [they]3593-those who were before us cut the channel that [thou]3585-thou seest across [the plain]1452-the plain . Then , when at last the water burst out , it rushed down the channel that had been made to receive it , and crossed [this plain]3599-this plain till it reached [the low land behind the rise]3600-the low land behind the rise , and there , perchance , it made [the swamp through which [we]3588-us have come]3601-the swamp through which we have come . Then when [the lake]779-the lake was drained dry , [the people]3344-the people whereof [I]137-job speak built [a mighty city on [its]779-the lake bed]3604-a mighty city on its bed , whereof naught but ruins and the name of [K"r]111-k"r[137-job] yet remaineth , and from age to age hewed [the caves]3307-the caves and passages that [thou]1468-thou wilt see . "[137-job]

" It may be , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered ; " but if so , how is it that [the lake]779-the lake does not fill up again with the rains and the water of [the springs]3606-the springs ? "[0-i]

" Nay , [[my]1469-my son]3150-my son , [the people]3344-the people were [a wise people]3609-a wise people , and [they]3344-the people left a drain to keep it clear . Seest [thou]1468-thou [the river to the right]3610-the river to the right ? "[1469-my] and [he]1469-my pointed to [a fair - sized stream that wound away across [the plain]1452-the plain , some four miles from [us]1472-us]1470-a fair - sized stream that wound away across the plain , some four miles from us . " That is the drain , and it comes out through the mountain wall where this cutting goes in . At first , perhaps , the water ran down [this canal]3611-this canal , but afterwards [the people]3344-the people turned it , and used the cutting for [a road]3583-a road . "[1469-my]

" And is there then no other place where one may enter into [the great mountain]3614-the great mountain , "[0-i] [I]0-i asked , " except through that drain ? "[0-i]

" There is a place , "[1469-my] [he]1469-my answered , " where cattle and [men on foot]3615-men on foot may cross with much labour , but it is secret . A year mightest [thou]1468-thou search and shouldst never find it . It is only used once a year , when the herds of cattle that have been fatting on [the slopes of [the mountain]1457-the mountain]3616-the slopes of the mountain , and on [this plain]3599-this plain , are driven into the space within . "[1469-my]

" And does [She]3619-she live [there]3168-there always ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked , " or does [she]3619-she come at times without [the mountain]1457-the mountain ? "[0-i]

" Nay , [[my]1469-my son]3150-my son , where [she]3619-she is , there [she]3619-she is . "[1469-my]

By now [we]1473-we were well on to [the great plain]1474-the great plain , and [I]0-i was examining with delight the varied beauty of [its]1474-the great plain semi - tropical flowers and trees , the latter of which grew singly , or at most in clumps of three or four , much of the timber being of large size , and belonging apparently to a variety of evergreen oak . There were also many palms , some of them more than one hundred feet high , and the largest and most beautiful tree ferns that [I]0-i ever saw , about which hung clouds of jewelled honeysuckers and great - winged butterflies . Wandering about among the trees or crouching in the long and feathered grass were all varieties of game , from rhinocerotes down . [I]0-i saw a rhinoceros , buffalo a large herd , eland , quagga , and sable antelope , the most beautiful of all the bucks , not to mention many smaller varieties of game , and three ostriches which scudded away at [our]1473-we approach like white drift before a gale . So plentiful was the game that at last [I]0-i could stand it no longer . [I]0-i had a single barrel sporting [Martini]186-martini with [me]0-i in the litter , the " Express "[186-martini] being too cumbersome , and espying a beautiful fat eland rubbing [himself]1475-him under one of the oak - like trees , [I]0-i jumped out of the litter , and proceeded to creep as near to [him]1475-him as [I]0-i could . [He]1475-him let [me]0-i come within eighty yards , and then turned [his]1475-him head , and stared at [me]0-i , preparatory to running away . [I]0-i lifted the rifle , and taking [him]1475-him about midway down the shoulder , for [he]1475-him was side on to [me]0-i , fired . [I]0-i never made a cleaner shot or a better kill in all [my]0-i small experience , for the great buck sprang right up into the air and fell dead . [The bearers , who had all halted to see the performance]1476-the bearers , who had all halted to see the performance , gave a murmur of surprise , an unwonted compliment from [these sullen people , who never appear to be surprised at anything]1477-these sullen people , who never appear to be surprised at anything , and [a party of the guard]1478-a party of the guard at once ran off to cut the animal up . As for [myself]0-i , though [I]0-i was longing to have a look at [him]1475-him , [I]0-i sauntered back to [my]0-i litter as though [I]0-i had been in the habit of killing eland all [my]0-i life , feeling that [I]0-i had gone up several degrees in the estimation of [the Amahagger , who looked on the whole thing as a very high - class manifestation of witchcraft]1479-the amahagger , who looked on the whole thing as a very high - class manifestation of witchcraft . As a matter of fact , however , [I]0-i had never seen [an eland in a wild state]1480-an eland in a wild state before . [Billali]137-job received [me]0-i with enthusiasm .

" It is wonderful , [[my]137-job son]3150-my son [the Baboon]3497-the baboon , "[137-job] [he]137-job cried ; " wonderful ! [Thou]1475-him art [a very great man]3625-a very great man , though so ugly . Had [I]137-job not seen , surely [I]137-job would never have believed . And [thou]1475-him sayest that [thou]1475-him wilt teach [me]137-job to slay in this fashion ? "[137-job]

" Certainly , [[my]0-i father]3091-my father , "[0-i] [I]0-i said airily ; " it is nothing . "[0-i]

But all the same [I]0-i firmly made up [my]0-i mind that when " [[my]137-job father]3091-my father "[137-job] [Billali]137-job began to fire [I]0-i would without fail lie down or take refuge behind a tree .

After this little incident nothing happened of any note till about an hour and a half before sundown , when [we]1481-we arrived beneath the shadow of the towering volcanic mass that [I]0-i have already described . It is quite impossible for [me]0-i to describe its grim grandeur as it appeared to [me]0-i while [[my]0-i patient bearers]1482-my patient bearers toiled along the bed of [the ancient watercourse]1483-the ancient watercourse towards [the spot where [the rich brown - hued cliff]1485-the rich brown - hued cliff shot up from precipice to precipice]1484-the spot where the rich brown - hued cliff shot up from precipice to precipice till [its]1485-the rich brown - hued cliff crown lost itself in a cloud . All [I]0-i can say is that it almost awed [me]0-i by the intensity of its lonesome and most solemn greatness . On [we]1481-we went up [the bright and sunny slope]1486-the bright and sunny slope , till at last the creeping shadows from above swallowed up its brightness , and presently [we]1481-we began to pass through a cutting hewn in the living rock . Deeper and deeper grew this marvellous work , which must , [I]0-i should say , have employed thousands of [men]516-men for many years . Indeed , how it was ever executed at all without the aid of blasting - powder or dynamite [I]0-i can not to this day imagine . It is and must remain one of the mysteries of [that wild land]1488-that wild land . [I]0-i can only suppose that these cuttings and [the vast caves that had been hollowed out of the rocks [they]516-men pierced]1489-the vast caves that had been hollowed out of the rocks they pierced were the State undertakings of [the people of [K"r]56-k"r , who lived [here]3102-here in the dim lost ages of [the world]252-the world]3628-the people of k"r , who lived here in the dim lost ages of the world , and , as in the case of the Egyptian monuments , were executed by the forced labour of [tens of thousands of captives , carried on through an indefinite number of centuries]3631-tens of thousands of captives , carried on through an indefinite number of centuries . But who were [the people]3344-the people ?[0-i]

At last [we]1481-we reached [the face of [the precipice itself]1491-the precipice itself]1490-the face of the precipice itself , and found [ourselves]1481-we looking into the mouth of a dark tunnel that forcibly reminded [me]0-i of those undertaken by [[our]1481-we nineteenth - century engineers]1492-our nineteenth - century engineers in the construction of railway lines . Out of [this tunnel]1493-this tunnel flowed [a considerable stream of water]1494-a considerable stream of water . Indeed , though [I]0-i do not think that [I]0-i have mentioned it , [we]1481-we had followed [this stream]1495-this stream , which ultimately developed into [the river]621-the river [I]0-i have already described as winding away to the right , from [the spot where the cutting in the solid rock commenced]1497-the spot where the cutting in the solid rock commenced . Half of this cutting formed [a channel for [the stream]826-the stream]1498-a channel for the stream , and half , which was placed on a slightly higher level - eight feet perhaps - was devoted to the purposes of [a roadway]1466-a roadway . At the termination of the cutting , however , [the stream]826-the stream turned off across [the plain]1452-the plain and followed [a channel of]1503-a channel of [its]826-the stream own . At [the mouth of [the cave]936-the cave]1328-the mouth of the cave [the cavalcade]1355-the cavalcade was halted , and , while [the men]532-the men employed [themselves]532-the men in lighting some earthenware lamps [they]532-the men had brought with [them]532-the men , [Billali]137-job , descending from [his]137-job litter , informed [me]0-i politely but firmly that the orders of [She]1508-she were that [we]1509-we were now to be blindfolded , so that [we]1509-we should not learn the secret of the paths through [the bowels of [the mountains]3433-the mountains]1510-the bowels of the mountains . To this [I]0-i , of course , assented cheerfully enough , but [Job , who was now very much better , notwithstanding the journey]1512-job , who was now very much better , notwithstanding the journey , did not like it at all , fancying , [I]0-i believe , that it was but a preliminary step to being hot - potted . [He]1512-job , who was now very much better , notwithstanding the journey was , however , a little consoled when [I]0-i pointed out to [him]1512-job , who was now very much better , notwithstanding the journey that there were no hot pots at hand , and , so far as [I]0-i knew , no fire to heat them in . As for poor [Leo]183-leo , after turning restlessly for hours , [he]183-leo had , to [my]0-i deep thankfulness , at last dropped off into a sleep or stupor , [I]0-i do not know which , so there was no need to blindfold [him]183-leo . The blindfolding was performed by binding a piece of the yellowish linen whereof those of [the Amahagger who condescended to wear anything in particular made [their]1513-the amahagger who condescended to wear anything in particular made their dresses , tightly round the eyes dresses , tightly round the eyes]1513-the amahagger who condescended to wear anything in particular made their dresses , tightly round the eyes . This linen [I]0-i afterwards discovered was taken from [the tombs]1514-the tombs , and was not , as [I]0-i had at first supposed , of native manufacture . The bandage was then knotted at the back of the head , and finally brought down again and the ends bound under the chin to prevent its slipping . [Ustane]172-ustane was , by the way , also blindfolded , [I]0-i do not know why , unless it was from fear that [she]172-ustane should impart the secrets of the route to [us]1515-we .

This operation performed [we]1515-we started on once more , and soon , by the echoing sound of the footsteps of [the bearers]890-the bearers and the increased noise of the water caused by reverberation in a confined space , [I]0-i knew that [we]1515-we were entering into [the bowels of [the great mountain]3614-the great mountain]1517-the bowels of the great mountain . It was an eerie sensation , being borne along into [the dead heart of [the rock]550-the rock [we]1515-we knew not whither]1519-the dead heart of the rock we knew not whither , but [I]0-i was getting used to eerie sensations by this time , and by now was pretty well prepared for anything . So [I]0-i lay still , and listened to the tramp , tramp of [the bearers]890-the bearers and the rushing of the water , and tried to believe that [I]0-i was enjoying [myself]0-i . Presently [the men]532-the men set up the melancholy little chant that [I]0-i had heard on the first night when [we]1515-we were captured in [the whaleboat]1523-the whaleboat , and the effect produced by [their]532-the men voices was very curious , and quite indescribable . After a while the air began to get exceedingly thick and heavy , so much so , indeed , that [I]0-i felt as though [I]0-i were going to choke , till at length the litter took a sharp turn , then another and another , and the sound of the running water ceased . After this the air was fresher again , but the turns were continuous , and to [me]0-i , blindfolded as [I]0-i was , most bewildering . [I]0-i tried to keep a map of them in [my]0-i mind in case it might ever be necessary for [us]1515-we to try and escape by this route , but , needless to say , failed utterly . Another half - hour or so passed , and then suddenly [I]0-i became aware that [we]1515-we were once more in the open air . [I]0-i could see the light through [my]0-i bandage and feel its freshness on [my]0-i face . A few more minutes and [the caravan]1524-the caravan halted , and [I]0-i heard [Billali]137-job order [Ustane]1525-her to remove [her]1525-her bandage and undo [ours]1515-we . Without waiting for [her]1525-her attentions [I]0-i got the knot of mine loose , and looked out .

As [I]0-i anticipated , [we]1515-we had passed right through the precipice , and were now on the farther side , and immediately beneath [its]1526-its beetling face . The first thing [I]0-i noticed was that [the cliff]723-the cliff is not nearly so high here , not so high [I]0-i should say by five hundred feet , which proved that the bed of [the lake]779-the lake , or rather of [the vast ancient crater in which [we]1515-we stood]1529-the vast ancient crater in which we stood , was much above the level of [the surrounding plain]1530-the surrounding plain . For the rest , [we]1515-we found [ourselves]1515-we in [a huge rock - surrounded cup , not unlike that of the first place where [we]1515-we had sojourned]1531-a huge rock - surrounded cup , not unlike that of the first place where we had sojourned , only ten times the size . Indeed , [I]0-i could only just make out the frowning line of [the opposite cliffs]1532-the opposite cliffs . [A great portion of [the plain thus enclosed by nature]1534-the plain thus enclosed by nature]1533-a great portion of the plain thus enclosed by nature was cultivated , and fenced in with walls of stone placed there to keep the cattle and goats , of which there were large herds about , from breaking into [the gardens]1535-the gardens . Here and there rose great grass mounds , and some miles away towards the centre [I]0-i thought that [I]0-i could see the outline of colossal ruins . [I]0-i had no time to observe anything more at the moment , for [we]1515-we were instantly surrounded by [crowds of Amahagger]1536-crowds of amahagger , similar in every particular to those with whom [we]1515-we were already familiar , who , though [they]1536-crowds of amahagger spoke little , pressed round [us]1515-we so closely as to obscure the view to [a person lying in a hammock]1537-a person lying in a hammock . Then all of a sudden a number of [armed men arranged in companies]1538-armed men arranged in companies , and marshalled by [officers who held ivory wands in [their]1539-officers who held ivory wands in their hands hands]1539-officers who held ivory wands in their hands , came running swiftly towards [us]1515-we , having , so far as [I]0-i could make out , emerged from the face of the precipice like ants from [[their]1536-crowds of amahagger burrows]1540-their burrows . [These men]3427-these men as well as [[their]3427-these men officers]1542-their officers were all robed in addition to the usual leopard skin , and , as [I]0-i gathered , formed the bodyguard of [She]1543-she [herself]1543-she .

[[Their]3427-these men leader]1544-their leader advanced to [Billali]137-job , saluted [him]137-job by placing [his]137-job ivory wand transversely across [his]137-job forehead , and then asked some question which [I]0-i could not catch , and [Billali]137-job having answered [him]137-job [the whole regiment]1545-the whole regiment turned and marched along the side of [the cliff]723-the cliff , [our]1547-we cavalcade of litters following in [their]3427-these men track . After going thus for about half a mile [we]1547-we halted once more in front of the mouth of [a tremendous cave]1548-a tremendous cave , measuring about sixty feet in height by eighty wide , and here [Billali]137-job descended finally , and requested [Job]137-job and [myself]0-i to do the same . [Leo]183-leo , of course , was far too ill to do anything of the sort . [I]0-i did so , and [we]1547-we entered [the great cave]1549-the great cave , into which the light of the setting sun penetrated for some distance , while beyond the reach of the daylight it was faintly illuminated with lamps which seemed to [me]0-i to stretch away for an almost immeasurable distance , like the gas lights of [an empty London street]1550-an empty london street . The first thing [I]0-i noticed was that the walls were covered with sculptures in bas - relief , of a sort , pictorially speaking , similar to those that [I]0-i have described upon the vases ; - love - scenes principally , then hunting pictures , pictures of executions , and the torture of [criminals]1551-criminals by the placing of a , presumably , red - hot pot upon the head , showing whence [[our]1547-we hosts]1079-our hosts had derived this pleasant practice . There were very few battle - pieces , though many of duels , and [men running and wrestling]1553-men running and wrestling , and from this fact [I]0-i am led to believe that [this people]1554-this people were not much subject to attack by [exterior foes]1555-exterior foes , either on account of the isolation of [their]1554-this people position or because of [their]1554-this people great strength . Between the pictures were columns of stone characters of a formation absolutely new to [me]0-i ; at any rate , they were neither Greek nor Egyptian , nor Hebrew , nor Assyrian - that [I]0-i am sure of . They looked more like Chinese writings than any other that [I]0-i am acquainted with . Near to the entrance of [the cave]936-the cave both pictures and writings were worn away , but further in they were in many cases absolutely fresh and perfect as the day on which [the sculptor]1557-the sculptor had ceased work on them .

[The regiment of [guards]1559-guards]1558-the regiment of guards did not come further than the entrance to [the cave]936-the cave , where [they]1558-the regiment of guards formed up to let [us]1547-we pass through . On entering [the place itself]1561-the place itself [we]1547-we were , however , met by [a man robed in white]1562-a man robed in white , who bowed humbly , but said nothing , which , as it afterwards appeared that [he]1562-a man robed in white was [a deaf mute]1563-a deaf mute , was not very wonderful .

Running at right angles to [the great cave]1549-the great cave , at a distance of some twenty feet from the entrance , was a smaller cave or [wide gallery]1565-wide gallery , that was pierced into the rock both to the right and to the left of [the main cavern]1566-the main cavern . In front of [the gallery]1567-the gallery to [our]1547-we left stood [two guards]1568-two guards , from which circumstance [I]0-i argued that it was the entrance to [the apartments of She]1569-the apartments of she [herself]1570-you . The mouth of the right - hand gallery was unguarded , and along [it]1571-it [the mute]1572-the mute indicated that [we]1547-we were to go . Walking a few yards down [this passage]1573-this passage , which was lighted with lamps , [we]1547-we came to the entrance of a chamber having a curtain made of some grass material , not unlike a Zanzibar mat in appearance , hung over the doorway . This [the mute]1572-the mute drew back with another profound obeisance , and led the way into [a good - sized apartment]1575-a good - sized apartment , hewn , of course , out of [the solid rock]1576-the solid rock , but to [my]0-i great relief lighted by means of a shaft pierced in the face of the precipice . In [this room]1577-this room was [a stone bedstead]1578-a stone bedstead , pots full of water for washing , and beautifully tanned leopard skins to serve as blankets .

Here [we]1547-we left [Leo]183-leo , who was still sleeping heavily , and with [him]183-leo stopped [Ustane]172-ustane . [I]0-i noticed that [the mute]1572-the mute gave [her]1570-you a very sharp look , as much as to say , " Who are [you]1570-you , and by whose order do [you]1570-you come here ? "[1570-you] Then [he]1572-the mute conducted [us]1547-we to [another similar room which [Job]137-job took , and then to two more that were respectively occupied by [Billali]137-job and [myself]0-i]1580-another similar room which job took , and then to two more that were respectively occupied by billali and myself .

[XII

"]187-xii " [SHE]1570-you "[187-xii "]

The first care of [Job]137-job and [myself]0-i , after seeing to [Leo]183-leo , was to wash [ourselves]1547-we and put on clean clothing , for what [we]1547-we were wearing had not been changed since the loss of the dhow . Fortunately , as [I]0-i think that [I]0-i have said , by far the greater part of [our]1547-we personal baggage had been packed into [the whaleboat]1523-the whaleboat , and was therefore saved - and brought hither by [the bearers]890-the bearers - although [all the stores laid in by [us]1547-we for barter and presents to [the natives]1584-the natives]1583-all the stores laid in by us for barter and presents to the natives was lost . Nearly all [our]1547-we clothing was made of a well - shrunk and very strong grey flannel , and excellent [I]0-i found it for travelling in [these places]1585-these places , because though a Norfolk jacket , shirt , and pair of trousers of it only weighed about four pounds , a great consideration in [a tropical country]1586-a tropical country , where every extra ounce tells on [the wearer]1587-the wearer , it was warm , and offered a good resistance to the rays of the sun , and best of all to chills , which are so apt to result from sudden changes of temperature .

Never shall [I]0-i forget the comfort of the " wash and brush - up , "[171-the amahagger] and of those clean flannels . The only thing that was wanting to complete [my]0-i joy was a cake of soap , of which [we]1547-we had none .

Afterwards [I]0-i discovered that [the Amahagger]171-the amahagger , who do not reckon dirt among [their]171-the amahagger many disagreeable qualities , use a kind of burnt earth for washing purposes , which , though unpleasant to the touch till [one]328-one gets accustomed to it , forms a very fair substitute for soap .

By the time that [I]0-i was dressed , and had combed and trimmed [my]0-i black beard , the previous condition of which was certainly sufficiently unkempt to give weight to [Billali]137-job 's appellation for [me]0-i of " Baboon , "[0-i] [I]0-i began to feel most uncommonly hungry . Therefore [I]0-i was by no means sorry when , without the slightest preparatory sound or warning , the curtain over the entrance to [[my]0-i cave]1589-my cave was flung aside , and [another mute]1590-another mute , [a young girl this time]1591-a young girl this time , announced to [me]0-i by signs that [I]0-i could not misunderstand - that is , by opening [her]1591-a young girl this time mouth and pointing down it - that there was something ready to eat . [Accordingly]188-accordingly [I]0-i followed [her]1591-a young girl this time into [the next chamber , which [we]1593-we had not yet entered]1592-the next chamber , which we had not yet entered , where [I]0-i found [Job]137-job , who had also , to [his]137-job great embarrassment , been conducted thither by [a fair mute]1594-a fair mute . [Job]137-job never got over the advances [the former lady]1595-the former lady had made towards [him]137-job , and suspected [every girl who came near to [him]137-job]1596-every girl who came near to him of similar designs .

" [These young parties]3633-these young parties have a way of looking at one , [sir]3126-sir , "[137-job] [he]137-job would say apologetically , " which [I]137-job do n't call respectable . "[137-job]

[This chamber]1049-this chamber was twice the size of [the sleeping caves]1598-the sleeping caves , and [I]0-i saw at once that [it]1049-this chamber had originally served as [a refectory]1599-a refectory , and also probably as [an embalming room for [the Priests of [the Dead]1054-the dead]1601-the priests of the dead]1600-an embalming room for the priests of the dead ; for [I]0-i may as well say at once that [these hollowed - out caves]1603-these hollowed - out caves were nothing more nor less than [vast catacombs]1604-vast catacombs , in which for tens of ages the mortal remains of [the great extinct race whose monuments surrounded [us]1606-us]1605-the great extinct race whose monuments surrounded us had been first preserved , with an art and a completeness that has never since been equalled , and then hidden away for all time . On each side of [this particular rock - chamber]1607-this particular rock - chamber was a long and solid stone table , about three feet wide by three feet six in height , hewn out of the living rock , of which it had formed part , and was still attached to at the base . These tables were slightly hollowed out or curved inward , to give room for the knees of any one sitting on the stone ledge that had been cut for a bench along the side of [the cave]936-the cave at a distance of about two feet from [them]1609-them . Each of [them]1609-them , also , was so arranged that [it]1610-it ended right under a shaft pierced in the rock for the admission of light and air . On examining them carefully , however , [I]0-i saw that there was a difference between them that had at first escaped [my]0-i attention , viz . that one of the tables , that to the left as [we]1606-us entered [the cave]936-the cave , had evidently been used , not to eat upon , but for the purposes of embalming . That this was beyond all question the case was clear from five shallow depressions in the stone of the table , all shaped like a human form , with a separate place for the head to lie in , and a little bridge to support the neck , each depression being of a different size , so as to fit bodies varying in stature from [a full - grown man]1612-a full - grown man 's to [a small child 's , and with little holes bored at intervals to carry off fluid]1613-a small child 's , and with little holes bored at intervals to carry off fluid . And , indeed , if any further confirmation was required , [we]1606-us had but to look at the wall of the cave above to find it . For there , sculptured all round [the apartment]1614-the apartment , and looking nearly as fresh as the day it was done , was the pictorial representation of the death , embalming , and burial of [an old man with a long beard]1615-an old man with a long beard , probably [an ancient king or grandee of [this country]302-this country]1616-an ancient king or grandee of this country .

The first picture represented [his]1615-an old man with a long beard death . [He]1615-an old man with a long beard was lying upon a couch which had four short curved posts at the corners coming to a knob at the end , in appearance something like written notes of music , and was evidently in the very act of expiring . Gathered round the couch were [women]327-women and [children]395-children weeping , the former with [their]1620-their hair hanging down [their]1620-their backs . The next scene represented the embalmment of the body , which lay stark upon a table with depressions in it , similar to the one before [us]1606-us ; probably , indeed , it was a picture of the same table . [Three men]3418-three men were employed at the work - one superintending , one holding a funnel shaped exactly like a port wine strainer , of which the narrow end was fixed in an incision in the breast , no doubt in the great pectoral artery ; while [the third , who was depicted as standing straddle - legged over the corpse]1622-the third , who was depicted as standing straddle - legged over the corpse , held a kind of large jug high in [his]1622-the third , who was depicted as standing straddle - legged over the corpse hand , and poured from it some steaming fluid which fell accurately into the funnel . The most curious part of this sculpture is that both [the man with the funnel]1623-the man with the funnel and [the man who pours the fluid]1624-the man who pours the fluid are drawn holding [their]3418-three men noses , either [I]0-i suppose because of the stench arising from the body , or more probably to keep out the aromatic fumes of the hot fluid which was being forced into [the dead man]1625-the dead man 's veins . Another curious thing which [I]0-i am unable to explain is that [all three men]1626-all three men were represented as having a band of linen tied round the face with holes in it for the eyes .

The third sculpture was a picture of the burial of [the deceased]1190-the deceased . There [he]1615-an old man with a long beard was , stiff and cold , clothed in a linen robe , and laid out on a stone slab such as [I]0-i had slept upon at [our]1606-us first sojourning - place . At [his]1615-an old man with a long beard head and feet burnt lamps , and by [his]1615-an old man with a long beard side were placed several of the beautiful painted vases that [I]0-i have described , which were perhaps supposed to be full of provisions . [The little chamber]1312-the little chamber was crowded with [mourners]1629-mourners , and with [musicians playing on an instrument resembling a lyre]1630-musicians playing on an instrument resembling a lyre , while near the foot of the corpse stood [a man]352-a man holding a sheet , with which [he]352-a man was preparing to cover it from view .

These sculptures , looked at merely as works of art , were so remarkable that [I]0-i make no apology for describing them rather fully . [They]1632-they struck [me]0-i also as being of surpassing interest as representing , probably with studious accuracy , the last rites of [the dead]1054-the dead as practised among [an utterly lost people]1634-an utterly lost people , and even then [I]0-i thought how envious [some antiquarian friends of [my]0-i own at [Cambridge]2-cambridge]1635-some antiquarian friends of my own at cambridge would be if ever [I]0-i found an opportunity of describing these wonderful remains to [them]1635-some antiquarian friends of my own at cambridge . Probably [they]1635-some antiquarian friends of my own at cambridge would say that [I]0-i was exaggerating , notwithstanding that every page of this history must bear so much internal evidence of its truth that it would obviously have been quite impossible for [me]0-i to have invented it .

To return . As soon as [I]0-i had hastily examined these sculptures , which [I]0-i think [I]0-i omitted to mention were executed in relief , [we]1636-we sat down to a very excellent meal of boiled goat's - flesh , fresh milk , and cakes made of meal , the whole being served upon clean wooden platters .

When [we]1636-we had eaten [we]1636-we returned to see how [Leo]183-leo was getting on , [Billali]137-job saying that [he]183-leo must now wait upon [She]1637-she , and hear [her]1637-she commands . On reaching [[Leo]183-leo 's room]1638-leo 's room [we]1636-we found [the poor boy]1639-the poor boy in a very bad way . [He]1639-the poor boy had woke up from [his]1639-the poor boy torpor , and was altogether off [his]1639-the poor boy head , babbling about some boat - race on [the Cam]59-the cam , and was inclined to be violent . Indeed , when [we]1636-we entered [the room]449-the room [Ustane]172-ustane was holding [him]1639-the poor boy down . [I]0-i spoke to [him]1639-the poor boy , and [my]0-i voice seemed to soothe [him]1639-the poor boy ; at any rate [he]1639-the poor boy grew much quieter , and was persuaded to swallow a dose of quinine .

[I]0-i had been sitting with [him]1639-the poor boy for an hour , perhaps - at any rate [I]0-i know that it was getting so dark that [I]0-i could only just make out [his]1639-the poor boy head lying like a gleam of gold upon the pillow [we]1636-we had extemporised out of a bag covered with a blanket - when suddenly [Billali]137-job arrived with an air of great importance , and informed [me]0-i that [She]1641-she [herself]1641-she had deigned to express a wish to see [me]0-i - an honour , [he]1639-the poor boy added , accorded to but very few . [I]0-i think that [he]1639-the poor boy was a little horrified at [my]0-i cool way of taking the honour , but the fact was that [I]0-i did not feel overwhelmed with gratitude at the prospect of seeing [some savage , dusky queen]1642-some savage , dusky queen , however absolute and mysterious [she]1642-some savage , dusky queen might be , more especially as [my]0-i mind was full of dear [Leo]183-leo , for whose life [I]0-i began to have great fears . However , [I]0-i rose to follow [him]1639-the poor boy , and as [I]0-i did so [I]0-i caught sight of something bright lying on the floor , which [I]0-i picked up . Perhaps [the reader]298-the reader will remember that with the potsherd in the casket was a composition scarabæus marked with a round O , a goose , and another curious hieroglyphic , the meaning of which is " Suten se Ra , "[183-leo] or " [Royal Son of the Sun]3014-royal son of the sun . "[183-leo] The scarab , which is a very small one , [Leo]183-leo had insisted upon having set in a massive gold ring , such as is generally used for signets , and it was this very ring that [I]0-i now picked up . [He]183-leo had pulled it off in the paroxysm of [his]183-leo fever , at least [I]0-i suppose so , and flung it down upon the rock - floor . Thinking that if [I]0-i left it about it might get lost , [I]0-i slipped it on [my]0-i own little finger , and then followed [Billali]137-job , leaving [Job]137-job and [Ustane]172-ustane with [Leo]183-leo .

[We]1644-we passed down [the passage]1645-the passage , crossed the great aisle - like cave , and came to [the corresponding passage on the other side]1646-the corresponding passage on the other side , at the mouth of which [the guards]1647-the guards stood like two statues . As [we]1644-we came [they]1647-the guards bowed [their]1647-the guards heads in salutation , and then lifting [their]1647-the guards long spears placed them transversely across [their]1647-the guards foreheads , as [the leaders of the troop that had met [us]1644-we had done with [their]1648-the leaders of the troop that had met us had done with their ivory wands ivory wands]1648-the leaders of the troop that had met us had done with their ivory wands . [We]1644-we stepped between [them]1647-the guards , and found [ourselves]1644-we in [an exactly similar gallery to that which led to [[our]1644-we own apartments]1650-our own apartments]1649-an exactly similar gallery to that which led to our own apartments , only [this passage]1573-this passage was , comparatively speaking , brilliantly lighted . A few paces down [it]1573-this passage [we]1644-we were met by [four mutes]1652-four mutes - [two men]1356-two men and [two women]1173-two women - who bowed low and then arranged [themselves]1652-four mutes , [the women in front]1655-the women in front and [the men behind of [us]1644-we]1656-the men behind of us , and in this order [we]1644-we continued [our]1644-we procession past several doorways hung with curtains resembling those leading to [[our]1644-we own quarters]1657-our own quarters , and which [I]0-i afterwards found opened out into chambers occupied by [the mutes who attended on [She]1659-she]1658-the mutes who attended on she . A few paces more and [we]1644-we came to another doorway facing [us]1644-we , and not to [our]1644-we left like the others , which seemed to mark the termination of [the passage]1645-the passage . Here [two more white- , or rather yellow - robed guards]1661-two more white- , or rather yellow - robed guards were standing , and [they]1661-two more white- , or rather yellow - robed guards too bowed , saluted , and let [us]1644-we pass through heavy curtains into a great antechamber , quite forty feet long by as many wide , in which some eight or ten women , most of [them]1662-them young and handsome , with yellowish hair , sat on cushions working with ivory needles at what had the appearance of being embroidery frames . [These women]942-these women were also deaf and dumb . At the farther end of [this great lamp - lit apartment]1664-this great lamp - lit apartment was another doorway closed in with heavy Oriental - looking curtains , quite unlike those that hung before the doors of [[our]1644-we own rooms]1665-our own rooms , and here stood [two particularly handsome girl mutes]1666-two particularly handsome girl mutes , [their]1666-two particularly handsome girl mutes heads bowed upon [their]1666-two particularly handsome girl mutes bosoms and [their]1666-two particularly handsome girl mutes hands crossed in an attitude of humble submission . As [we]1644-we advanced [they]1666-two particularly handsome girl mutes each stretched out an arm and drew back the curtains . Thereupon [Billali]137-job did a curious thing . Down [he]137-job went , [that venerable - looking old gentleman]1667-that venerable - looking old gentleman - for [Billali]137-job is [a gentleman at the bottom]1668-a gentleman at the bottom - down on to [his]137-job hands and knees , and in this undignified position , with [his]137-job long white beard trailing on the ground , [he]137-job began to creep into [the apartment beyond]1669-the apartment beyond . [I]0-i followed [him]137-job , standing on [my]0-i feet in the usual fashion . Looking over [his]137-job shoulder [he]137-job perceived it .

" Down , [[my]137-job son]3150-my son ; down , [[my]137-job Baboon]3510-my baboon ; down on to [thy]3510-my baboon hands and knees . [We]3638-we enter the presence of [She]3639-she , and , if [thou]3510-my baboon art not humble , of a surety [she]3639-she will blast [thee]3510-my baboon where [thou]3510-my baboon standest . "[137-job]

[I]0-i halted , and felt scared . Indeed , [my]0-i knees began to give way of their own mere motion ; but reflection came to [my]0-i aid . [I]0-i was [an Englishman]1670-an englishman , and why , [I]0-i asked [myself]0-i , should [I]0-i creep into the presence of [some savage woman]1671-some savage woman as though [I]0-i were [a monkey in fact as well as in name]1672-a monkey in fact as well as in name ? [I]0-i would not and could not do it , that is , unless [I]0-i was absolutely sure that [my]0-i life or comfort depended upon it . If once [I]0-i began to creep upon [my]0-i knees [I]0-i should always have to do so , and it would be a patent acknowledgment of inferiority . So , fortified by an insular prejudice against " kootooing , "[137-job] which has , like most of [our]1673-our so - called prejudices , a good deal of common sense to recommend it , [I]0-i marched in boldly after [Billali]137-job . [I]0-i found [myself]0-i in [another apartment]1674-another apartment , considerably smaller than the anteroom , of which the walls were entirely hung with rich - looking curtains of the same make as those over the door , the work , as [I]0-i subsequently discovered , of [the mutes who sat in the antechamber]1675-the mutes who sat in the antechamber and wove [them]1675-the mutes who sat in the antechamber in strips , which were afterwards sewn together . Also , here and there about [the room]449-the room , were settees of a beautiful black wood of the ebony tribe , inlaid with ivory , and all over the floor were other tapestries , or rather rugs . At the top end of [this apartment]1677-this apartment was what appeared to be a recess , also draped with curtains , through which shone rays of light . There was [nobody]488-nobody in [the place]1059-the place except [ourselves]1673-our .

Painfully and slowly [old Billali]137-job crept up the length of [the cave]936-the cave , and with the most dignified stride that [I]0-i could command [I]0-i followed after [him]137-job . But [I]0-i felt that it was more or less of a failure . To begin with , it is not possible to look dignified when [you]1681-you are following in the wake of [an old man]907-an old man writhing along on [his]907-an old man stomach like a snake , and then , in order to go sufficiently slowly , either [I]0-i had to keep [my]0-i leg some seconds in the air at every step , or else to advance with a full stop between each stride , like [Mary Queen of Scots]189-queen going to execution in a play . [Billali]137-job was not good at crawling , [I]0-i suppose [his]137-job years stood in the way , and [our]1673-our progress up [that apartment]1683-that apartment was a very long affair . [I]0-i was immediately behind [him]137-job , and several times [I]0-i was sorely tempted to help [him]137-job on with a good kick . It is so absurd to advance into the presence of [savage royalty]1684-savage royalty after the fashion of [an Irishman driving a pig to market]1685-an irishman driving a pig to market , for that is what [we]1673-our looked like , and the idea nearly made [me]0-i burst out laughing then and there . [I]0-i had to work off [my]0-i dangerous tendency to unseemly merriment by blowing [my]0-i nose , a proceeding which filled [old Billali]190-billali with horror , for [he]137-job looked over [his]137-job shoulder and made a ghastly face at [me]0-i , and [I]0-i heard [him]137-job murmur , " Oh , [[my]137-job poor Baboon]3640-my poor baboon ! "[137-job]

At last [we]1673-our reached the curtains , and here [Billali]190-billali collapsed flat on to [his]190-billali stomach , with [his]190-billali hands stretched out before [him]190-billali as though [he]190-billali were dead , and [I]0-i , not knowing what to do , began to stare about [the place]1059-the place . But presently [I]0-i clearly felt that [somebody]357-somebody was looking at [me]0-i from behind the curtains . [I]0-i could not see [the person]1688-the person , but [I]0-i could distinctly feel [his]1689-his or [her]1690-her gaze , and , what is more , it produced a very odd effect upon [my]0-i nerves . [I]0-i was frightened , [I]0-i do not know why . [The place]1059-the place was [a strange one]1692-a strange one , it is true , and looked lonely , notwithstanding [its]1059-the place rich hangings and the soft glow of the lamps - indeed , these accessories added to , rather than detracted from its loneliness , just as [a lighted street]1693-a lighted street at night has always a more solitary appearance than a dark one . It was so silent in [the place]1059-the place , and there lay [Billali]190-billali like one dead before the heavy curtains , through which the odour of perfume seemed to float up towards the gloom of the arched roof above . Minute grew into minute , and still there was no sign of life , nor did the curtain move ; but [I]0-i felt the gaze of the unknown being sinking through and through [me]0-i , and filling [me]0-i with a nameless terror , till the perspiration stood in beads upon [my]0-i brow .

At length the curtain began to move . Who could be behind it ? - [some naked savage queen]1695-some naked savage queen , [a languishing Oriental beauty]1696-a languishing oriental beauty , or [a nineteenth - century young lady]1697-a nineteenth - century young lady , drinking afternoon tea ? [I]0-i had not the slightest idea , and should not have been astonished at seeing any of the three . [I]0-i was getting beyond astonishment . The curtain agitated itself a little , then suddenly between its folds there appeared a most beautiful white hand white as snow , and with long tapering fingers , ending in the pinkest nails . The hand grasped the curtain , and drew it aside , and as it did so [I]0-i heard a voice , [I]0-i think the softest and yet most silvery voice [I]0-i ever heard . It reminded [me]0-i of the murmur of a brook .

" [Stranger]3387-stranger , "[0-i] said the voice in Arabic , but much purer and more classical Arabic than the Amahagger talk - ' stranger , wherefore art [thou]1698-thou so much afraid ? "[0-i]

Now [I]0-i flattered [myself]0-i that in spite of [my]0-i inward terrors [I]0-i had kept a very fair command of [my]0-i countenance , and was , therefore , a little astonished at this question . Before [I]0-i had made up [my]0-i mind how to answer it , however , the curtain was drawn , and [a tall figure]1699-a tall figure stood before [us]1700-us . [I]0-i say a figure , for not only the body , but also the face was wrapped up in soft white , gauzy material in such a way as at first sight to remind [me]0-i most forcibly of a corpse in [its]1701-its grave - clothes . And yet [I]0-i do not know why it should have given [me]0-i that idea , seeing that the wrappings were so thin that [one]328-one could distinctly see the gleam of the pink flesh beneath them . [I]0-i suppose it was owing to the way in which they were arranged , either accidentally , or more probably by design . Anyhow , [I]0-i felt more frightened than ever at this ghost - like apparition , and [my]0-i hair began to rise upon [my]0-i head as the feeling crept over [me]0-i that [I]0-i was in the presence of something that was not canny . [I]0-i could , however , clearly distinguish that the swathed mummy - like form before [me]0-i was that of [a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part , and also with a certain snake - like grace which [I]0-i had never seen anything to equal before . When [she]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part moved a hand or foot [her]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part entire frame seemed to undulate , and the neck did not bend , it curved .

" Why art [thou]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part so frightened , [stranger]3387-stranger ? "[1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part] asked the sweet voice again - a voice which seemed to draw the heart out of [me]0-i , like the strains of softest music . " Is there that about [me]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part that should affright [a man]352-a man ? Then surely are [men]516-men changed from what [they]516-men used to be ! "[1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part] And with a little coquettish movement [she]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part turned [herself]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part , and held up one arm , so as to show all [her]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part loveliness and the rich hair of raven blackness that streamed in soft ripples down [her]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part snowy robes , almost to [her]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part sandalled feet .

" It is [thy]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part beauty that makes [me]0-i fear , [oh Queen]3645-oh queen , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered humbly , scarcely knowing what to say , and [I]0-i thought that as [I]0-i did so [I]0-i heard [old Billali]190-billali , who was still lying prostrate on the floor , mutter , " Good , [my]190-billali Baboon , good . "[190-billali]

" [I]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part see that [men]516-men still know how to beguile [[us]3647-us women]3648-us women with false words . Ah , [stranger]3387-stranger , "[1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part] [she]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part answered , with a laugh that sounded like distant silver bells , " [thou]3650-ye wast afraid because [mine]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part eyes were searching out thine heart , therefore wast [thou]3650-ye afraid . Yet being but [a woman]284-a woman , [I]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part forgive [thee]3650-ye for the lie , for it was courteously said . And now tell [me]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part how came [ye]3650-ye hither to [this land of [the dwellers among [the caves]3307-the caves]3653-the dwellers among the caves - [a land of swamps]3655-a land of swamps and evil things and dead old shadows of the dead]3652-this land of the dwellers among the caves - a land of swamps and evil things and dead old shadows of the dead ? What came [ye]3650-ye for to see ? How is it that [ye]3650-ye hold [your]3650-ye lives so cheap as to place [them]3656-them in [the hollow of the hand of [Hiya]174-hiya]3657-the hollow of the hand of hiya , into the hand of ' [She]3658-she - who - must - be - obeyed ' ? Tell [me]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part also how come [ye]3650-ye to know the tongue [I]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part talk . It is an ancient tongue , [that sweet child of [the old Syriac]3660-the old syriac]3659-that sweet child of the old syriac . Liveth it yet in [the world]252-the world ? [Thou]3662-thou seest [I]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part dwell among [the caves]3307-the caves and the dead , and naught know [I]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part of the affairs of [men]516-men , nor have [I]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part cared to know . [I]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part have lived , [O stranger]3665-o stranger , with [my]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part memories , and [my]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part memories are in a grave that [mine]1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part hands hollowed , for truly hath it been said that [the child of man]3666-the child of man maketh [his]3666-the child of man own path evil ; "[1703-a tall and lovely woman , instinct with beauty in every part] and [her]1704-her beautiful voice quivered , and broke in a note as soft as any wood - bird 's . Suddenly [her]1704-her eye fell upon the sprawling frame of [Billali]190-billali , and [she]1704-her seemed to recollect [herself]1704-her .

" Ah ! [thou]3662-thou art there , [old man]3667-old man . Tell [me]1704-her how it is that things have gone wrong in [thine household]3668-thine household . [Forsooth]191-forsooth , it seems that these [[my]1704-her guests]3669-my guests were set upon . Ay , and [one]328-one was nigh to being slain by the hot - pot to be eaten of [those brutes]3671-those brutes , [[thy]3662-thou children]3672-thy children , and had not [the others]847-the others fought gallantly [they]847-the others too had been slain , and not even [I]1704-her could have called back the life which had been loosed from the body . What means it , [old man]3667-old man ? What hast [thou]3675-thy to say that [I]1704-her should not give [thee]3675-thy over to [those who execute [my]1704-her vengeance]3676-those who execute my vengeance ? "[1704-her]

[Her]1705-her voice had risen in [her]1705-her anger , and it rang clear and cold against the rocky walls . Also [I]0-i thought [I]0-i could see [her]1705-her eyes flash through the gauze that hid them . [I]0-i saw [poor [Billali]190-billali , whom [I]0-i had believed to be [a very fearless person]1706-a very fearless person]190-billali , positively quiver with terror at [her]1705-her words .

" Oh ' Hiya ! ' oh [She]1705-her ! "[190-billali] [he]190-billali said , without lifting [his]190-billali white head from the floor . " Oh [She]1705-her , as [thou]3675-thy art great be merciful , for [I]190-billali am now as ever [[thy]3675-thy servant]3677-thy servant to obey . It was no plan or fault of [mine]190-billali , oh [She]1705-her , it was [those wicked ones who are called [[my]190-billali children]3679-my children]3678-those wicked ones who are called my children . Led on by [a woman whom [[thy]3675-thy guest]3681-thy guest [the Pig]3682-the pig had scorned , [they]3678-those wicked ones who are called my children would have followed the ancient custom of [the land]670-the land]3680-a woman whom thy guest the pig had scorned , they would have followed the ancient custom of the land , and eaten [the fat black stranger]3684-the fat black stranger who came hither with [these [thy]3675-thy guests the Baboon and the Lion who is sick , thinking that no word had come from [thee]3675-thy about [the Black one]3380-the black one]3685-these thy guests the baboon and the lion who is sick , thinking that no word had come from thee about the black one . But when [the Baboon]180-the baboon and [the Lion]799-the lion saw what [they]3678-those wicked ones who are called my children would do , [they]3678-those wicked ones who are called my children slew [the woman]3243-the woman , and slew also [[their]3678-those wicked ones who are called my children servant]3689-their servant to save [him]3689-their servant from the horror of the pot . Then [those evil ones]3690-those evil ones , ay , [those children of the Wicked One who lives in the Pit]3691-those children of the wicked one who lives in the pit , [they]3690-those evil ones went mad with the lust of blood , and flew at the throats of the Lion and [the Baboon]3497-the baboon and [the Pig]3682-the pig . But gallantly [they]3690-those evil ones fought . Oh Hiya ! [they]3690-those evil ones fought like [very men]3694-very men , and slew many , and held [their]3690-those evil ones own , and then [I]190-billali came and saved [them]3690-those evil ones , and [the evildoers]3695-the evildoers have [I]190-billali sent on hither to [K"r]56-k"r[190-billali] to be judged of [thy]1707-thee greatness , oh [She]1708-she ! and here [they]1709-they are . "[1708-she]

" Ay , [old man]3667-old man , [I]190-billali know it , and to - morrow will [I]190-billali sit in [the great hall]3697-the great hall and do justice upon [them]1709-they , fear not . And for [thee]1707-thee , [I]190-billali forgive [thee]1707-thee , though hardly . See that [thou]1707-thee dost keep [thine]1707-thee household better . Go . "[190-billali]

[Billali]190-billali rose upon [his]190-billali knees with astonishing alacrity , bowed [his]190-billali head thrice , and [his]190-billali white beard sweeping the ground , crawled down [the apartment]1614-the apartment as [he]190-billali had crawled up [it]1614-the apartment , till [he]190-billali finally vanished through the curtains , leaving [me]0-i , not a little to [my]0-i alarm , alone with [this terrible but most fascinating person]1711-this terrible but most fascinating person .

[XIII

AYESHA]192-xiii ayesha UNVEILS

" There , "[1712-she] said [She]1712-she , " [he]190-billali has gone , [the white - bearded old fool]3698-the white - bearded old fool ! Ah , how little knowledge does [a man]352-a man acquire in [his]352-a man life . [He]352-a man gathereth it up like water , but like water it runneth through [his]352-a man fingers , and yet , if [his]352-a man hands be but wet as though with dew , behold [a generation of [fools]3701-fools]3700-a generation of fools call out , ' See , [he]352-a man is [a wise man]3581-a wise man ! ' Is it not so ? But how call [they]3700-a generation of fools [thee]3700-a generation of fools ? ' [Baboon]180-the baboon , ' [he]190-billali says , "[1712-she] and [she]1712-she laughed ; " but that is the fashion of [these savages who lack imagination]3703-these savages who lack imagination , and fly to the beasts [they]3703-these savages who lack imagination resemble for a name . How do [they]3700-a generation of fools call [thee]3700-a generation of fools in [thine own country]3704-thine own country , [stranger]3387-stranger ? "[1712-she]

" [They]3700-a generation of fools call [me]0-i [Holly]109-holly , oh Queen , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered .

" [Holly]109-holly , "[1712-she] [she]1712-she answered , speaking the word with difficulty , and yet with a most charming accent ; " and what is ' [Holly]109-holly ' ? "[1712-she]

" ' [Holly]109-holly ' is a prickly tree , "[0-i] [I]0-i said .

" So . Well , [thou]3706-thou hast a prickly and yet a tree - like look . Strong art [thou]3706-thou , and ugly , but if [my]1713-i wisdom be not at fault , honest at the core , and a staff to lean on . Also one who thinks . But stay , oh [Holly]109-holly , stand not there , enter with [me]1713-i and be seated by [me]1713-i . [I]1713-i would not see [thee]3706-thou crawl before [me]1713-i like [those slaves]3707-those slaves . [I]1713-i am aweary of [their]3707-those slaves worship and [their]3707-those slaves terror ; sometimes when [they]3707-those slaves vex [me]1713-i [I]1713-i could blast [them]3707-those slaves for very sport , and to see the rest turn white , even to the heart . "[1713-i] And [she]1713-i held the curtain aside with [her]1713-i ivory hand to let [me]0-i pass in .

[I]0-i entered , shuddering . [This woman]1714-this woman was very terrible . Within the curtains was a recess , about twelve feet by ten , and in the recess was a couch and a table whereon stood fruit and sparkling water . By [it]1715-it , at [its]1715-it end , was a vessel like a font cut in carved stone , also full of pure water . [The place]1059-the place was softly lit with lamps formed out of the beautiful vessels of which [I]0-i have spoken , and the air and curtains were laden with a subtle perfume . Perfume too seemed to emanate from the glorious hair and white - clinging vestments of [She]1713-i [herself]1713-i . [I]0-i entered [the little room]1717-the little room , and there stood uncertain .

" Sit , "[1713-i] said [She]1713-i , pointing to the couch . " As yet [thou]3708-thou hast no cause to fear [me]1713-i . If [thou]3708-thou hast cause , [thou]3708-thou shalt not fear for long , for [I]1713-i shall slay [thee]3708-thou . Therefore let [thy]3708-thou heart be light . "[1713-i]

[I]0-i sat down on the foot of the couch near to the font - like basin of water , and [She]1713-i sank down softly on to the other end .

" Now , [Holly]109-holly , "[1713-i] [she]1713-i said , " how comest [thou]3708-thou to speak Arabic ? It is [my]1713-i own dear tongue , for [Arabian]193-arabian am [I]1713-i by [my]1713-i birth , even ' al Arab al [Ariba]61-ariba ' [an Arab of [the Arabs]170-arabs]3709-an arab of the arabs , and of the race of [[our]3710-our father]3565-our father Yárab , [the son of Kâhtan]3712-the son of kâhtan , for in [that fair and ancient city Ozal]3713-that fair and ancient city ozal was [I]1713-i born , in [the province of]3714-the province of [Yaman]62-yaman [the Happy]3715-the happy . Yet dost [thou]3708-thou not speak it as [we]3710-our used to speak . [Thy]3708-thou talk doth lack the music of the sweet tongue of [the tribes of [Hamyar]63-hamyar which [I]1713-i was wo nt to hear]3716-the tribes of hamyar which i was wo nt to hear . Some of the words too seemed changed , even as among these [Amahagger]171-the amahagger , who have debased and defiled its purity , so that [I]1713-i must speak with [them]171-the amahagger in what is to [me]1713-i another tongue . "[1713-i]

Yárab [the son of Kâhtan]3712-the son of kâhtan , who lived some centuries before the time of [Abraham]194-abraham , was [the father of [the ancient Arabs]1720-the ancient arabs]1719-the father of the ancient arabs , and gave its name [Araba]64-araba to [the country]3308-the country . In speaking of [herself]1722-she as " [al Arab al [Ariba]61-ariba]3717-al arab al ariba , "[1722-she] [She]1722-she no doubt meant to convey that [she]1722-she was of the true Arab blood as distinguished from [the naturalised Arabs]1723-the naturalised arabs , [the descendants of [Ismael]196-ismael]1724-the descendants of ismael , [the son of [Abraham]194-abraham and [Hagar]197-hagar , who were known as " al Arab al mostáraba]3718-the son of abraham and hagar , who were known as " al arab al mostáraba . "[1722-she] The dialect of [the Koreish]198-the koreish was usually called the clear or " perspicuous "[198-the koreish] Arabic , but the Hamaritic dialect approached nearer to the purity of the mother Syriac . - L. H. H.

" [I]0-i have studied it , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered , " for many years . Also the language is spoken in [Egypt]8-egypt and elsewhere . "[0-i]

" So it is still spoken , and there is yet an [Egypt]8-egypt ? And what [Pharaoh]199-pharaoh sits upon the throne ? Still one of [the spawn of the Persian Ochús]3719-the spawn of the persian ochús , or are [the Achæmenians]200-the achæmenians gone , for far is it to the days of [Ochús]201-ochús . "[1725-she]

" [The Persians]3350-the persians have been gone for [Egypt]8-egypt for nigh two thousand years , and since then [the Ptolemies]3721-the ptolemies , [the Romans]3722-the romans , and many others have flourished and held sway upon [the Nile]65-the nile , and fallen when [their]3723-their time was ripe , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , aghast . " What canst [thou]3724-thou know of [the Persian Artaxerxes]202-the persian artaxerxes ? "[0-i]

[She]1725-she laughed , and made no answer , and again a cold chill went through [me]0-i . " And [Greece]18-greece , "[1725-she] [she]1725-she said ; " is there still [a Greece]18-greece ? Ah , [I]1725-she loved [the Greeks]203-the greeks . Beautiful were [they]203-the greeks as the day , and clever , but fierce at heart and fickle , notwithstanding . "[1725-she]

" Yes , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " there is [a Greece]3725-a greece ; and , just now , it is once more [a people]3726-a people . Yet [the Greeks of to - day]3727-the greeks of to - day are not what [the Greeks of the old time]3728-the greeks of the old time were , and [Greece]18-greece herself is but a mockery of the [Greece]18-greece that was . "[0-i]

" So ! [The Hebrews]3729-the hebrews , are [they]3729-the hebrews yet at [Jerusalem]67-jerusalem ? And does [the Temple that [the wise king]3731-the wise king built]3730-the temple that the wise king built stand , and if so what [God]134-god do [they]3729-the hebrews worship therein ?
